Title: Bristow First Assembly of God v. BP p.l.c.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, church, pastor, and pastor's wife produced no evidence that alleged "public wrong" of pollution of church property by previous operation of oil refinery was caused by fraud or manipulation of corporate structure of successors-in-interest to oil company that acquired property after refinery stopped operations, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold a Delaware energy company, which acquired corporation whose subsidiary was indirectly a parent corporation of the oil company, liable for pollution under negligence and other theories.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Nuisance. Church knew or should have known that its property was contaminated by oil more than two years before it filed nuisance and other claims.

Title: Bristow First Assembly of God v. BP p.l.c.

Title: Cyprus Amax Minerals Company v. TCI Pacific Communications, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, unjust outcome would have resulted to third parties if district court had refused to pierce corporate veil of subsidiary of limited liability company's (LLC) predecessor, as relevant to LLC's liability under CERCLA for remediation of area in which subsidiary had operated a zinc smelter; LLC's position that subsidiary was an entirely separate corporation from predecessor was contrary to predecessor's representation before the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) nearly a century earlier that subsidiary was merely an instrumentality of predecessor, and practice of holding subsidiary out as distinct entity while representing subsidiary as mere component of predecessor could be seen as fraudulent attempt to skirt Kansas law. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 § 101, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. Company was liable for contribution under CERCLA based on operation of zinc smelter by subsidiary of company's predecessor.

Title: Cyprus Amax Minerals Company v. TCI Pacific Communications, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, factors for determining whether subsidiary was alter ego of parent supported finding that subsidiary of limited liability company's (LLC) predecessor was predecessor's alter ego, as relevant to LLC's liability under CERCLA for remediation of area in which subsidiary had operated a zinc smelter; it was logical to conclude that predecessor had been flouting Kansas law to operate subsidiary at time when ability of a foreign entity to invest in Kansas was limited, predecessor conducted itself as if it owned all of predecessor's capital stock, predecessor and subsidiary shared common officers and directors, and predecessor's own statements suggested that any distinction between predecessor and subsidiary was mere formality. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 § 101, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. Company was liable for contribution under CERCLA based on operation of zinc smelter by subsidiary of company's predecessor.

Title: Cyprus Amax Minerals Company v. TCI Pacific Communications, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, lack of stock ownership in subsidiary on part of limited liability company's (LLC) predecessor did not preclude finding that subsidiary was predecessor's alter ego, as relevant to LLC's liability under CERCLA for remediation of area in which subsidiary had operated a zinc smelter; stock ownership was only one of ten factors to consider for determining alter ego status under Kansas law, affording lack of stock ownership nearly dispositive weight would allow parent companies to avoid veil piercing while disregarding corporate separateness in practice, and ample facts supported determination that predecessor in fact owned subsidiary despite on-paper representations of ownership. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 § 101, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. Company was liable for contribution under CERCLA based on operation of zinc smelter by subsidiary of company's predecessor.

Title: Cyprus Amax Minerals Company v. TCI Pacific Communications, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence supported determination that, under Kansas law, subsidiary of limited liability company's (LLC) predecessor was predecessor's alter ego throughout subsidiary's 20-year existence, rather than for just a five-year period within the larger span, as relevant to LLC's liability under CERCLA for remediation of area in which subsidiary had operated a zinc smelter; subsidiary was predecessor's alter ego at least throughout the five-year period, no evidence indicated that material circumstances changed before or after that period, individuals affiliated with predecessor incorporated subsidiary, and predecessor received the dividend paid when subsidiary ceased operation, not the individuals listed as subsidiary's shareholders. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 § 101, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. Company was liable for contribution under CERCLA based on operation of zinc smelter by subsidiary of company's predecessor.

Title: Seattle Times Company v. LeatherCare, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: District Court did not clearly err in determining that corporate successor of former owner of commercial property contaminated by halogenated hydrocarbons and petroleum products did not assume liabilities of former owner, in current property owner's action to recover costs of remediation and cleanup expenses with respect to soil and groundwater, under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) and Washington's Model Toxics Control Act (MTCA), absent evidence that former owner's corporate formalities were disregarded after it became subsidiary of acquiring corporation. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq.; Wash. Rev. Code Ann. § 70.105D.010 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. Interim action plan for remediation of property did not comply with national contingency plan, precluding former owner's CERCLA claim against tenant.

Title: Atlantic Richfield Co. v. Central Valley Regional Water Quality Control Bd.
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Under federal law, a parent corporation is subject to derivative liability for a subsidiary's discharge of hazardous waste where circumstances are present that would traditionally allow the application of the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  Hazardous Waste. Trial court could not base holding that parent company was not directly liable for hazardous waste solely on lack of involvement in waste disposal.

Title: A.O.A. v. Rennert
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Peruvian children demonstrated that piercing the corporate veil was warranted under Missouri and New York law in action against American companies to recover for injuries allegedly caused by pollution at metallurgical smelting and refining complex owned and operated by the defendant companies and their Peruvian subsidiary, based on allegations that defendants controlled the policy and decision-making processes of Peruvian subsidiary through various agreements for professional, technical, and managerial services, undercapitalization of Peruvian subsidiary left the company unable to implement environmental protection measures, and it was foreseeable that the lack of pollution-control technology could result in harm because of the danger from un-remediated toxic emissions.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Allegations that Peruvian children were injured by refinery's pollution were sufficient to state plausible claims of negligence.

Title: Trinity Industries, Inc. v. Greenlease Holding Company
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Direct and derivative liability are two analytically distinct bases for holding a parent company liable for environmental cleanup costs resulting from a subsidiary's conduct. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 § 113, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9613(f)(1).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not directly liable for its subsidiary's share of responsibility for environmental contamination at manufacturing facility.

Title: Trinity Industries, Inc. v. Greenlease Holding Company
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation can be held derivatively liable under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) for its subsidiary's actions only when the corporate veil may be pierced, and the corporate veil may be pierced only in extraordinary circumstances, such as when the corporate form would otherwise be misused to accomplish certain wrongful purposes. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not directly liable for its subsidiary's share of responsibility for environmental contamination at manufacturing facility.

Title: Trinity Industries, Inc. v. Greenlease Holding Company
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Railcar manufacturing facility owner could not pierce corporate veil under federal law, and thus, former owner's parent corporation was not derivatively liable under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) for former owner's share of responsibility for environmental contamination at the facility, where former owner was not undercapitalized while operating the facility, and former owner functioned with autonomy on decisions concerning manufacturing, environmental compliance, and waste disposal. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not directly liable for its subsidiary's share of responsibility for environmental contamination at manufacturing facility.

Title: Trinity Industries, Inc. v. Greenlease Holding Company
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Railcar manufacturing facility owner could not pierce corporate veil under Pennsylvania law, and thus, former owner's parent corporation was not derivatively liable under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) for former owner's share of responsibility for environmental contamination at the facility; record did not indicate that parent corporation misused separate corporate entities for some nefarious purpose, and permitting owner to pierce corporate veil would result in rendering useless parent corporation's legitimate use of corporate form when setting up former owner as subsidiary. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.

Title: Rice v. First Energy Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania, Pittsburgh.
Headnote: Subsidiary power station owner was not the alter ego of energy corporation parent, and thus parent corporation was not liable for environmental contamination stemming from power station coal ash emanating from refuse site, although parent was sole member of subsidiary, the parties filed consolidated financial statements and engaged in intra-company borrowing and repayment, and parent received dividends from subsidiary, where parent did not control subsidiary's daily affairs and day-to-day operations, payment of dividends indicated companies observed corporate formalities, and parent at best had some involvement in subsidiary's decision to deactivate power station.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES  Electricity. Energy corporations were not liable for coal ash contamination stemming from power plants owned by subsidiaries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1063 Environmental liabilities and violations >
Title: Rice v. First Energy Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania, Pittsburgh.
Headnote: Summary judgment evidence was insufficient to establish that energy corporation was the alter ego of power plant operator, and thus was liable for environmental contamination caused by coal ash deposited at refuse site; summary judgment evidence included evidence that corporation's subsidiary, which itself owned power plant operator, had deactivated power plant, that subsidiary had filed rate schedule, that energy corporation was subsidiary's parent, and that subsidiary held itself out as the owner and operator of the power plant.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES  Electricity. Energy corporations were not liable for coal ash contamination stemming from power plants owned by subsidiaries.

Title: Seattle Times Company v. LeatherCare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil of parent company of former owner of property contaminated by halogenated hydrocarbons used in dry cleaning operations and by petroleum products was not warranted in order to hold parent company liable under CERCLA or related state law for former owner's share, if any, of current owner's remedial action costs; there was no evidence that parent company, which had acquired former owner as sole shareholder, had disregarded former owner's corporate identity, manipulated entities to avoid any legal duty or perpetrate a fraud, or otherwise behaved in a manner that would justify piercing corporate veil. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.; Wash. Rev. Code Ann. § 70.105D.010 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  Hazardous Substances. Former owner of contaminated property was 31/103 liable under MTCA for current owner's groundwater treatment and regulatory review expenses.

Title: Duke Energy Florida, LLC v. FirstEnergy Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Former parent of former utility company subsidiaries that released hazardous waste while operating gas plants and caused significant environmental harm requiring ongoing cleanup operations dominated and controlled key aspects of subsidiaries' operations prior to parent filing for bankruptcy, in support of parent's successor qualifying as potentially responsible party (PRP) indirectly liable for contribution and response cleanup costs, under CERCLA, by piercing corporate veil between parent and subsidiaries, under Florida law, where parent owned majority of subsidiaries' stock, parent and subsidiaries shared overlapping officers and directors, and subsidiaries were unable to act independently of parent that made key decisions in New York directing all of subsidiaries' operations in Florida. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 § 107, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(4).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. Corporate parent's successor was not indirectly liable under CERCLA for cleanup costs for former subsidiaries' release of hazardous waste.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1063 Environmental liabilities and violations >
Title: Duke Energy Florida, LLC v. FirstEnergy Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Officials of former parent lacked fraudulent or improper purpose in allowing former subsidiaries to release hazardous waste while operating gas plants that caused significant environmental harm requiring ongoing cleanup operations, such that corporate veil could not be pierced between parent and subsidiaries, under Florida law, and thus, parent's successor did not qualify as "potentially responsible party" (PRP), within meaning of CERCLA, and was not indirectly liable for contribution and response cleanup costs, where parent did not purposefully avoid environmental liability or cut costs at expense of environment, and there was no evidence that parent's officials were even aware of environmental costs of their business model that released hazardous wastes decades before CERCLA was enacted. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 § 107, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(4).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. Corporate parent's successor was not indirectly liable under CERCLA for cleanup costs for former subsidiaries' release of hazardous waste.

Title: MRP Properties, LLC v. United States
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Northern Division.
Headnote: The question in determining whether a parent corporation is liable under CERCLA for the activities of its subsidiary, is not whether the parent operates the subsidiary, but rather whether it operates the facility, and that operation is evidenced by participation in the activities of the facility, not the subsidiary; control of the subsidiary, if extensive enough, gives rise to indirect liability under piercing doctrine, not direct liability under the statutory language. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 § 107, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(3).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. Owners of refineries failed to state that their remediation actions were consistent with the National Contingency Plan.

Title: New Jersey Dept. of Environmental Protection v. Navillus Group
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to pierce corporate veil of subsequent owner of mercury-contaminated real property following its purchase from prior purchaser for $1, despite contention that commingling of funds occurred when owner provided funds for prior purchaser's purchase; alleged commingling of funds was based on assumption from attorney in deposition of owner's employee or shareholder, evidence did not explain whether owner's provision of funds to purchaser was for business purpose or other reason, and owner's purchase of property for $1 and distribution of assets to shareholders or employees, without evidence of reason for transfers, were inadequate to pierce veil.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Hazardous Substances. Purchaser of mercury-contaminated real property was not innocent purchaser under Spill Compensation and Control Act.

Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Engine importer's sole employee did not engage in fraud or other misfeasance, as required under Mississippi law to pierce corporate veil and hold employee individually liable as importer's alter ego in action to recover for civil penalties it paid for violation of Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) emission and labeling standards, although engines employee assisted in ordering on behalf of importer for reseller did not comport with EPA specifications, where employee did not use reseller's payments for her own personal benefit, or use importer as a shell corporation as a shield from personal liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole employee of corporation did not engage in fraud or other misfeasance as required under Mississippi law to pierce corporate veil.

Title: State ex rel. Petro v. Pure Tech Sys., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to pierce corporate veil of property development corporations and hold corporations' sole shareholder individually liable, in action brought by state against corporations alleging violations of hazardous waste and water pollution control laws, where corporations existed at the will of the shareholder, and in exercising control over them, shareholder was personally involved in their violations of environmental laws.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Hazardous Waste. Evidence was sufficient to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder personally liable for $6 million in penalties for violations of environmental laws.

Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Aberdeen Division.
Headnote: Reseller of Chinese engines did not have reasonable expectation of contractual performance from engine importer's sole employee, as required under Mississippi law to pierce corporate veil and hold employee individually liable as importer's alter ego in action to recover for civil penalties it paid for violation of Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) emission and labeling standards, where reseller did not contract with employee individually for performance, or require employee to guarantee performance of importer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Defendant's sole employee did not engage in fraud, precluding piercing of corporate veil on alter ego theory.

Title: New York State Elec. and Gas Corp. v. FirstEnergy Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold parent's successor liable for CERCLA response costs at subsidiary's facilities, even though subsidiary was not undercapitalized, where subsidiary was dominated and controlled by parents' owners, parent's owner freely transferred funds in and out of subsidiary and its subsidiaries, owners forced subsidiary to utilize management company they owned, which charged excessive fees, subsidiary's board meetings were held in parent's office, service contracts between service companies run by parent and subsidiary left subsidiary with no vestige of independent authority or control, no one represented subsidiary in contract negotiations with service companies, and parent loaned money to subsidiary and guaranteed debts by others to it. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold parent's successor liable for CERCLA response costs at subsidiary's sites.

Title: New York State Elec. and Gas Corp. v. FirstEnergy Corp.

Headnote: Landowners' were not entitled to subpoena former chief executive officer of oil refinery owner's parent company in action against owner for damages related to soil and groundwater contamination, where the parent company was not a party to the litigation, and landowners made no showing of any alter ego that would have allowed them to pursue the parent company.

Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not subject to liability under CERCLA for subsidiary's alleged releases of contaminants into groundwater, were parent did not take ownership of subsidiary until after releases had occurred, and no basis for piercing corporate veil had been pled. Title: U.S. v. Federal Resources Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, failing to pierce corporate entities' corporate veils to allow recovery against individual who controlled entities would promote injustice, in government's action seeking to recover costs incurred for environmental cleanup efforts at one entity's mining site pursuant to Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA), even though individual personally guaranteed judgment in government's favor up to $5.9 million; evidence demonstrated individual's propensity to use corporate form as a shield from liability, given his admission that entities shared a common bank account to frustrate attempts by certain banks to attach their assets. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Response action taken by government under CERCLA was consistent with national contingency plan.

Title: U.S. v. Conagra Grocery Products Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Maine.
Headnote: A "corporate parent," that is, a company that owns all of the stock of another corporation, is not subject to liability under CERCLA simply because its subsidiary owns or operates a polluting facility; however, a corporate parent may accrue CERCLA liability to the extent it actually operates its subsidiary's polluting facility, or to the extent a traditional corporate veil-piercing analysis applies. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Property owner was corporate successor to predecessor owner that was potentially responsible party under CERCLA.

Title: In re Appalachian Fuels, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be charged with derivative liability for its subsidiary's actions in operating a polluting facility in violation of environmental laws, but only when corporate veil may be pierced.

Title: Rochester Gas and Elec. Corp. v. GPU, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: District court's factual findings amply supported its conclusion, in imposing liability on parent corporation's corporate successor under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), that there was a "direct nexus" between parent corporation's domination of subsidiary and coal tar contamination at the subsidiary's facilities, where the district court found that coal tar was an inevitable byproduct of subsidiary's manufactured gas production, that leakage and soil contamination were "inherent" in the storage methods used at the relevant time, and that parent corporation so dominated subsidiary that the actions of subsidiary were the actions of the parent corporation during the period in question. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.

Title: Waste Management, Inc. v. Danis Industries Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: A corporation was not liable for the costs its subsidiary incurred in relation to the remediation of a landfill because the corporation did not exercise sufficient control over the subsidiary. The court did not find liability under a theory of piercing the corporate veil because the subsidiary received reasonably equivalent value for assets it received as a part of a recapitalization/split-off transaction. The corporation did not assume the debts of the subsidiary related to remediation of the landfill, the subsidiary was not a dissolved corporation that had nothing more than a paper existence, and no shareholders of the corporation requested to inspect the books of the subsidiary.

Title: McCarthy v. State Five Industrial Park, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut, Judicial District of Hartford.
Headnote: A closely-held corporation which operated as a commercial landlord was liable on a reverse veil piercing theory for a judgment against its former president for environmental contamination. The former president created the corporation and continued to control it after transferring ownership to corporation owned by wife and sons. The corporation assumed debt personally guarantied by the owners, was used to pay their personal expenses and make interest-free loans to family members, and paid the debts of other corporations. The control was utilized to further fraudulent practices in which owners used the corporation to pay property taxes of another corporation and to evade funding obligations of a prior judgment. The former president directly or indirectly so controlled the finances, policies, and practices of the corporation that an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting him and the corporation to escape liability for the obligations of the judgment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Closely-held corporation was liable on reverse veil piercing theory for judgment against its former president for environmental contamination.

Title: In re Alper Holdings USA, Inc.

Headnote: Alter ego claims that were asserted by personal injury and property damage claimants against Chapter 11 debtor, alleging that debtor, by virtue of its control over its subsidiary, or due to its purported looting of subsidiary, was liable for damages that claimants suffered due to allegedly negligently performed remediation of environmental contamination at subsidiary's facility, were "general" claims that could have been asserted by any creditor of subsidiary under Delaware law, and therefore claims were property of subsidiary's bankruptcy estate and were released pursuant to subsidiary's confirmed reorganization plan, given that debtor's actions in relation to subsidiary or remediation at its facility were not alleged to be specific to any claimant. 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a)(1).

Title: Maine v. Kerramerican, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maine.
Headnote: The mere fact that the parent and subsidiary share common directors is insufficient to impose CERCLA liability on the parent, since directors and officers holding positions with a parent and its subsidiary can and do "change hats" to represent the two corporations separately, despite their common ownership; thus, a general presumption exists that directors are wearing their "subsidiary hats" and not their "parent hats" when acting for the subsidiary and it cannot be enough to establish liability that dual officers and directors made policy decisions and supervised activities at a facility. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Fact issue existed as to whether parent's officers were acting for subsidiary in disposal of hazardous materials.

Title: Atlanta Gas Light Co. v. UGI Utilities, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: To impose liability upon a parent as an "operator" under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) with respect to a pollution-causing facility owned by a subsidiary, a plaintiff must prove that the parent as operator must have managed, directed, or conducted operations specifically related to pollution, that is, operations having to do with the leakage or disposal of hazardous waste, or decisions about compliance with environmental regulations. Title: Atlanta Gas Light Co. v. UGI Utilities, Inc.

Headnote: Corporate parent of subsidiary which owned a pollution-causing facility did not manage, direct or conduct operations of the facility specifically related to pollution, leakage, or disposal of hazardous waste, and therefore was not subject to liability for environmental clean-up costs under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) as an "operator," notwithstanding existence of overlapping officers and directors, and a management contract between the two entities. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 113(f)(1), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9613(f)(1).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Corporate parent of subsidiaries which owned pollution-causing facility were not liable for clean-up costs under CERCLA.

Title: State ex rel. Petro v. Mercomp, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Sole shareholder, who was also sole officer and director, had sole control over corporation as required in order to allow trial court to pierce the corporate veil and find shareholder individually liable for the corporation's violations of solid waste regulations in connection with the closure of landfill held by corporation, even if corporation was not under-capitalized or insolvent, or observed corporate formalities; shareholder was sole shareholder of every corporation associated with the landfill, and corporation was created solely to facilitate the closing of the landfill. R.C. § 3734.01 et seq.

Title: State ex rel. Petro v. Mercomp, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Sole shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a manner as to commit an illegal act, as required in order to allow trial court to pierce the corporate veil and find shareholder individually liable for the corporation's violations of solid waste regulations in connection with the closure of landfill held by corporation, despite shareholder's contention that mere regulatory violations would not allow court to pierce corporate veil; solid waste regulations allowed shareholder to be held individually liable. R.C. § 3734.01 et seq.

Title: State ex rel. Petro v. Mercomp, Inc.

R.C. § 3734.10.

Title: State ex rel. Petro v. Mercomp, Inc.

R.C. § 3734.01 et seq.

Title: City of Waukesha v. Viacom International Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: City, which alleged that corporate parent of subsidiary structured sale of subsidiary's assets so that asset-poor subsidiary would retain liability under environmental statutes for landfill, and parent would receive the value of subsidiary's assets but evade its obligation to pay for its share of liability at the landfill, alleged sufficient facts to state a claim under Wisconsin law for piercing the corporate veil, and holding parent liable for its subsidiary's environmental harm; city claimed that parent exercised complete control over subsidiary so that subsidiary had no separate mind, will or existence of its own and that parent used such control to commit an injustice.

Title: U.S. v. JG-24, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, It was appropriate to pierce corporate veil to hold corporation's president personally liable for response costs incurred in cleaning up hazardous waste site, where there were no stockholders, no payment of dividends, nonfunctioning officers and directors, failure to observe corporate formalities, absence of corporate records, and commingling of corporate funds through joint bank account with another company owned by president, and president hired workers, decided what products would be produced, supervised workers, and personally arranged for raw materials for fiberglass manufacturing operations. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Owner of fiberglass product manufacturer was personally liable under CERCLA for response costs.

Title: Consolidated Edison Co. of New York, Inc. v. UGI Utilities, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under CERCLA, derivative liability cases, which are based on piercing the corporate veil, are distinct from operator liability cases, in which parent's liability for environmental contamination at subsidiary's facility is direct. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.

Title: Consolidated Edison Co. of New York, Inc. v. UGI Utilities, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining parent company's operator liability under CERCLA for environmental contamination at subsidiary's facility, question is not whether parent operates subsidiary, but rather whether parent operates facility, and that operation is evidenced by participation in activities of facility, not subsidiary; parent's control of subsidiary, if extensive enough, gives rise to indirect liability under piercing doctrine, not direct liability as operator. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(2), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(2).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Gas company did not incur CERCLA liability as operator of subsidiary's manufactured gas plant sites.

Title: Consolidated Edison Co. of New York, Inc. v. UGI Utilities, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent company's direct liability as operator under CERCLA might arise, based on environmental contamination at subsidiary's facility, when a dual officer or director departs so far from the norms of parental influence exercised through dual officeholding as to serve the parent, even when ostensibly acting on behalf of the subsidiary in operating the facility. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(2), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(2).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Gas company did not incur CERCLA liability as operator of subsidiary's manufactured gas plant sites.

Title: Durham Mfg. Co. v. Merriam Mfg. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Liability of owner of corporate polluter under CERCLA for portion of response costs incurred in cleaning up hazardous waste site was premised on his capacity as owner of premises on which discharges took place, not on theory of piercing corporate veil or alter ego theory, even though he was polluter's president and sole shareholder, where there was no evidence that he exercised domination or control over corporation and that that control was cause of contamination, or that he was personally involved in use, handling, or disposal of hazardous substances. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 113(f), as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9613(f).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Corporation was not subject to successor liability under CERCLA.

Title: U.S. v. Jones
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Georgia, Macon Division.
Headnote: In order to hold individual derivatively liable under Oil Pollution Act (OPA) as owner of facility that is otherwise owned by corporation, court must look to corporate veil piercing considerations. Oil Pollution Act of 1990, § 1001(32)(B), 33 U.S.C.A. § 2701(32)(B).

Title: U.S. Public Interest Research Group v. Atlantic Salmon of Maine, LLC.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maine.
Headnote: There was complete lack of corporate independence from offshore salmon farm operator on part of its wholly-owned subsidiary, such that actions of subsidiary in purchasing and stocking salmonid smolt were, in reality, acts of operator acting for its own wrongful purpose to evade court order prohibiting it from introducing new class of fish into its net pens without permits required by Clean Water Act (CWA), and thus court would pierce corporate veil to hold operator in contempt; operator assumed complete dominance and control over all of subsidiary's affairs, subsidiary was completely dependent upon operator for smolt, operator was subsidiary's sole market for its harvested fish, operator consciously used subsidiary to evade court order in order to avoid $1.9 to 2.5 million loss, and operator's actions in stocking these smolt were clear effort to defeat CWA's and court's purposes. Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, § 101, as amended, 33 U.S.C.A. § 1251 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Contempt. Salmon farm operator's use of wholly-owned subsidiary to stock smolt warranted contempt sanctions.

Title: Pfohl Brothers Landfill Site Steering Committee v. Allied Waste Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, district court's power to pierce a corporation's veil so as to hold the parent corporation liable for the actions of its subordinates applies in CERCLA actions. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.

Title: Pfohl Brothers Landfill Site Steering Committee v. Allied Waste Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, parent did not so completely dominate subsidiary as to permit piercing of corporate veil, and thus successor-in-interest of parent could not be held liable for environmental cleanup costs; subsidiary was not undercapitalized in light of its purpose, and no evidence showed that parent exercised any control over subsidiary's daily operations, engaged in corporate siphoning, or that subsidiary had nonfunctioning officers or directors, although corporations failed to observe corporate formalities and separateness.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Rubber waste processer was liable for CERCLA cleanup contribution costs.

Title: U.S. v. Union Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Current owner of environmentally contaminated site was "alter ego" of its parent, so as to justify piercing corporate veil and holding parent derivatively liable, in CERCLA action, for response costs; control exercised by parent over owner was pervasive, and it would be fundamentally unfair to allow parent to deliberately circumvent liability for environmental contamination that it helped to create. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Past and current owners of contaminated site were responsible parties under CERCLA.

Title: Interfaith Community Organization v. Honeywell Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: A parent corporation cannot be held liable under CERCLA as an owner or operator for merely exercising control over a subsidiary unless the corporate veil is pierced. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Factors weighted against piercing veil to make parent corporation liable for CERCLA cleanup costs.

Title: Interfaith Community Organization v. Honeywell Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Factors did not weigh in favor of piercing corporate veil, to subject parent corporation to liability for CERCLA cleanup contribution costs of site allegedly owned and operated by subsidiary; although subsidiary was in bankruptcy proceedings, it was not necessarily undercapitalized, subsidiary maintained separate audited books and records and had separate board and officers, subsidiary's transactions paid by parent were debited as intercorporate debts which subsidiary was required to repay, and subsidiary was not mere shell of parent. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 113(f), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9613(f).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Factors weighted against piercing veil to make parent corporation liable for CERCLA cleanup costs.

Title: New York v. Solvent Chemical Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Since liability of corporate officer under CERCLA as "arranger" arising from his direct involvement in arrangements for disposal of hazardous substance is direct and not derivative, based solely upon person's status as corporate officer, there is no need to pierce corporate veil. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607.

Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Parent corporation was liable under CERCLA as operator of subsidiary's textile manufacturing facility, for costs of cleaning up trichloroethylene (TCE) contamination at facility, in light of parent's control over subsidiary's environmental affairs, as evidenced by involvement of parent's executive vice-president; thus, parent had no potentially meritorious defense to liability under CERCLA as would warrant relief from earlier declaratory judgment that imposed operator liability upon parent for future clean up costs under previously applicable standards. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a); Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 60(b)(5), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Parent corporation was liable as operator for contamination at subsidiary's facility.

Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: To impose direct operator liability under CERCLA upon the parent of a subsidiary whose site is contaminated requires an ultimate finding of the parent's involvement with operations having to do with the leakage or disposal of hazardous waste, or decisions about compliance with environmental regulations. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).

Title: Bestfoods v. Aerojet-General Corp.

Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable as an operator of facility of wholly owned subsidiary in the government's CERCLA cost recovery action, based on allegations that wholly owned subsidiary developed manufacturing process for cationic reagent for parent, parent funded expansion of facilities, and parent purchased the product from the subsidiary. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).

Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).

Title: Bestfoods v. Aerojet-General Corp.

Title: BP Amoco Chemical Co. v. Sun Oil Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Parent corporation can be liable as owner/operator under CERCLA when its subsidiary owned or operated CERCLA facility only if: (1) parent corporation itself managed, directed, or controlled operations of facility that were specifically related to pollution such as those concerning waste management or compliance with environmental regulations, or (2) corporate veil may be pierced between parent and subsidiary under traditional corporate law principles. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1990, § 113(f)(1), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9613(f)(1).

Title: BP Amoco Chemical Co. v. Sun Oil Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Unless corporate veil can be pierced, parent corporation that actively participated in, and exercised control over, general operations of subsidiary, without more, cannot be held liable under CERCLA as "operator" of polluting facility owned or operated by subsidiary. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1990, § 113(f)(1), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9613(f)(1).

Title: BP Amoco Chemical Co. v. Sun Oil Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Parent corporation's control of subsidiary was insufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil to impose direct operator liability on parent under CERCLA, even though parent's board of directors was aware of subsidiary's waste management activities at facility, and parent extended its welfare plan to cover subsidiary's employees directly, selected subsidiary's trade names, established joint laboratory facility, centralized subsidiary's administrative officers at plant, and guaranteed bank notes. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1990, § 113(f)(1), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9613(f)(1).

Title: U.S. v. Friedland
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, parent corporation did not control subsidiary to extent necessary to warrant piercing corporate veil, and thus parent could not be held liable under CERCLA for its subsidiary's actions in operating polluting facility, even though parent owned 67 percent of subsidiary's stock, parent and subsidiary shared two common directors and one common officer, parent loaned money to subsidiary, and parent paid salary of employee for his service on subsidiary's board, where parent was not involved in subsidiary's incorporation, nothing indicated that subsidiary was grossly undercapitalized, parent expected subsidiary to repay any expenses it paid on subsidiary's behalf, subsidiary did no business with parent, and subsidiary observed corporate formalities. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(2), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(2).

Title: U.S. v. Friedland
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Parent corporation's involvement in subsidiary's operation of mine was not sufficient to render parent liable under CERCLA as "operator" of mine, even though parent's president made decisions regarding mine, parent invoiced subsidiary for its services at mine, and creditors sent invoices relating to subsidiary to parent, where parent did not charge subsidiary management fee for performing functions relating to site, regulatory authorities charged with overseeing mine consistently acknowledged subsidiary as operator, decisions of parent's president regarding mine were typical of those one would expect of parent and largely unrelated to pollution control management or decisions, and subsidiary made all fundamental decisions concerning development of facility. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(2), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(2).

Title: U.S. v. Friedland
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Corporate parent that actively participated in, and exercised control over, operations of its subsidiary's facility may be held directly liable in its own right under CERCLA as operator of facility. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(2), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(2).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Parent could not be held liable under CERCLA for its subsidiary's actions in operating mine.

Title: U.S. v. Friedland
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not liable under CERCLA as "arranger" of disposal of hazardous waste produced at mine operated by its subsidiary, despite contention that parent's officers were involved in making operational decisions at mine, where parent's involvement in operation of mine was limited to isolated instances wherein parent sent subsidiary invoices for its services, and subsidiary made all fundamental decisions concerning development of facility before parent acquired subsidiary's stock. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(3), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(3).

Title: U.S. v. Ming Hong
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: To convict defendant for negligently violating pretreatment requirements of the Clean Water Act (CWA) "as a responsible corporate officer," the Government was not required to prove that defendant was a formally designated corporate officer of the company committing the violations; rather, the pertinent question was whether the defendant bore such a relationship to the corporation that it was appropriate to hold him criminally liable for failing to prevent the charged violations of the CWA. Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, §§ 309(c)(1)(A), (c)(6), 502(5), 33 U.S.C.A. §§ 1319(c)(1)(A), (c)(6), 1362(5).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Clean Water. Conviction for violating Clean Water Act as responsible corporate officer did not require formal designation as officer.

Title: State v. Della Villa
Court: Supreme Court, Schenectady County, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced to allow for liability to be imposed against individuals who owned and operated corporations running an illegal solid waste disposal facility, where these corporations held no meetings, issued no stock, paid no franchise taxes, filed no governmental reports, and shared employees and equipment.

Title: Booth Oil Site Administrative Group v. Safety-Kleen Corp.

Title: Kays v. Schregardus
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Portage County.
Headnote: Director of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) could pierce landowner's corporate veil and order sole shareholder and officer to remove scrap tires; the corporations were inactive and owned the land as their sole asset, and the shareholder had transferred the property to his shell corporations after the Attorney General had notified him that the dump was unlawful.

Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Test for determining whether parent corporation may be held directly liable under CERCLA as "operator" of a hazardous waste facility run by its subsidiary is not whether parent operates subsidiary, but rather whether it operates facility. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101(20), as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601(20).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Parent was operator under CERCLA due to amount of control over environmental operations.

Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Manufacturer's parent was subject to liability as "operator" under CERCLA for contamination at manufacturer's textile mill, where parent's pervasive general control encompassed specific control over environmental matters at mill including use of trichloroethylene (TCE) involved in contamination, and parent had made decision to settle earlier government environmental action against manufacturer. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101(20), as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601(20).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Parent was operator under CERCLA due to amount of control over environmental operations.

Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp., Inc.

Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp., Inc.

Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Although general control over a subsidiary is not by itself sufficient to make a parent corporation directly liable under CERCLA as "operator" of a facility run by its subsidiary, control of subsidiary, if extensive enough, gives rise to indirect liability under piercing doctrine. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101(20), as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601(20).

Title: Harris v. Oil Reclaiming Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Lessors of land containing oil reclaiming plant could not pierce the corporate veil, under Kansas law, so as to hold former vice-president for lessee's general partner individually liable under lease for cleanup of premises, given absence of evidence that general partner was grossly underfunded, that formal legal requirements of corporate entity were ignored, or that former vice-president used general partner to promote fraud, illegality, or injustice, and given evidence that former vice-president's loan to general partner was evidenced by note and that former vice-president took actions, in such capacity, that were typical of those in his position.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Oil and Gas. Alleged discharge of oil on grounds of Kansas oil processing plant was not within scope of Oil Pollution Act.

Title: Com. Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Cabinet v. Neace
Court: Supreme Court of Kentucky.
Headnote: Statute that imposes penalties on various corporate parties for a corporation's violation of statutes and regulations governing surface coal mining did not repeal common law, and thus, common law remedy of piercing the corporate veil is still available to Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Cabinet to seek to impose penalties against shareholders. KRS 350.990(9).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole director, officer, and shareholder could be held liable for coal mining company's regulatory violations.

Title: Schiavone v. Pearce
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not "operator" of subsidiary's creosote plant, and thus incurred no direct liability for CERCLA clean-up costs, despite overlapped and intertwined management structure, absent evidence parent acted in manner inconsistent with traditional and typical relationship between parent and subsidiary; parent did not manage, direct, or conduct operations specifically related to pollution at plant, or have anything to do with leakage or disposal of creosote, or with decisions about compliance with environmental regulations. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Parent of plant's former corporate owner was not directly liable as CERCLA operator.

Title: Schiavone v. Pearce
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, CERCLA defendant was not entitled to reimbursement from parent of former corporate owner of site absent showing that parent was directly liable under CERCLA as operator of site or indirectly liable under CERCLA or state law; showing of at least negligence was required in order for reimbursement statute to apply. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.; C.G.S.A. § 22a-452(a).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Parent of plant's former corporate owner was not directly liable as CERCLA operator.

Title: Browning-Ferris Industries of Illinois, Inc. v. Ter Maat
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, neither principal shareholder nor affiliate of corporation would be derivatively liable for corporation's share of liability for costs of cleaning up landfill site in CERCLA contribution action, under theory of piercing the corporate veil, absent significant failure to comply with corporate formalities or undercapitalization. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 113(f)(1), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9613(f)(1).
Document Preview: Companies responsible for some pollution at landfill site brought action against corporations and their principal shareholder for contribution under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA). Following bench trial, the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Philip G. Reinhard, J., 13 F.Supp.2d 756, allocated liability, and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Posner, Chief Judge, held that: (1) shareholder could be individually liable under CERCLA if he personally operated landfill; (2) liability could be imposed jointly against multiple defendants; (3) allocation of 40% of responsibility for cleanup costs to plaintiffs was not abuse of discretion; and (4) shareholder and affiliate would not be held derivatively liable for costs allocated to one defendant corporation under theory of piercing the corporate veil. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Title: Carter-Jones Lumber Co. v. Dixie Distributing Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Individual could be liable under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) as an arranger for disposal of hazardous waste due to his status as the sole shareholder of corporation involved in arrangement if state law would allow the piercing of the corporate veil, and he also was liable in his own right due to his intimate participation in the arrangement for disposal; he could not hide behind his officer or employee status to claim that because he took all actions on behalf of the company he could not be personally liable. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(3), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(3).
Document Preview: Landowner sued corporation and its sole shareholder under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) to recover costs expended in cleanup of hazardous waste. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, Edmund A. Sargus, Jr., J., imposed several liability on defendants as arrangers for disposal. Defendants appealed and landowner cross-appealed. The Court of Appeals, Siler, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court's determination that defendants intended to arrange for disposal of hazardous waste, so as to be liable for response costs under CERCLA, was not clearly erroneous; (2) third party defense was unavailable to defendants; (3) system of cost apportionment under CERCLA is not unconstitutionally vague; (4) individual defendant was properly held liable; and (5) liability of corporation and individual defendant did not have to be several as a matter of law. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Title: Bob's Beverage, Inc. v. ACME, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Chemical migration in soil or groundwater after corporation's articles had been canceled did not constitute corporate "act," in violation of Ohio law allowing cancelled corporation to perform only such acts as were required to wind up its affairs, and thus migration could not form basis for imposing liability on corporate shareholder in CERCLA contribution action. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, §§ 107(a), 113(f), 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 9607(a), 9613(f); Ohio R.C. §§ 1701.88(A), 1701.97.

Title: Love v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Evidence was legally and factually sufficient to support finding that former shareholders and directors manipulated corporate form to escape their statutory obligations concerning pollution and plugging of oil and gas wells, and that this was against public policy, thus making it necessary to pierce the corporate veil to hold them individually liable in order to prevent an injustice; although conflicting, evidence showed former shareholders and directors were well aware of violations on leases before they transferred only valuable lease to their other closely-held corporation and then allegedly sold stripped corporation with potentially large liabilities and very few assets to another party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporation Veil. Evidence supported finding of necessity to pierce the corporate veil to impose individual liability for penalties and well-plugging costs involving oil and gas leases.

Document Preview: The government sued a corporation and various of its officers and directors under the Comprehensive Environmental, Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), seeking to recover the costs of cleaning up a hazardous waste site. Title: Matter of Dougherty
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Commissioner of the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency was not required to "pierce corporate veil" before holding corporation's president personally liable for violations of Minnesota's hazardous waste laws under responsible corporate officer doctrine. M.S.A. § 116.072, subd. 1.
Document Preview: Corporation and its president sought review of administrative penalty order issued by the commissioner of the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency.  The Court of Appeals, Crippen, J., held that: (1) president could be held liable, under responsible corporate officer doctrine for corporation's hazardous waste violations; (2) pools of acid found on floor of corporation's metal galvanizing plant were not part of a continuing process excluded from definition of hazardous waste; and (3) Minnesota Pollution Control Agency was not required to issue formal written citation following administrative inspection of corporation's plant for inspection results to be considered a prior violation for purposes of imposing enhanced penalty. Affirmed.

Title: Com. of Mass. v. Blackstone Valley Elec. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under CERCLA, corporate veil need not be pierced to hold officers and directors of corporation personally liable for disposing of hazardous waste, but officer must have personally participated in conduct that violated CERCLA. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(3), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(3).
Document Preview: Massachusetts brought action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) and Massachusetts law to recover costs for cleanup of hazardous waste site. Motions allowed.

Court: Court of Common Pleas of Ohio, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Had it been necessary, corporate veil could have been pierced and individual officers and/or shareholders been held liable for corporation's violations of state or federal environmental laws on basis of undercapitalization of corporation; corporation was undercapitalized from its inception and relied solely on "purchase of stock" and/or loans made or guaranteed by officers to continue its existence, financial affairs were ineptly managed and ordinary accounting and bookkeeping abuses were so apparent that the parties themselves had been unable to confirm nature and amount of corporate expenditures over a course of many years, and ultimate control of corporation was at all times in hands of few officers and shareholders.

Title: John Boyd Co. v. Boston Gas Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Corporate form alone will not shield entities that exhibit significant indicia of responsibility from CERCLA liability. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).

Headnote: Corporate veil was not pierced to hold parent company liable for cost of cleanup of contaminated site of former wood treating and/or creosoting operation of its subsidiary; subsidiary faithfully adhered to basic corporate formalities by keeping its own books and records and holding frequent shareholder and directors meetings, and daily operations of parent and subsidiary were separate. Title: In re Acushnet River & New Bedford Harbor Proceedings Re Alleged PCB Pollution
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Foreign, parent corporation's involvement with wholly owned subsidiary that allegedly transcended pure investment relationship did not justify piercing of corporate veil in action by United States and Massachusetts under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, §§ 101–115, as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 9601–9615.
Document Preview: The United States and Massachusetts brought action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act, River and Harbor Act, Federal Clean Water Act, and Resource Conservation and Recovery Act to recover response and clean-up costs and other relief in connection with contamination of harbor and river by polychlorinated biphenyls.  Motions to dismiss and to obtain summary judgment were filed.  The District Court, Young, J., held that: (1) Act did not permit nationwide service of process; (2) foreign, parent corporation of defendant wholly owned subsidiary was not alter ego and could not be subjected to personal jurisdiction on veil piercing theory; and (3) previously dissolved corporation was properly revived and possessed capacity to be sued. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Attarian v. Sagard Capital Partners, L.P.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Section of Business Corporation Law (BCL) allowing employees to hold their corporate employer's ten largest shareholders liable for unpaid wages effectively pierces the corporate veil between employers and their shareholder and creates an exception to the rule that a corporation exists independently of its owners and that it is perfectly legal to incorporate for the express purpose of limiting the liability of the corporate owners. Title: Attarian v. Sagard Capital Partners, L.P.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Corporation's former employees failed to allege facts that would support, under Delaware law, piercing corporate veil to reach shell entity that owned vast majority of corporation's shares, which would have then allowed former employees to use section of Business Corporation Law (BCL) governing liability of shareholders for wages to reach corporation's beneficial shareholder, which owned the shell entity, to hold the beneficial shareholder liable for former employees' unpaid wages, and thus former employees failed to state claim against beneficial shareholder under BCL section; former employees did not allege that shell entity wielded influence over corporation to commit fraud or wrong, but instead alleged only that shell entity had no officers or employees and held no property. N.Y. Business Corporation Law § 630(a).

Title: United States v. Planes
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, chief executive officer (CEO) of management corporation, which entered a management contract to oversee and manage the operations of hospital, dominated and controlled every aspect of company that had owned properties on which hospital's facilities were located such that company lacked an existence independent from CEO, as would support subjecting company's assets to collection under an alter ego theory for CEO's failure to pay employment taxes for hospitals managed by corporation; although CEO's wife nominally owned company, she was unaware of her ownership and acknowledged that CEO controlled company, and CEO used company's bank accounts to shield his assets from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and pay the CEO and wife's personal expenses. 26 U.S.C.A. § 6672.
Document Preview: TAXATION  Employment. CEO was responsible for remitting hospital's employment tax withholdings, as required for claim for failure to pay employment taxes under the IRC.

Headnote: When assessing whether corporations constitute an "integrated enterprise," such that they can be held liable for employment discrimination as a single entity, pertinent factors include: (1) unity of ownership, management, and business functions, (2) whether entities present themselves as a single entity to third parties, (3) whether parent company indemnifies expenses or losses of its subsidiary, and (4) whether one entity does business exclusively with the other.

Title: Holder v. Fraser Shipyards, Inc.

Title: Partridge v. American Hospital Management Company, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Allegations that chief executive officer (CEO) maintained operational control over corporate employer and former employee, that CEO had power to approve the hiring of employee, that CEO had power to approve employee's rate and method of compensation, that CEO had the power to supervise employee's work, that CEO had control over all material aspects of employer's business, and that the CEO converted to his own use funds received from employer on account of the services employee performed for employer were sufficient to support piercing corporate veil in order to allow employee to assert claims directly against CEO, under District of Columbia law, in action seeking to recover wages allegedly due under employment agreements, and asserting claims for breach of contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee's allegations were sufficient to permit piercing corporate veil in order to assert breach of contract claims directly against CEO.

Title: Paguirigan v. Prompt Nursing Employment Agency LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Nurse, a citizen of the Philippines, who was recruited to work in nursing home in the United States by nursing home, staffing agency, and their employees, sufficiently alleged that employees exercised complete domination over staffing agency and nursing home, as required to state a plausible claim to pierce corporate veil and hold employees individually liable on her breach of contract claim under New York law; nurse was unlikely to have been privy to documents concerning various corporate practices and formalities, but complaint alleged intertwined relationships among agency, nursing home, and employees, alleging coordinated action to coerce nurse's continued performance of employment contract, which included a $25,000 termination fee.

Title: Turman v. Superior Court of Orange County
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Trial court applied improper test when determining that restaurant employer's sole shareholder and his other corporation were not employer's alter ego for purposes of former employees' wage claims; court did not consider whether there would be an inequitable result, but rather found that restaurant employees were required to "establish that failure to disregard the corporate entity would sanction a fraud or promote injustice," and that employer "was a real business with real purpose and assets and not a sham corporate entity formed for the purpose of committing a fraud or other misdeeds."
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Trial court employed improper tests when determining alter ego and joint employer issues.

Title: Thomas v. Khrawesh
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.

Title: Thomas v. Khrawesh

Title: Nicks v. Koch Meat Co., Inc.

Title: Board of Trustees of Employers–Shopmen's Local 516 Pension Trust Through Galton v. Columbia Wire & Iron Works, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: When considering whether to pierce the corporate veil and hold a corporation's shareholders liable for the corporation's withdrawal liability, courts consider three factors: the amount of respect given to the separate identity of the corporation by its shareholders, the degree of injustice visited on the litigants by recognition of the corporate entity, and the fraudulent intent of the incorporators. Title: Board of Trustees of Employers–Shopmen's Local 516 Pension Trust Through Galton v. Columbia Wire & Iron Works, Inc.

Title: Simmons v. LUBA Workers' Comp.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Sub-chapter S corporation that was owned by workers' compensation claimant and his wife functioned as a separate entity and not as claimant and wife's alter ego, and therefore their failure to disburse any of the corporation's earnings to themselves did not warrant crediting those earnings to claimant as income in calculating supplemental earnings benefits, where corporation repaid a loan that claimant and wife had made to it, corporation paid claimant and wife rent for a workshop and equipment, and CPA recommended that money be left in the corporation in order to fund new construction projects in the following year. La. Civ. Code Ann. art. 24.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Workers' Compensation. Claimant's sub-chapter S corporation was not an alter ego that would warrant a credit to insurer for undistributed income.

Title: Alta Mesa Holdings, L.P. v. Ives

Headnote: Parent company of company which acquired employer in merger was not liable for any breach of employment agreement executed between employer and executive employees, where merger agreement specified that acquiring company, rather than parent company, assumed the obligations of employer, and employees did not press any theory to pierce corporate veil or establish an agency relationship.

Title: Bridge v. New Holland Logansport, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: It was not appropriate to pierce the corporate veil under Indiana law, to provide a basis for aggregating employees of defendant corporate employer, which operated a farm-equipment store, with employees of another corporation with common ownership that operated a separate farm-equipment store, for purposes of 20–employee minimum for definition of covered "employer" under the ADEA; while there was a certain degree of integration between the two corporations with respect to board membership, particular employees' provision of human resources, accounting, or payroll services to both corporations, participation of employees in common group health-insurance plan, use of same address on tax returns, and sharing of website, each corporation had its own invoices and its own bank account, each filed its own tax returns, and corporations operated out of separate locations, maintained separate inventories, were managed individually, and were responsible for their own advertising. Title: Carpenters' District Council of Greater St. Louis and Vicinity v. F.G. Lancia Custom Woodworking, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Evidence demonstrated that successor company formed before close of business of employees' former employer was a continuation of former employer and was created in effort to evade former employer's ERISA obligations to its employees, and thus successor company was the alter ego of the former employer such that employees were entitled to a creditor's bill under Missouri law in order to satisfy a default ERISA judgment against former employer from the assets of successor company; temporal proximity of creation of successor and fact that companies shared same business purpose, management and supervision, operations, and employees supported conclusion that successor was established for reason of avoiding former employer's debt owed to employees. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 §§ 502, 515, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1132(a)(3)(ii), 1145.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Employees were entitled to creditor's bill to reach assets of former employer's alter ego in order to satisfy default ERISA judgment.
