Title: Carpenters' District Council of Greater St. Louis and Vicinity v. F.G. Lancia Custom Woodworking, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Company formed shortly before close of business of employees' former employer was alter ego of former employer, and thus employees were entitled to a creditor's bill under Missouri law, in order to satisfy a default ERISA judgment against former employer from the assets of its alter ego company; both companies were controlled by the same dominant figure who controlled day-to-day operations of both companies, companies shared common business purpose of manufacturing custom wood cabinetry and furniture, and both companies shared same core employees, same address, and common equipment, with only difference being a change of corporate name and shuffling of ownership. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 §§ 502, 515, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1132(a)(3)(ii), 1145; Labor Management Relations Act, 1947 § 301, 29 U.S.C.A. § 185(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Employees were entitled to creditor's bill to reach assets of former employer's alter ego in order to satisfy default ERISA judgment.

Title: Kenkel v. Parker
Court: Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Headnote: Shareholders of an insolvent and bankrupt company that did not have workers' compensation insurance cannot generally be held personally liable under the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil for the payment of the employee's workers' compensation award, absent evidence that the corporation was established to avoid workers' compensation claims. 18 Okl.St.Ann. § 1100.3.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Shareholders of bankrupt company that did not have workers' compensation insurance cannot generally be held personally liable for compensation awards.

Title: Johnson v. Serenity Transportation, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Allegation that owner dominated and controlled actions of corporation, that owner failed to adequately capitalize corporation, that owner failed to properly maintain minutes and corporate records, that owner maintained sole ownership of stock, that owner used his personal home as location for board meetings, and that owner failed to conduct board meetings as required by corporate by-laws and state law, alleged that there was unity of interest between owner and corporation, as required under California law to establish alter ego liability on part of owner in wage-and-hour action of corporation's workers.

Title: Dupuy v. N.L.R.B.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Even if termination of employer's 401(k) group retirement plan, or some other event, had freed up corporate funds which could be used by corporate employer to pay interest to terminated employee on unpaid backpay, pursuant to court of appeals' judgment enforcing National Labor Relations Board's (NLRB) order for remedial action with respect to unfair labor practice, that was no argument for piercing the corporate veil to make shareholder personally liable for paying interest, at least in the absence of any claim of improper dissipation. Title: Jarrett v. Dillard
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: After corporation, which had not carried workers' compensation insurance, was found liable to pay workers' compensation benefits in claimant's suit against corporation, doctrine of claim preclusion did not prevent claimant from bringing separate action against corporation's president individually to enforce judgment; due to president's involvement and control over prior litigation as president and majority shareholder, coupled with evidence that president was the alter ego of corporation, prior judgment was tantamount to a judgment against president personally. West's A.M.C. § 71–3–83(1).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Corporation's president was individually liable for workers' compensation benefits.

Title: Sebago v. Boston Cab Dispatch, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: There was no cause to analyze taxicab companies, which were corporations, as a single employer in action by licensed taxicab drivers against employers, alleging that they were misclassified as independent contractors, thereby depriving them of minimum wages, overtime pay, tips, and the protections afforded by the Wage Act, although there was common ownership among some of the companies, where allegations were limited to common ownership and control, which did not establish, as a matter of law, a partnership, agency, or joint venture relationship that rendered the companies a single employer. M.G.L.A. c. 149, § 148B(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Independent Contractors. Taxicab drivers did not provide services to cab companies, as required for independent contractor statute to apply.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Turley v. ISG Lackawanna, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In the employment-discrimination context, courts may look past the formal separation among corporate affiliates when extraordinary circumstances permit treating a parent and a subsidiary as a single employer for the purposes of applicable statutes.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Supervisor's egregious actions supported finding of intentional infliction of emotional distress (IIED) on employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Turley v. ISG Lackawanna, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: The inquiry into whether a parent company and subsidiary are a single employer for purposes of Title VII liability is conceptually distinct from other theories of corporate veil-piercing; a plaintiff need not demonstrate unlawful motive or any intent to use the corporate form to avoid contractual obligations, and the plaintiff need not demonstrate that the parent company exercises day-to-day control over labor relations. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Supervisor's egregious actions supported finding of intentional infliction of emotional distress (IIED) on employee.

Title: Trustees of Laborers Union Local No. 1298 of Nassau and Suffolk Counties Ben. Funds v. A to E, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To protect employee benefits under ERISA, courts observe a general federal policy of piercing the corporate veil when necessary. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Trustees of benefit funds sufficiently alleged nonsignatories to CBA were alter egos of employer.

Title: Farmer v. Town of Speedway, Ind.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil in an employment case allows the plaintiff to sue one entity even though an affiliated entity is her actual employer; in such a situation, the corporate veil is pierced only when corporate formalities are ignored and the actions of one company can accrue to another.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS - Municipal Liability. Deputy-clerk was an employee of the independently-elected clerk-treasurer and not a town, for purposes of anti-discrimination statutes.

Title: Pencheng Si v. Laogai Research Foundation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Although the word "employer," as used in False Claims Act's (FCA) retaliation provision does not normally apply to a supervisor in his individual capacity, there is an exception to this rule; an individual supervisor can be held liable as an employer when the supervisor can be considered to be an alter ego of the company, and therefore an employer under the familiar principle of piercing the corporate veil. 31 U.S.C.A. § 3730(h).
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Complaint sufficiently alleged protected activity under FCA.

Title: Kutty v. U.S. Dept. of Labor
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold medical clinic operator personally liable for back wages and penalties owed as result of clinic's deduction of expenses incurred by nonimmigrant physicians in obtaining visas, in violation of Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), where operator set up web of corporate entities, with help of his attorney, in order to hire nonimmigrant physicians, operator was sole owner and investor in those entities, he made all companies' major decisions regarding salaries and staffing from single office, he and his wife were only officers and directors, there was no evidence that corporations issued stock certificates or financial statements, operator treated corporations as extension of himself, corporations were undercapitalized, corporations were interchangeable and did not deal at arms length with each other, multiple entities were represented as employer of same physician, and physicians that were employed by one corporation were often paid by another. Immigration and Nationality Act, § 212(n)(1)(A), (n)(2)(C), 8 U.S.C.A. § 1182(n)(1)(A), (n)(2)(C).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold medical clinic operator personally liable for immigration violations.

Title: Ferrara v. Smithtown Trucking Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: ERISA was enacted to promote the interests of employees and their beneficiaries in employee benefit plans and to protect contractually defined benefits; thus, to protect employee benefits, courts observe a general federal policy of piercing the corporate veil when necessary. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Trustees of multiemployer plan could amend pleading to join defendants to hold them liable under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Ferrara v. Smithtown Trucking Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Test of alter ego status is flexible, and, although perhaps a germane or sufficient basis for imposing alter ego status, an anti-union animus or an intent to evade union obligations, such as those in a collective bargaining agreement (CBA), is not a necessary factor to impose alter ego liability; relatedly, parallel existence also is not an impediment to imposing alter ego status.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Trustees of multiemployer plan could amend pleading to join defendants to hold them liable under ERISA.

Title: Tianbo Huang v. iTV Media, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Employee sufficiently alleged that employer and its funding source were part of a facade constructed by chief executive officer (CEO) of employer's parent corporation to avoid their liability for employee's wages and other compensation, as required under English law to pierce the corporate veil so as to hold employer and funding source liable for CEO and parent corporation in employee's action arising out of his employment, where he alleged that CEO's contract with him was on behalf of parent corporation, yet at CEO's behest, funding source acted as funding conduit for parent corporation and employer, that CEO suggested that funding source would provide funds for employee's salary, that employer, a newly-established entity created for purpose of attracting employee to work for CEO and parent corporation, paid employee's initial salary, and that CEO subsequently misused employer by preventing employee's efficient management of it.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Nonresident defendants had sufficient minimum contacts with New York to support exercise of personal jurisdiction over them.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Tianbo Huang v. iTV Media, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Employee's allegations satisfied temporal requirement under English law for piercing the corporate veil so as to hold employer and funding source liable for employer's parent corporation and its chief executive officer (CEO) in employee's action arising out of his employment, although funding source appeared to have existed before employee allegedly joined parent corporation's group, where he alleged that, after incurring liability to employee for compensation, CEO deprived employer of funds to pay employee by keeping the money in funding source, and that CEO created employer to lure employee into parent corporation's group based on false promises, and then defraud him.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Nonresident defendants had sufficient minimum contacts with New York to support exercise of personal jurisdiction over them.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Tianbo Huang v. iTV Media, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Employee sufficiently alleged that chief executive officer (CEO) of employer's parent corporation actively managed multiple entities in order to gain benefit of employee's labor while shielding himself of liability for his compensation to warrant piercing the corporate veil of employer and its funding source, where he alleged that employer and funding source were directly involved in CEO's actions.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Nonresident defendants had sufficient minimum contacts with New York to support exercise of personal jurisdiction over them.

Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The mere fact that a corporation commits an unfair labor practice, or breaches a contract, or commits a tort, does not mean that the individual shareholders of the corporation should personally be liable. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as would support piercing corporate veil.

Title: Teamsters Local 639Employers, Health Trust v. Hileman
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Corporate owner-officer is not personally liable for ERISA withdrawal payments absent a showing that he acted as an "alter ego" of the company or in a fashion that would warrant piercing the corporate veil. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 § 4201, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1381(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Former director was not company or employer responsible for defunct corporation's ERISA debts under terms of plans.

Title: Lipsitt v. Plaud
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Worcester.
Headnote: Museum employee stated claims against museum founder individually for breach of contract and quantum meruit under the doctrine of corporate disregard, notwithstanding that the employment agreement at issue was between employee and corporate museum; allegations in complaint included that founder intended to pay employee's back salary once debts owed to founder were paid, that the museum had not filed any corporate tax returns, and that any salary employee did in fact receive was paid from founder's personal checking account and without any withholdings.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. The Wage Act does not preempt common-law claims for breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims in actions to recover unpaid wages.

Title: Patel v. Flexo Converters U.S.A., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under the alter ego exception to the exclusivity of workers' compensation law for intentional torts committed by supervisory employee who is the alter ego of the employer, the alter ego test is stringent, and supervisory employee alleged to have intentionally injured the plaintiff must be the employer's alter ego under the standards governing disregard of the corporate entity, a test corresponding to the requirements for piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Supervisor was not employer's alter ego for purposes of alter ego exception to exclusivity of workers' compensation law for intentional torts committed by supervisory employee who is alter ego of employer.

Title: Boland v. Thermal Specialties, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Alter-ego liability under the ERISA provision governing delinquent pension contributions prevents a parallel evasion, enabling ERISA trustees to recover delinquent contributions from a sham entity used to circumvent the participating employer's pension obligations. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 515, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1145.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Two companies were not alter egos such that one would be required to honor the other's ERISA contribution agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Boland v. Thermal Specialties, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In deciding whether two nominally distinct unincorporated businesses are alter egos for the purpose of assessing the ERISA provision governing delinquent pension contributions, the court evaluates the similarities between the two enterprises in their ownership, management, business purpose, operations, equipment, and customers, as well as any transactions or other dealings between the two entities; no single factor is controlling, and all need not be present to support a finding of alter ego status. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 515, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1145.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Two companies were not alter egos such that one would be required to honor the other's ERISA contribution agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Allred v. Exceptional Landscapes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Industrial Commission's findings of fact were insufficient to support legal conclusion that corporation's treasurer was alter ego of corporation, having complete dominion and control over its business practices such that corporation had no separate identity, so as to pierce corporate veil as to her and impose personal liability for workers' compensation claim, even though corporation was not adequately capitalized and did not follow corporate formalities.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Industrial Commission had jurisdiction over work-related injury claim against uninsured employer.

Title: National Integrated Group Pension Plan v. Dunhill Food Equipment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate employer's owner dominated corporation and used that domination to avoid its withdrawal liability to multiemployer pension plan, and thus piercing of corporate veil was warranted to find owner jointly and severally liable for corporation's withdrawal liability under ERISA, where corporation did not maintain any basic corporate formalities, owner regularly used corporate credit cards to charge personal expenses, and did not reimburse corporation for total amount of personal expenses he charged, owner failed to put sufficient money into corporation to satisfy its debts or regular expenses, owner was sole officer and director, and owner did not timely inform plan of corporation's withdrawal, and used corporate assets to pay his personal expenses after it had ceased operations. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 4201(a), 29 U.S.C.A. § 1381(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Employer's owner was jointly and severally liable for its withdrawal liability to multiemployer pension plan.

Title: Zoom Elec., Inc. v. International Broth. of Elec. Workers, Local 595
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Subcontractor's corporate veil could not be pierced for purposes of assessing contractor's imputed liability under California Labor Code; that would contravene clear California law that corporation was separate legal entity from its officers and did not gain license simply because officer was separately licensed. West's Ann.Cal.Labor Code § 2750.5.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Abstention. Colorado River abstention was not warranted in dispute involving subcontractor's noncompliance with project labor agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Dalton v. Manor Care of West Des Moines IA, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Iowa, Central Division.
Headnote: Even parent company may be found liable for its subsidiary's discriminatory action in some circumstances and may employ its subsidiary's employees if (a) parent company so dominates subsidiary's operations that the two are one entity and therefore one employer, or (b) parent company is linked to alleged discriminatory action because it controls individual employment decisions; however, there is strong presumption that parent company is not employer of its subsidiary's employees, and courts have found otherwise only in extraordinary circumstances.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Plaintiff's employee status was substantive element of federal disability discrimination claim, not jurisdictional prerequisite.

Title: Edmunds v. Delta Partners, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to support piercing of corporate veil and holding of company president personally liable to employee in employee's action against employer to recover for breach of employment contract after employer failed to pay employee who continued working for employer despite being told there that was no money to pay his salary; although employer had no separate existence from its president and president made assurances to employee that he would be paid his full compensation, president never stated that the obligation to pay employee was his own personally, president told employee that he would receive compensation when the company had the money to pay it, and there was no there was no evidence that president improperly distributed corporate assets to himself, failed to observe corporate formalities, or sought to defeat employee's claim.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient to support piercing of corporate veil and holding of company president personally liable to employee for unpaid wages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Ferrara v. Oakfield Leasing Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Individual is not liable for corporate ERISA obligations solely by virtue of his role as officer, but rather corporate principals are personally liable for corporation's ERISA obligations in special circumstances such as those in which court can properly pierce the corporate veil and conclude officer is corporation's alter ego; "special circumstances" include knowingly participating in fiduciary's breach of ERISA trust obligations, conspiring to divert ERISA funds for personal benefit, intermingling personal and corporate assets, engaging in fraudulent conduct, or where the individual is in fact corporation or corporation's alter ego. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Attorney Fees. Time sheets in ERISA action for delinquent contributions were sufficiently detailed, but rates charged were not all reasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Ferrara v. Oakfield Leasing Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil would be pierced to hold companies' owner and sole shareholder individually liable for their ERISA obligations to union trust funds, despite fact no wrongful conduct had been demonstrated; there was strong showing that he had no respect for separate identity of his corporation and to its formal administration and degree of injustice to plaintiff union trust funds that would result with recognition of corporate firm if he were permitted to hide behind shield of his corporation. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 502(a)(3), (g)(2), 515, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1132(a)(3), (g)(2), 1145.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Attorney Fees. Time sheets in ERISA action for delinquent contributions were sufficiently detailed, but rates charged were not all reasonable.

Title: Board of Trustees of Auto. Mechanics' Local No. 701 Union and Industry Pension Fund v. Moroni
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Board of trustees for labor union and industry pension fund, as judgment creditor for withdrawal liability owed to fund by insolvent employer, as judgment debtor, that stopped contributing to ERISA fund, adequately pleaded claim under theory of alter ego liability against employer's former officer who created new corporation and sole proprietorship allegedly to divert employer's assets without first satisfying contribution obligations; board alleged insolvency, commingling of assets, diversion of assets to shareholder to detriment of creditors, failure to maintain arms' length relationship among related entities by diversion of assets, new entities serving as mere facades for officer, failure to respect formalities of separate entities, establishment of new entities to permit employer to escape its contractual and financial obligations to fund, and that recognizing new corporate entity would result in injustice and fraud by deprivation of ERISA payments. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. ERISA single employer liability claim was sufficiently alleged by board of trustees for ERISA pension fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Tryco Enterprises, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Former employer and its successor-in-interest were alter egos of its owners and were part of single business enterprise, as grounds for disregarding corporate form and piercing corporate veil in order to enforce prior judgment entered against employer for violations of Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA); employer's owners forfeited employer's corporate charter just after verdict was returned in employee's favor and before judgment was entered, all of employer's assets and personnel were transferred to employer's successor in order to avoid payment of judgment, owners owned both entities and exercised absolute ownership and control over both entities, successor had same offices as employer at same location, it performed same services for essentially same clients, and it was managed by same personnel. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were alter egos of owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil to enforce judgment against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Tryco Enterprises, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were used as means of perpetrating an actual fraud on employer's former employee primarily for direct personal benefit of employer's and successor's owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil and holding owners jointly and severally liable on prior judgment entered against employer for violations of Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA); successor was organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of employer's business, owners forfeited employer's corporate charter just before judgment was entered on jury verdict in employee's favor in FLSA suit, created successor, and transferred employer's assets to successor as means of evading employer's legal obligation to pay judgment, corporate fiction was used to circumvent consequences to owners of employer's violation of FLSA by transferring employer's assets that were subject to employee's judgment lien to successor, which left employer without assets to pay judgment, and corporate fiction was thereby relied upon owners to justify wrong. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were alter egos of owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil to enforce judgment against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Shearrow v. Easton Enterprises, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Failing to pierce the corporate veil of an employer's corporate affiliates would not sanction a fraud or promote injustice, and thus, the affiliates were not proper defendants in a former employee's Title VII action alleging sexual harassment and retaliation; despite allegedly misleading statements on a web site, there was no evidence that any creditor of the employer was ever actually confused as to the company it was dealing with and as a result went unpaid, and despite purported improper business practices, there was no evidence that any creditor of the employer had gone unpaid while another entity was unjustly enriched and enjoyed a surplus of funds. Civil Rights Act of 1964, §§ 703(a), 704(a), 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 2000e–2(a), 2000e–3(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employer's corporate affiliates were not proper defendants in a former employee's Title VII action.

Title: Gaddy v. Universal Cable Systems, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of cable television service provider's contractor was not permissible remedy on wage claims brought by workers hired by contractor's subcontractor to perform audits of households to determine whether unauthorized cable television service hookups were in service and to sell such services, absent any evidence to support workers' claims that contractor and subcontractor operated as single business entity, such that workers could be considered to be employees of contractor, within meaning of wage statute. LSA–R.S. 23:631.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Trial court's refusal to award penalty wages due to unreasonable delay in resolving pay dispute was manifest error.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Chin-McKenzie v. Continuum Health Partners
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, a corporate entity is liable for the employment-related acts of a separate, related entity only under extraordinary circumstances; the law only treats the employees of a corporate entity as the employees of a related entity under extraordinary circumstances.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. There was no evidence of reasonable accommodation which would have allowed employee to perform essential job functions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Chin-McKenzie v. Continuum Health Partners
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There is an exception to the rule that a corporate entity is generally only liable for the employment-related acts of a separate, related entity only under extraordinary circumstance, known as the single employer doctrine; it applies where there are sufficient indicia of an interrelationship between the immediate corporate employer and the affiliated corporation to justify the belief on the part of an aggrieved employee that the affiliated corporation is jointly responsible for the acts of the immediate employer.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. There was no evidence of reasonable accommodation which would have allowed employee to perform essential job functions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Flores v. Bodden
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, seaman seeking to hold corporate owner-president liable on alter ego theory for default judgment entered against corporation, which owned vessel and employed seaman, was not required to prove that owner-president exercised complete control over day-to-day operation of vessel on which seaman was injured and that control was used to commit fraud or wrong causing seaman to be injured, but only to prove that there was such unity between corporation and owner-president that separateness of corporation had ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported finding owner-president to be alter ego of corporation and liable for default judgment for seaman injured on shrimping trawler.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Mehl v. PortaCo, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: There was no evidence of any fraudulent activity by employer's president and majority owner, such as undercapitalization or commingling of funds, as required to pierce the corporate veil under Minnesota law to hold president individually liable in former employee's claims under Title VII and the Minnesota Human Rights Act (MHRA). Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.; M.S.A. § 363A.01 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether employee was treated differently than others because of her sex.

Title: Guifu Li v. A Perfect Day Franchise, Inc
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Under California law, there was no unity of interest and ownership between branch manager and massage corporation such that manager was alter ego of corporation in certified class action by massage therapists alleging violations of California wage and hour laws; manager was not owner, director, or corporate officer of corporation.

Title: U.S. E.E.O.C. v. Global Horizons, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Hawai'i.
Headnote: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission's (EEOC) allegations that parent corporation represented to public that it, rather than its subsidiary, had purchased employer, that parent created subsidiary in order to avoid potential Title VII liability in connection with acquisition of employer's assets, and that parent exercised substantial control over employer were sufficient to raise reasonable inference that circumstances warranted piercing corporate veil in EEOC's Title VII discrimination action. Title: Payne v. Local Lodge 698
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: An alter ego will be found only in cases involving a mere technical change in the structure or identity of the employing entity, frequently to avoid the effect of the labor laws.

Title: Medical Arts Office Services, Inc. v. Erber
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In employer's action to declare that employee had been properly terminated for cause, employee stated counterclaim for piercing the corporate veil of employer by alleging that company was dominated by owner, acting individually and through additional entities, and that such domination was used to commit a wrong or injustice against employee such that a court in equity might intervene.

Title: Oliver v. Black Knight Asset Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, once corporate liability has been established under ERISA, officers may be held personally liable for their corporations' obligations if they have acted as the alter egos of their corporations or otherwise met requirements that justify piercing the corporate veil under traditional common law principles. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 3(5), 29 U.S.C.A. § 1002(5).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Terminated employee stated ERISA claim against her employer.

Title: International Painters and Allied Trades Industry Pension Fund v. Davanc Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Companies were alter egos of employer that failed to make required contributions to union pension funds, and thus companies were jointly and severally liable with employer for unpaid contributions; companies and employer had substantially identical officers and management, shared same employees and equipment, served same or similar type of customer, and shared awareness of employer's obligations to funds. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Judgment. Entry of default judgment against employer was warranted in ERISA action seeking recovery of unpaid contributions.

Title: International Painters and Allied Trades Industry Pension Fund v. Davanc Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In the ERISA context, alter ego liability enables ERISA trustees to recover delinquent contributions from a sham entity used to circumvent the participating employer's pension obligations. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Judgment. Entry of default judgment against employer was warranted in ERISA action seeking recovery of unpaid contributions.

Title: International Painters and Allied Trades Industry Pension Fund v. Davanc Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In order to determine whether businesses are alter egos for purposes of ERISA, courts evaluates the similarities between the enterprises in ownership, management, business purpose, operations, equipment, and customers. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Judgment. Entry of default judgment against employer was warranted in ERISA action seeking recovery of unpaid contributions.

Title: Leek v. Cooper
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: A determination that a person is the alter ego of a corporate employer does not make the alter ego an employer under the California Fair Employment and Housing Act (FEHA); rather it makes the alter ego liable for the obligations of the corporation. West's Ann.Cal.Gov.Code § 12940.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer's Liability. Corporation's sole shareholder was not employees' employer for purposes of FEHA discrimination claims.

Title: Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico v. Holt Marine Terminal, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To establish a corporate veil piercing claim so as to subject employer's owner to employer's withdrawal liability under Multiemployer Pension Plan Amendments Act (MPPAA), plaintiffs must show that the corporate forms of employer and employer's owner were abused and should be disregarded. Multiemployer Pension Plan Amendments Act of 1980, § 402(a), 29 U.S.C.A. § 1301(b).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Summary judgment was precluded on employer's corporate affiliate's liability for employer's MPPAA withdrawal liability.

Title: Bonham v. Wolf Creek Academy
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Asheville Division.
Headnote: Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) requires no "veil piercing" to attach liability to individuals behind a corporate employer, as individuals may under certain circumstances be subjected to liability for unpaid wages under FLSA. Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, § 3, 29 U.S.C.A. § 203.
Document Preview: TORTS - Conversion. Internal Revenue Code provision barring suit prior to filing claim for refund barred employees' state claim for conversion.

Title: Thorkelson v. Publishing House of Evangelical Lutheran Church in America
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, company that published religious materials, which sponsored and administered defined benefit pension plan, was alter ego of church, thus subjecting church to liability as to breach of contract, promissory estoppel, and Minnesota Consumer Fraud Act (MCFA) claims brought by plan participants and beneficiaries arising from termination of plan; company's first board consisted of three pastors, company's articles of incorporation provided that company was organized and operated exclusively for religious purposes and to assist church in carrying out its purposes, delegates of church's convention elected company's board, articles provided that in event of company's dissolution, any surplus property went to church, and company's chief executive officer (CEO) frequently described company and church as partners, which implied that company and church would stand together and look after each other and their employees.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Single employer defined benefit pension plan was church plan exempt from Employee Retirement Income Security Act.

Title: Baraliu v. Vinya Capital, L.P.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Employee presented only evidence that employer's owner, in his capacity as employer's chief investment officer, donated some of employer's computers and furniture to various charities in India, which, standing alone, was insufficient under New York law to warrant piercing of corporate veil to bring breach of employment contract claims against owner as individual.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Nooralmodification clause controlled under New York's statute of frauds, and so oral promises were not binding on employer.

Title: Retirement Plan of UNITE HERE Nat. Retirement Fund v. Kombassan Holding A.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To protect employee benefits, courts observe a general federal policy of piercing the corporate veil when necessary.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Corporation was alter ego of related entities and thus was subject to withdrawal liability under ERISA.

Title: A & B Bolt & Supply, Inc. v. Dawes
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Former employee's business was not liable for employee's alleged breach of a non-compete agreement with former employer, absent any allegation by former employer that business, which did not exist at the time non-compete agreement was entered into, was the alter-ego of employee organized for the purposes of circumventing his non-compete agreement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee's business was not liable for employee's alleged breach of non-compete agreement, absent any allegation business was alter-ego of employee organized for purposes of circumventing agreement.

Title: Wellman v. DuPont Dow Elastomers, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Parent and subsidiary corporations' operations were not interrelated, and therefore, parent was not liable for alleged discrimination in female former employee's Title VII action against subsidiary, where corporations did not share common management, ownership or financial controls, employee could not apply to certain positions within parent because she was considered a non-parent employee, and parent was not consulted or informed about employee's termination. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employee was not terminated in retaliation for filing internal charge of sexual harassment.

Title: PACE Industry Union-Management Pension Fund v. Dannex Mfg. Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Company solely owned by employer's majority shareholder was "alter ego" of employer, for purpose of multi-employer employee pension fund's action against that company and employer to recover delinquent contributions owed to fund, under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) and the Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA); company and employer were controlled by same individual, shareholder admitted that all the labor and equipment necessary for any sales that company made were provided by employer, employer sold company's equipment as if it were employer's own, and tax returns were inconsistent with businesses operating independently of one another. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 502, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1132; Labor Management Relations Act, 1947, § 301, 29 U.S.C.A. § 185.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Company solely owned by employer's majority shareholder was alter ego of employer.

Title: Dollman v. Mast Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There was no obvious need to pierce corporate veil and subject holding company and subsidiary of holding company which originally hired employee to liability in employment discrimination action brought by employee against employer for whom she worked when she was terminated, which was also subsidiary of holding company, holding company, and subsidiary which originally hired her; gravamen of employee's case concerned only her employment with most recent employer and employee's tax returns indicated that most recent employer, and not any other defendant, was her employer.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Fact issue precluded summary judgment as to wrongful termination claim under Pregnancy Discrimination Act.

Title: Kellett v. Wofford Bros. Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Union was able to pierce the corporate veil to obtain a judgment against corporation formed by owners of a prior corporation. Union had obtained a judgment against the prior corporation for delinquent contributions, liquidated damages, interest, attorneys' fees, and costs owed. The prior corporation went out of business and the owners formed a new corporation. The new corporation performed the same type of services, provided services to customers of the prior corporation, used tools from the prior corporation without paying for them, maintained the same address and bank as the prior corporation, and the employees of the new corporation were employees of the prior corporation. Due to the multitude of similarities between the corporations, the new corporation was properly found to be the mere alter ego of the prior corporation. Therefore, union could collect from the new corporation on the judgment obtained against the prior corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Union was able to pierce the corporate veil to obtain a judgment against corporation formed by owners of a prior corporation.

Title: Melamed v. Girardi
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Employee's allegations that employer corporation was undercapitalized were insufficient to pierce the corporate veil and subject sole shareholder to liability in employee's suit for breach of employment contract. Although corporation was losing money, it paid nearly three million dollars in salaries in one year, demonstrating that it was a significant undertaking. Furthermore, shareholder made multiple loans to corporation to ensure its success, contradicting employee's assertion that shareholder set up corporation as a sham in order to channel assets into his own account.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee's allegations that employer corporation was undercapitalized were insufficient to pierce the corporate veil.

Title: PharMethod, Inc. v. Caserta
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, whether former employer had a right to enforce non-competition agreement that former employee had entered into with a separate legal entity depended upon the relationship between those separate corporations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Injunction. District court failed to set forth sufficient findings of fact when issuing preliminary injunction.

Title: Jeansonne v. Schmolke
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced to hold sole owner, officer, and shareholder of general contractor personally liable to its former employee in action seeking unpaid wages, given the lack of any corporate formalities, use of corporate bank account by sole owner for personal use, shifting of costs for work done on owner's personal home onto other jobs of corporation, and apparent termination of employee because she had ended romantic relationship with owner.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. General contractor's former project manager was employee who could seek unpaid wages and not an independent contractor.

Title: Navarro-Rosario v. Fuxa-Catalan
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Employee's allegation that employer misused the corporate form in order to provide a liability shield for shareholders was insufficient to compel the court to pierce the corporate veil and impose personal liability on shareholders in employee's Title VII claim for sex discrimination. Although employee alleged that employer was suffering financial difficulties and created a sister company to remedy the situation, rendering the latter a mere shell for the former, this did not implicate the ethics of the corporation-shareholder relationship. 29 U.S.C.A. § 2000e.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employee's allegation that employer misused the corporate form was insufficient to impose personal liability on shareholders in employee's Title VII claim for sex discrimination.

Title: Finkel v. Triple A Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: An officer may be held personally liable for ERISA obligations of the corporation in cases involving fraud or facts warranting piercing the corporate veil; in addition, a corporate officer may be held individually liable if there is clear and explicit evidence of the parties' intent that he be personally bound. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Corporate officer was jointly and severally liable with employer for delinquent contributions that became due under CBA.

Title: Williamson v. Adventist Health System/Sunbelt, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate parent of hospital subsidiaries did not exercise sufficient control over subsidiaries so as to impute liability to parent under Title VII and § 1981 for subsidiaries' purported discriminatory actions against temporary licensed practical nurse, as subsidiaries operated as independent decision-makers in personnel matters. 42 U.S.C.A. § 1981; Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 703, 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e–2.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Temporary staffing agency for nurses did not discriminate on basis of race either directly or through cat's paw theory.

Title: Larco, Inc. v. Strebeck
Court: Court of Appeals of Arkansas.
Headnote: Evidence showing that the corporations were operated by the same person and employed the same people was not sufficient grounds to disregard the separate legal existence of the corporate entities, and therefore, trial court clearly erred in finding that the corporations were jointly and severally liable for the commissions owed to employee, who worked for both corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court clearly erred in finding that corporations were jointly and severally liable for commissions owed to employee.

Title: Carpenters Dist. Council of Kansas City Pension Fund v. JNL Const. Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation was so controlled by its sole owner and her ex-husband, who was a former shareholder, that it had independence in form only, as element of test for determining whether allowing employee benefit funds to pierce corporate veil to reach owner and husband was warranted in action under ERISA alleging that corporation failed to pay contributions as required by collective bargaining agreements; owner and husband shared space with corporation and paid for the space, owner acquired corporation's stock for no value, corporation obtained loan to build residence and then husband took out personal mortgages on it and received the net loan proceeds, and he paid corporation's $100,00 tax debt. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 502, 515, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1132, 1145.

Title: Carpenters Dist. Council of Kansas City Pension Fund v. JNL Const. Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Company to which corporation in the construction business purportedly sold its tools was so controlled by the corporation that the two entities were independent in form only, as element of test for determining whether allowing employee benefit funds to pierce the corporate veil to reach the company was warranted in their action under ERISA alleging that the corporation failed to pay contributions as required by collective bargaining agreements, since corporation was the company's sole customer, company never paid for the tools, and corporation did not thereafter pay the company for the purported rental of the tools. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 502, 515, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1132, 1145.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on issue of whether to allow piercing corporate veil in action under ERISA.

Title: MacDonald v. Summit Orthopedics, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Retired employee's allegations that former employees and officers of corporate employer siphoned funds from employer, exacerbated employer's insolvency, and engaged in self dealing were sufficient to plead factual basis to pierce corporate veil under Minnesota law, as required for employee's action to hold defendants personally liable for recovery of ERISA plan benefits. Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Corporate officers cannot be held personally liable for recovery of ERISA benefits if there is no basis for piercing the corporate veil. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 502(a)(1)(B), 29 U.S.C.A. § 1132(a)(1)(B).

Title: Trustees of the Auto. Mechanics' Industry Welfare and Pension Funds Local 701 v. Elmhurst Lincoln Mercury
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Trustees of welfare and pension funds stated claim under Illinois law for piercing corporate veils of automobile dealership and leasing company in order to hold the individual defendants personally liable for corporations' debts, on allegations that individual defendants "diverted money from the operation of the business of [dealership] and put it into defendant [company], where they used the money for their own person expenses" and they "further failed to observe corporate formalities by engaging in this siphoning off of money from [dealership] and further used money so siphoned to pay for personal items such as Season's Cubs Tickets." Title: Painters Dist. Council No. 2 v. McCoy Drywall, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Employee benefit plans, which received consent judgment against a company that failed to make contributions to the plans, were entitled to pierce the company's corporate veil and collect from the company's alter egos. The company, and its alter ego, were formed and run by a husband and wife who performed every duty and made every decision for the two companies. Moreover, the company's attorney admitted that the separate company was formed because the initial company was going broke. Where the husband and wife exercised control over both companies' finances, policies, and business practices, the companies were separate entities in form only.

Title: LaChance v. Unemployment Compensation Bd. of Review
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Unemployment Compensation Board appropriately pierced corporate veil in finding that claimant possessed control of marital business in manner as to render him self-employed and thus ineligible for unemployment compensation benefits; although claimant had transferred ownership of business into his wife's name, at no point in his testimony did claimant indicate that he took direction from his wife when acting in his capacity as an "employee" of the marital business. 43 P.S. § 802(h).

Title: Osgood v. Midwest Parking Solutions
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Parking service employees alleged facts sufficient to state a claim for relief under a state law "piercing the corporate veil" theory against an individual employer upon which relief could be granted to survive dismissal. The employees alleged that the individual had control and complete dominance of the employer corporation's policies and business practices, such that the corporation had no virtual existence of its own. Furthermore, employees alleged that the individual co-mingled personal and corporate assets and that the corporation was under-capitalized.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parking service employees alleged facts sufficient to state claim for relief under state law piercing the corporate veil theory against individual employer to survive dismissal.

Title: Robles v. Copstat Sec., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a putative class composed of former security guards of a corporation stated a claim against sole shareholder of the corporation under the New York Minimum Wage Act. Title: Esposito v. Altria Group, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Employee of wholly-owned subsidiary of foreign corporation failed to demonstrate that corporation exercised control over or made any employment decision related to her, and thus corporation could not be held liable for her employer's alleged unlawful conduct toward her under Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), New York State Human Rights Law (NYSHRL), or New York City Human Rights Law (NYCHRL). Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, § 2 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 12101 et seq.; McKinney's Executive Law § 292(21); New York City Administrative Code, § 8-102(16).

Title: Stuto v. Kerber
Court: Supreme Court, Albany County, New York.
Headnote: Statute imposing personal liability upon 10 largest shareholders of closely held corporation for unpaid wages due to employees operates, in effect, to pierce the corporate veil and impose personal liability against corporate shareholders for the debts of their corporation. McKinney's Business Corporation Law § 630.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Statute making shareholders of closely held corporation liable for unpaid wages applies only to domestic corporations.

Title: Trustees of Chicago Painters v. Destiny Decorators, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil in an ERISA case was proper. There was such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and the individual that separate personalities no longer existed and continued separation would sanction fraud. The corporation failed to keep accurate records and the individual had commingled his personal funds with those of the corporation and had used a personal account to compensate workers. Compensating workers from the personal account allowed the individual to avoid making contributions to employees' pension and benefit funds, which constituted a fraudulent wrong. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 502(g)(2), 515, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1132(g)(2), 1145.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporations. Piercing the corporate veil in ERISA case was proper.

Title: Carpenters' Dist. Council of Greater St. Louis and Vicinity v. F.G. Lancia Custom Woodworking, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Former employees were entitled to a creditor's bill in order to satisfy a default ERISA judgment against former employer from the assets of its alter ego company. Both companies were controlled by the same person, the alter ego company was formed shortly before primary company, stopped doing business, and the primary company breached its duty to its former employees by failing to pay judgment. Both companies were in the same business, used the same tools, were located at the same address, and had the same bank account. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Former employees were entitled to a creditor's bill in order to satisfy default ERISA judgment against former employer from the assets of its alter ego company.

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Property developer that controlled purse strings, if not operations, of newly formed successor to parent unionized subcontractor, partly to avoid union dues and pension benefit obligations of parent and successor, was dominating personality directing successor at developer's whim, as required to pierce corporate veil of successor to recover unpaid obligations from developer, under Illinois law, since developer was successor's de facto principal as successor never operated separately and independently from developer, but rather, was restricted from entering any material transactions with third parties without developer's consent, and successor was undercapitalized corporation propped up by loans from parent or shareholders due to lack of any equity capital and failure to meet debts.

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.

Headnote: Residential housing contractor that was involved in scheme of transactions that formed successor to parent unionized subcontractor, partly to avoid pension benefit and union dues obligations of parent and successor, was subject to piercing of corporate veil of successor to reach contractor in order to recover unpaid obligations, under Illinois law, since contractor was integral part of transactional scheme that stripped parent of assets, leaving nothing but tax and union liabilities, contractor also extended credit to financially struggling parent as would suggest lack of arm's length relationship with parent and thus successor, and contractor lacked corporate formality by twice making payments to trust instead of successor for parent's prior work.

Title: Harris v. Kupersmith
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut, Judicial District of Stamford-Norwalk.
Headnote: A former employee hired to assist a corporation in the construction of a golf course alleged sufficient facts to pierce the corporate veil and hold a corporate officer personally liable for certain tortious conduct. The employee alleged that on multiple occasions the officer made promises to pay the employee but then deferred compensation allegedly owed, and ultimately failed to pay the employee. The employee also specifically alleged that the officer promised to pay the employee, blaming the delay on a second employee. General Statutes § 34-133.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A former employee hired to assist a corporation in the construction of a golf course alleged sufficient facts to pierce the corporate veil and hold a corporate officer personally liable for certain tortious conduct.

Title: Pineda v. Lopito, Ileana & Howie, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Parent was not alter ego of employer, precluding parent's liability on former employee's claim, under Puerto Rico law, for unjust dismissal; even though parent and employer had same board of directors, common stock holders, one same system of accounting, and shared human resources department, parent did not control employer, finances of parent and employer were separate, employer did not lack corporate integrity and was not mere shell employed by parent as artifice or for illegal purposes, and fact that employee had dual functions as general manager of parent and as producer for employer's creative department for specified period of time did not justify piercing corporate veil. 29 L.P.R.A. § 185 (Repealed).

Title: Local 513, Intern. Union of Operating Engineers, AFL-CIO v. Sunrise Const., Inc.

Headnote: Under Missouri law, limited liability company (LLC), operations manager of LLC, and LLC's owner were alter egos of corporation and thus, under doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, were liable, jointly and severally, for balance of money judgment that ERISA plans obtained against corporation for failure to make fringe benefits contributions. Title: Williamson v. Adventist Health System/Sunbelt, Inc.

Title: Malcolm v. Franklin Drywall, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: A company's sole shareholder could not be held personally liable for a judgment in favor of several union fringe benefit funds, and against the company, for delinquent fringe benefit contributions and liquated damages. Title: Long v. Aronov Realty Management, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Even assuming that "single employer" theory applied to liability for non-employment claims, real estate brokerage firm's parent corporation was not vicariously liable under civil rights statutes for commercial real estate broker's conduct in connection with shopping center transaction; while parent and subsidiary had overlapping officers, shared office space, and used the same human resources division and third-party payroll company, brokerage company paid for using both, broker's compensation came from brokerage firm which was qualifying company on her real estate license, broker was walled off from employment benefits her former employer offered, and her job description changed when she transferred employers, thereby freeing her to work with properties outside parent corporation's portfolio. 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 1981, 1982.

Title: Roberts v. Shaw Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: The evidence was insufficient to pierce the corporate veil and hold a parent corporation liable to a former employee of its subsidiary for the alleged harassment of its subsidiary's employees. The former employee brought charges of employment discrimination after facing sexual harassment and retaliation for reporting such harassment at work. Although the parent corporation paid the former employee's paychecks, there was no evidence that the parent corporation exercised any control over the operation of its subsidiary corporation. Moreover, there was no evidence that the parent and subsidiary operated as a single entity since there was no evidence that the parent hired or fired any of the subsidiary's employees or routinely shifted employees between the two entities. 42 U.S.C. § 2000e.

Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Sunrise Const., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Several employee benefit plans, trustees and fiduciaries, and several unions were entitled to a creditor's bill in order to satisfy its judgment against a construction company from the assets of the company's alter egos. The underlying suit was to collect delinquent contributions and other damages that were owed to the benefit plans pursuant to collective bargaining agreements under the terms of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. The construction company failed to make the required payments. The benefit plans and unions showed, as required, that the construction company had a positive legal duty to make the contributions, that the company's owners abandoned the company and started a new company to avoid paying its debt, the breach of duty caused injury to the plaintiffs, and the judgment had been rendered uncollectible from the company. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 502, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1132.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Several employee benefit plans, its trustees and fiduciaries, and several unions were entitled to a creditor's bill.

Title: N.L.R.B. v. Bolivar-Tees, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced to impose shareholder liability for violation of NLRA when (1) there was such unity of interest and lack of respect given to the separate identity of the corporation by its shareholders that the personalities and assets of the corporation and the individual are indistinct, and (2) adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations. Title: N.L.R.B. v. Bolivar-Tees, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether shareholders and corporation have failed to maintain their separate identities, as required to pierce corporate veil to attach liability to a shareholder under NLRA, court may consider following non-exhaustive list of factors: (1) whether the corporation is operated as a separate entity; (2) the commingling of funds and other assets; (3) the failure to maintain adequate corporate records; (4) the nature of the corporation's ownership and control; (5) the availability and use of corporate assets, the absence of same, or under capitalization; (6) the use of the corporate form as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit of an individual or another corporation; (7) disregard of corporate legal formalities and the failure to maintain an arm's-length relationship among related entities; (8) diversion of the corporate funds or assets to noncorporate purposes; and (9) transfer or disposal of corporate assets without fair consideration. National Labor Relations Act, § 1 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 151 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unfair Labor Practices. Corporate veil could be pierced to enforce back pay order against controlling shareholder.

Title: Trustees of the Graphic Communications Intern. Union Upper Midwest Local 1M Health and Welfare Plan v. Bjorkedal
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, piercing of printing company's corporate veil was not warranted to reach shareholder, so as to make shareholder liable for printing company's contractual obligations under collective bargaining agreement entered by printing company; shareholder did not treat printing company as an extension of himself, but rather treated it as separate and distinct from his personal interests, printing company was the result of consolidating three corporate entities that had been in business for nearly 40 years, and shareholder did not siphon off funds, but rather made large cash infusions to try to save corporation long after the chief financial officer (CFO) thought it wise to do so.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Rental partnership was not alter ego of printing company, as to make it liable for company's contractual obligations.

Title: Plasticsource Workers Committee v. Coburn
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Individual defendant could be held vicariously liable for violations of WARN Act under alter ego theory of liability. Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, §§ 2(a)(1), 3(a), 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 2101(a)(1), 2102(a).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Sanctions. Willful violation of order for deposition, coupled with prior discovery conduct, warranted sanctions.

Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under the LMRA, one business entity is the alter ego of another, and thus liable for its obligations, if the two are substantially identical in terms of ownership, management, supervision, business purpose, operations, customers, equipment, facilities and employees; not all of the outlined factors need be identical. Labor-Management Relations Act, 1947, § 301(a), 29 U.S.C.A. § 185(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. LLC and corporation were alter egos of judgment debtor.
