Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under ERISA, one business entity is the alter ego of another if the two exist independently in form only, and those separate forms are used as a subterfuge to defraud, to justify a wrong or to mislead or discourage pursuit of legal action. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 502(a)(3)(ii), 515, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1132(a)(3)(ii), 1145.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. LLC and corporation were alter egos of judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, limited liability company (LLC) and corporation were alter egos of judgment debtor, so as to entitle employee benefit plans, trustees of those plans, and several unions, to creditor's bill in equity against LLC and corporation; companies had a common ownership, management and supervision, and LLC and corporation were incorporated for the purpose of either paying debts or generating additional business opportunities for judgment debtor.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. LLC and corporation were alter egos of judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Maddock v. KB Homes, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California, Western Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not "alter ego" of its subsidiary, as would allow piercing of corporate veil, in order to establish parent corporation's liability for subsidiary's employee's claims for overtime compensation, failure to provide meal and rest breaks, and other alleged violations of the FLSA and California labor laws; parent corporation did not control subsidiary's internal affairs or daily operations, and although the two entities had common directors and ownership, there was no unity of interest, and there was no showing that any fraud, injustice, or other inequity would result if corporate veil was not pierced, as parent corporation's policies did not cause employee's claimed losses. Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, § 3(d), 29 U.S.C.A. § 203(d); 29 C.F.R. § 791.2(a); West's Ann.Cal.Labor Code §§ 226.7, 1194.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Parent corporation was not joint employer of subsidiary's employee, as required to establish its liability under FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Avila-Blum v. Casa de Cambio Delgado, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To establish alter ego liability under Title VII, it is necessary to show that the individual defendant exercised such complete dominion and control that the corporation lacked independent will and that this control was used to commit fraud or wrong against the plaintiffs. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 706(e), 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e-5(e).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Leaves. Genuine issues of material fact precluded summary judgment for employer on employee's claim of interference of FMLA rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Operating Engineers Pension Trust v. Petelski
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Trustees of pension fund were not entitled to collect pension fund contributions under ERISA from employer's spouse's business, under an alter ego theory of liability, absent showing that spouse's business was created in an attempt to avoid the pension obligation's of employer, or that employer was operated with anti-union animus. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Pension fund could not collect contributions owed by one employer under ERISA from employer's spouse's business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Milan v. Centennial Communications Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, employer and affiliated corporation were not a single employer, for purposes of determining whether affiliated corporation was required under Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act to provide employee notice of his lay-off, where affiliated corporation did not have a degree of control over employer that rendered employer a mere shell for affiliated corporation. Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, § 2(b)(1), 29 U.S.C.A. § 2101(b)(1).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Employees who signed separation agreements knowingly and voluntarily waived all claims against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: In re First Financial Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Indiana, Hammond Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, allegedly fraudulent acts of corporation's principal, five days prior to his death by suicide, in causing corporation to transfer company-owned policy on his life from corporation to principal, so that principal could change beneficiary from corporation alone to his fiancee as main beneficiary, were not such as to permit piercing of corporate veil to hold fiancee personally liable for corporate debts; under Indiana law, veil piercing claim is asserted, not to avoid transfer, but when corporation's separate form has so far been ignored, controlled or manipulated that person or persons should become liable for corporate debts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee could recover death benefit lost as result of changes involving life insurance purchased by debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Lamb v. Vision Care Holdings, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: There are three ways in which corporation affiliated with employer may be found to be proper defendant in employment discrimination case: (1) if plaintiff presents evidence that affiliate itself maintained employment relationship with plaintiff, (2) if plaintiff can show that affiliate forfeited its limited liability with regard to employer, or (3) if plaintiff presents evidence that successor liability applies.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employer was not entitled to summary judgment on discrimination claims by terminated older female regional manager.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Lamb v. Vision Care Holdings, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: Affiliated business entity can forfeit its limited liability in discrimination context when it takes actions for express purpose of avoiding liability under discrimination law or where affiliate corporation might have directed the discriminatory act, practice, or policy of which employee is complaining.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employer was not entitled to summary judgment on discrimination claims by terminated older female regional manager.

Title: Hegre v. Alberto-Culver USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Augusta Division.
Headnote: To determine whether entities are an integrated enterprise, such that employee may sue multiple entities as a single employer under federal anti-discrimination laws, the following criteria must be considered: (1) interrelation of operations, (2) centralized control of labor relations, (3) common management, and (4) common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Store manager could not reasonably be regarded as disabled by bipolar disorder and hypertension.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Hegre v. Alberto-Culver USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Augusta Division.
Headnote: Parent and other subsidiaries did not have such interrelated operations that they could all be regarded as store manager's employer for purposes of suit under § 1981 and ADA, despite some evidence of common ownership or financial control, where other entities did not play role in day-to-day management of employer or its personnel decisions, aside from use of same employee handbook and common employee profit-sharing plan, and, with one exception, did not share common board members, officers, or employees. 42 U.S.C.A. § 1981; Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, § 2 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 12101 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Store manager could not reasonably be regarded as disabled by bipolar disorder and hypertension.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Hegre v. Alberto-Culver USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Augusta Division.
Headnote: Mere existence of common management and ownership are not sufficient to justify treating a parent corporation and its subsidiary as a single employer for purposes of federal anti-discrimination laws.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Store manager could not reasonably be regarded as disabled by bipolar disorder and hypertension.

Title: Novak v. Scarborough Alliance Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, former employee could not pierce corporate veil to hold corporations' president and chief executive officer personally liable for alleged breach of employment contract, even if he exercised absolute dominion over corporations, and had made decision to terminate employee without cause, where there was no allegation that president used corporations to accomplish his own and not corporations' business, contract was between employee and corporation, president signed contract on corporation's behalf, and there was no evidence that corporations were incapable of satisfying potential judgment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Former employee could not pierce corporate veil to hold corporations' president and CEO personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Pyramid Printing Co. v. Alaska State Com'n for Human Rights
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Order of State Commission for Human Rights, in proceeding on employee's sexual harassment case, that employer/corporation's owners undergo sexual harassment training, was within the Commission's broad remedial powers and not a piercing of the corporate veil; owners also were involved in employer's management and had the power to dictate the terms and conditions of employment. AS 18.80.130; Alaska Admin.Code tit. 6, § 30.480(b).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Evidence established employee subjected to sexual harassment acted reasonably by refusing to accept offer of re-employment.

Title: Corrigan v. U.S. Steel Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Former nonunion steel industry employees, who brought action seeking increased retirement benefits and damages for age discrimination against parent corporations of their employer, a general partnership formed by wholly owned subsidiaries of the parent corporations, failed to show that their employer and the parent corporations were "fundamentally indistinguishable," as required to pierce the corporate veil under Ohio law; although the parent corporations were parties to the employer's formation agreement and a subsequent restructuring agreement, and although the partnership subsidiaries were formed within one month of employer's formation, employees failed to present evidence demonstrating that these were not isolated incidents of control, or that parent corporations had direct control of employer's day-to-day operations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Steel industry employees could not pierce corporate veil on claims for age discrimination and increased retirement benefits.

Title: Williams v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not liable for its subsidiary's allegedly discriminatory discharge of its employee, even though subsidiary shared human resources employees with parent, where subsidiary exercised complete control over employment process, and parent's employees did not participate in any way in decision-making process leading to employee's discharge.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent corporation was not liable for its subsidiary's allegedly discriminatory discharge of its employee.

Title: Pottschmidt v. Klosterman
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: In seeking to pierce corporate veil of original and new corporations, original corporation's former employee satisfied element regarding fraud in disregard of corporate entity; sole shareholder of both corporations formed new corporation one month after former employee sued original corporation, shareholder formed new corporation to avoid potential liability related to former employee, and neither new corporation nor shareholder paid any consideration for original corporation's assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter-ego doctrine was satisfied for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Title: Pottschmidt v. Klosterman
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: For purposes of seeking to pierce corporate veils of original and new corporations, original corporation's former employee satisfied element concerning loss or injury resulting from shareholder's exercise of control over corporations; shareholder's transfer of all of original corporation's assets to new corporation, without adequate consideration being paid, left original corporation simply empty shell and made it impossible for former employee to collect judgment rendered in his favor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter-ego doctrine was satisfied for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Title: Central States, Southeast, Southwest Areas Pension Fund v. George W. Burnett, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: The "alter ego doctrine" is similar to the single employer doctrine, but it also requires a finding that the second corporation is a disguised continuance of the employing enterprise, resulting in evasion of the employer's obligation under the labor laws.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Union pension fund was entitled to summary judgment on issue of liability in ERISA suit for delinquent contributions.

Title: Trustees of Southern Cal Pipe Trades Health and Welfare Trust Fund v. Temecula Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Whether employer's principal was personally liable for alleged breaches of fiduciary duty under ERISA turned not on whether employer's corporate veil could be pierced, but instead on whether principal himself exercised any discretionary authority regarding the management or disposition of unpaid contributions that constituted plan assets. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 3(21)(A), 29 U.S.C.A. § 1002(21)(A); 29 C.F.R. § 2509.75-8.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Monies owed by employer to employee benefit funds for unpaid employer contributions were ERISA plan assets.

Title: Caskey v. Colgate-Palmolive Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: Pet food manufacturer's parent company could be found to be proper defendant in Title VII action by terminated manufacturer's employee if complainant (1) could present evidence that parent maintained an employment relationship with her, (2) could pierce corporate veil and present evidence that subsidiary was only alter ego of parent, or (3) could present evidence that parent took actions to avoid liability under discrimination laws or might have directed discriminatory act, practice, or policy of which she complained. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701(b), 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e(b).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Leaves. Parent company was not statutorily liable, as it was not worker's employer and did not direct or control relevant decisions.

Title: Mitchell v. TAM Equities, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Employer's parent corporation was not putatively liable for employer's alleged discrimination against employee, absent evidence that parent corporation exercised dominion and control over daily operations of employer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent corporation was not putatively liable for employer's alleged discrimination against employee.

Title: Dearth v. Collins
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine did not permit individual capacity liability to be imposed under Title VII against employer's president, director, and sole shareholder. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Relief under Title VII was not available against employer's sole shareholder/president.

Title: Dearth v. Collins
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to hold sole shareholder/president liable for employer's sexual harassment was not warranted under Georgia law since there was no showing that shareholder/president disregarded employer's corporate form, that he used employer to transact his own affairs or commingled employer's funds with his own funds, or that he was hiding behind employer's corporate form in order to protect his own fraudulent behavior.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Relief under Title VII was not available against employer's sole shareholder/president.

Title: Ford v. Carylon Corp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not liable for its subsidiary's alleged retaliatory discharge and intentional trespass to subsidiary's employee for filing workers' compensation claim for work-related injury, given that parent did not use subsidiary as its alter ego. Code 1975, § 25-5-11.1.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Co-worker's failure to install safety valve from third-party supplier was not willful conduct subjecting him to liability.

Title: Mayes v. Moore
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: When a shareholder has used the corporate form fraudulently or wrongly, that individual, even if not technically a Title VII employer, can be a proper Title VII defendant. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701, 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.

Title: Mayes v. Moore
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Allegations by former employee, who was chief financial officer (CFO) of corporation and its subsidiaries, that shareholder owned controlling interest in corporate employer and its subsidiaries, that shareholder made sexual advances toward employee, and then discharged employee when he responded negatively to such advances, were insufficient to pierce the corporate veil, as required to state claim against shareholder for violation of Title VII, absent allegations that shareholder fraudulently or unfairly used the corporate form. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701, 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil, as required to state claim against shareholder under Title VII.

Title: Platten v. HG Bermuda Exempted Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Director's actions on behalf of corporate parent and its subsidiaries did not warrant piercing of corporate veil under Massachusetts law, and thus liability could not be imposed upon on third and fourth tier subsidiaries for corporate parent's alleged failure to pay employees full amount of their termination distributions, where employees contracted with parent, they were not confused about identity of legal entity with which they were contracting, and there was no gross inequity that was required for overriding presumption of corporate separateness.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Motion Practice. District court did not abuse its discretion by denying plaintiffs leave to file supplemental affidavit.

Headnote: Factors in determining whether company is alter ego of another company, in context of federal labor dispute, are whether enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership.

Title: Yolton v. El Paso Tennessee Pipeline Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: "Relaxed" alter ego doctrine applied, in retirees' LMRA and ERISA action against employer's successor seeking paid retirement health benefits based on predecessor's having signed collective bargaining agreements (CBAs) that incorporated those benefits, even though there was no evidence of successor's intent to evade labor obligations. Labor-Management Relations Act, 1947, § 1 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 141 et seq.; Employee Retirement Income Security Act, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.

Title: Yolton v. El Paso Tennessee Pipeline Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Employer's successor, created when parent company reorganized and spun off employer, was alter ego of employer, and thus retained employer's labor law obligations undertaken via collective bargaining agreements (CBAs); successor continued to operate same business that employer had under same management, at same locations, with same equipment and same supervision, producing same products with same employees, and working under same CBAs.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Successor Employer. Employer's successor that retained same business and management was alter ego of employer, liable to same extent under CBAs.

Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Seneca County.

Headnote: Illinois courts reviewing alter ego allegations under both Illinois common law and in the context of Federal Employers' Liability Act (FELA) claims resolve the issue based on whether the entities have failed to maintain formal corporate distinctions, or whether recognition of the entities as distinct would allow them some unfair advantage. Title: Manos v. Geissler
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Female former employee who sued former employer, supervisor and parent corporation, alleging discrimination under federal and state law due to her pregnancy and subsequent termination, would not be allowed to pierce corporate veil as to direct claims against supervisor; employee provided no allegations establishing that supervisor was alter ego of employer, nor did she present any evidence that supervisor used his control over employer to commit fraud or any other wrongful act.

Title: Pantusco v. Wiley
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Shareholder who was sued by former corporate employees for unpaid wages could not assert corporation's claims against employees as counterclaim in employees' action, even though employees alleged that shareholder was corporation's alter ego so as to hold him personally liable for their wages; doctrine of piercing the corporate veil was equitable concept, based on abuse of the corporate form, and shareholder could not take advantage of his alleged abuse to assert corporation's claims.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder who was alleged to be corporation's alter ego could not thereby assert corporation's claims.

Title: Tlacoapa v. Carregal
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.

Title: Midwest Precision Heating and Cooling, Inc. v. N.L.R.B.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: In determining whether two business entities are alter egos, the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) and the courts consider a variety of factors, including whether the two entities have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership; they also consider whether a motive for the new entity's taking over of the operations of the old entity was to evade responsibilities under the NLRA and whether dealings between the two entities were at arm's length. National Labor Relations Act, § 1 et seq., as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 151 et seq.

Title: Nedzvekas v. LTV Copperweld

Headnote: There are three situations in which the court will consider affiliated entities as a single employer: (1) where the conditions for piercing the corporate veil are present; (2) small entities are created for the sole purpose of avoiding liability; or (3) where the affiliate directs the discriminatory act, practice, or policy.

Title: Shuck v. Wichita Hockey, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Terminated employees of sports franchise were not entitled to pierce corporate veils of franchise and league, both owned by same individual, in order to hold owner liable for alleged violations of Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) allegedly committed by franchise and league; owner was not employees' employer, league rather than owner was designated administrator of group health insurance plan in question, and owner was not alter ego of franchise or league since there was no evidence that either entity had failed to maintain its distinct personality or that maintenance of their corporate personalities would work injustice to employees. Title: Lenoble v. Best Temps, Inc.

Title: Trustees of Resilient Floor Decorators Ins. Fund v. A & M Installations, Inc.

Headnote: Non-union employer was not alter ego of union carpet installer, which was formed to satisfy customers who preferred union workers, and thus employer was not required to make contributions to ERISA pension funds pursuant to installer's collective bargaining agreement (CBA) with union, since there had been no change in structure or operations of installer, installer did not have intent to evade its preexisting obligations, and union received full benefit of its CBA. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 515, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1145.

Title: Trustees of Resilient Floor Decorators Ins. Fund v. A & M Installations, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: In labor cases, an intent to evade preexisting obligations is the focus of the alter ego doctrine; in the absence of some indication that the relationship between the companies has changed over the years or has caused the union to receive less than that for which it bargained under a collective bargaining agreement (CBA), there is no inequity that would justify a court's imposition of liability on a non-union company.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Non-union employer was not alter ego of union carpet installer.

Title: Trustees of Resilient Floor Decorators Ins. Fund v. A & M Installations, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Non-union employer and union carpet installer did not pervasively intermingle their funds and operations, which would have been necessary for companies to be considered alter egos of one another, for purpose of claim to collect employee fringe benefit contributions under ERISA, although union installer was created shortly after principal of non-union employer met with union representatives and discussed possibility of employer becoming union company, and then employer loaned $5,000 to installer shortly after it was formed so that installer could post security bond with union to fulfill condition of its collective bargaining agreement (CBA). Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 515, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1145.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Non-union employer was not alter ego of union carpet installer.

Title: Escobedo v. BHM Health Associates, Inc.

Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to impose liability on defunct health-care corporation's shareholders for employees' unpaid wages was not warranted, although corporation made overpayment of payroll tax arrearage before sale of corporation instead of paying wages, and although shareholders had personally guaranteed payment of that arrearage; tax arrearage was corporate debt, and personal guaranty did not change debt from corporate to individual one. West's A.I.C. 22-2-5-2, 23-1-26-3(b).

Title: Schlussler-Womack v. Chickasaw Technology Products Inc.

Headnote: Purported parent corporation was not employer's alter ego, even though entities had same office address 18 months before former employee filed ERISA action and filing in another action indicated, based on "available information, knowledge and beliefat the present time," that employer was a division of purported parent, management of two companies were separate, they maintained separate payrolls, accounting systems, financial accounts, minute books, and corporate records, they conducted separa te meetings of their boards of directors, and purported parent was not trustee or administrator of employee stock option plan at issue. Title: Denenberg v. Mahler
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: After employee, pursuant to settlement, withdrew with prejudice her Title VII discrimination claim against corporate employer, she could not maintain Title VII discrimination claim against employer's former president, under alter ego theory; imposition of alter ego liability on president was not necessary to prevent fraud or injustice or to achieve an equitable result, in light of employee's bargained-for dismissal of claim against corporate employer. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.

Title: Flynn v. Ohio Bldg. Restoration, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Alter ego relationship existed between employer that was party to collective bargaining agreement (CBA) and corporation, for purposes of determining corporation's liability for employer's contributions to multiemployer pension fund under ERISA and CBA, inasmuch as common ownership of corporation lay with employer's owner, even though corporate ownership was officially registered to his wife, entities shared management personnel who performed same duties for each, entities provided same type of construction services and operated simultaneously in same general geographic area, 25 employees had worked for both entities, entities had offices in same location and engaged in lease and loan arrangements with one another without written documentation, and both entities used same service providers in operation of their businesses. Headnote: Inequitable result that would otherwise follow, if corporate veil was not pierced to hold controlling shareholder personally liable for corporation's ERISA liability resulting from its failure to contribute to labor union pension fund as required by collective bargaining agreement (CBA), weighed in favor of piercing the corporate veil; corporation had ceased operations and no longer existed, and corporation was determined to owe the fund for delinquent contributions. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder was personally liable for corporation's ERISA liability upon corporate veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Minnesota Laborers Health and Welfare Fund v. Scanlan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Shareholder of closely-held corporation, which owed delinquent contributions to union pension funds, was not alter ego of corporation, so as to support holding shareholder liable for unpaid contributions under ERISA; corporation was not sham corporation, and identities of shareholder and corporation were distinct. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 515, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1145.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Owner of unincorporated business was personally liable for unpaid contributions to ERISA funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Matheson v. Virgin Islands Community Bank, Corp.
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Contract, tort and ERISA claims may be leveled against corporate shareholder or officer if it can be shown that shareholder or officer is doing business in his or her individual capacity without regard to corporate formality,that is, if it is appropriate to "pierce the corporate veil." Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Virgin Islands bank officer's wrongful discharge cause of action accrued before statutory amendment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Smith v. Grand Canyon Expeditions Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: Employer's election of the "S" corporate form was entirely lawful and, standing alone, was irrelevant to an alter ego inquiry, and thus, individual shareholders were not subject to liability in former employee's breach of contract and breach of implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing actions against employer.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Damages. Employee was not entitled to punitive damages in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. Evans
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported National Labor Relations Board's conclusion that partnership was corporation's alter ego, for purposes of NLRA, where partnership was started with interest-free loan from corporation, partnership frequently used corporation's telephone and equipment at no cost, both were based from same location for substantial portion of period at issue, both worked on many of same projects for same employers, there was significant intermingling of assets and little respect for formalities, and corporation's principal directly assisted in management and supervision of partnership in various capacities. National Labor Relations Act, § 8, 29 U.S.C.A. § 158.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unfair Labor Practices. Partnership was corporation's alter ego for purposes of NLRA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Flynn v. Greg Anthony Construction Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Pension funds suing corporate employer under ERISA for failure to make fund contributions, failed to make out prima facie case for piercing corporate veil and imposing alter ego liability on nonsignatory individuals; though one individual was officer of employer, neither had ownership interest in employer, and allegation that individuals' related companies had failed to follow corporate formalities were conclusory. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 515, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1145.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Union pension funds made out prima facie claim for companies' alter ego liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Flynn v. Greg Anthony Construction Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Union pension funds suing corporate employer under ERISA for failure to make fund contributions, made out prima facie case for piercing corporate veil and imposing alter ego liability on two related companies; companies and employer shared same management and operated similar businesses from same location, and union would be unable to recover full amount due unless corporate fiction was dismantled.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Union pension funds made out prima facie claim for companies' alter ego liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Kaplan v. Aspen Knolls Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Chief Operating Officer (COO) of real estate development and sales corporation could not pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability on principal for unpaid bonuses, despite claims that principal used personal checks to pay COO, that assets of corporation and principal were "routinely intermingled," and that corporate form was ignored, absent allegation that principal used control of corporation to COO's detriment; simply put, COO had not alleged that breach of contract furthered principal's interests rather than those of corporation or that breach was related to any misuse of corporate form.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. COO stated breach of contract claim under New York law against real estate development corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Roofers Local 149 Security Trust Fund v. Duane Smelser Roofing Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In the labor law context, alter ego doctrine prevents employers from evading their statutory obligations by merely changing or altering their corporate form.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on multiemployer benefit funds' contribution claim under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Roofers Local 149 Security Trust Fund v. Duane Smelser Roofing Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is applied in labor law context, when appropriate, to treat two nominally separate business entities as if they were a single continuous employer.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on multiemployer benefit funds' contribution claim under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Massachusetts Carpenters Cent. Collection Agency v. A.A. Bldg. Erectors, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Nonunion employer was not alter egos of its union subsidiary, which was formed to satisfy customers who preferred union workers, and thus employer was not required to make contributions to ERISA pension funds, pursuant to subsidiary's agreements with union; common ownership, method of operation and customer base of employer and subsidiary did not provide equitable basis for regarding subsidiary's agreements to make contributions as implying corresponding agreements by employer, particularly as subsidiary never deceived union about its relationship to employer, and no change in its relationship had caused union to receive less than it bargained. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Employer and its union subsidiary were not alter egos for purposes of pension fund contributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Massachusetts Carpenters Cent. Collection Agency v. A.A. Bldg. Erectors, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Although alter ego doctrine usually applies in situations involving successor companies where successor is merely disguised continuance of old employer, doctrine also has sufficient play in its joints to cover instances where company uses parallel entity to avoid a labor law obligation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Employer and its union subsidiary were not alter egos for purposes of pension fund contributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Massachusetts Carpenters Cent. Collection Agency v. A.A. Bldg. Erectors, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is not formalistic mechanism for reflexively regarding distinct jural entities as legally interchangeable whenever the entities' relationship is marked by sufficient number of doctrine's characteristic criteria, e.g., continuity of ownership between corporations, management overlap, similarity of business purpose, evidence that non-union entity was created to avoid obligation in a collective bargaining agreement (CBA), rather, doctrine is a tool to be employed when corporate shield, if respected, would inequitably prevent a party from receiving what is otherwise due and owing from the person or persons who have created the shield.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Employer and its union subsidiary were not alter egos for purposes of pension fund contributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Electrical Workers Pension Trust Fund of Local Union |58, IBEW v. Gary's Elec. Service Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: It was not necessary to pierce the corporate veil to hold corporate officer in contempt for disobeying order enforcing arbitration award requiring corporate employer to pay fringe-benefit contributions to union benefit funds, as funds were not attempting to hold officer liable for employer's corporate debts, but for his deliberate disobedience of court order.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Contempt. Corporate officer could be held in contempt for disobeying order directed to corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Osborn v. University Medical Associates of Medical University of South Carolina
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: In suit for, inter alia, breach of employment contract, corporate defendants other than plaintiff's direct employer would be dismissed for want of contractual privity, absent evidence they exercised total control over employer's operations, i.e., that employer was effectively operated as alter ego or instrumentality of any of them.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Individual directors of South Carolina nonprofit were statutorily immune from liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Rowland v. Franklin Career Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Tests employed by federal courts to determine whether Title VII liability can be imposed on parent corporation for actions of its subsidiaries include: (1) whether two companies are integrated, (2) whether parent exercises significant degree of control over subsidiary's decisions, (3) whether parent is alter ego of subsidiary, and (4) whether parent exercises extensive control over the acts of subsidiary with respect to particular claim of wrongdoing; critical inquiry under each test is whether parent exercised control over significant aspects of plaintiff's terms and conditions of employment or parent dominated subsidiary's operations to such degree that two companies are in reality single entity. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Summary judgment for truck school operator's parent was precluded under integrated enterprise test.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Trustees of Nat. Elevator Industry Pension, Health Benefit and Educational Funds v. Lutyk
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Assuming that sole shareholder of bankrupt employer who was not directly liable as ERISA fiduciary for employer's failure to make contributions to employee benefit plans required by terms of collective bargaining agreements was nevertheless subject to personal liability under federal alter ego doctrine, federal district court did not clearly err in piercing corporate veil and imposing such liability; corporation was clearly insolvent during final years of operation yet amount of "loans" that corporation owed shareholder dropped precipitously at same time, indicating siphoning, shareholder also directly withdrew money from corporation via irregular "partner's drawings," shareholder showed substantial disregard of corporate formalities in his management and ownership, and shareholder engaged in significant commingling of corporation's assets with his own. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 409(a), 29 U.S.C.A. § 1109(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder of bankrupt employer was personally liable for employer's failure to make benefit plan contributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Orenbuch v. North Shore Health Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether the necessary dominion and control exists for the court to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, the court must examine several factors, including (1) the sharing of a common office, staff, and ownership; (2) the intermingling of funds; (3) the treatment of the corporations as one, not separate, profit centers; (4) the lack of the conventions of corporate existence; and (5) any inadequate earnings.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debt collector's nondisclosure of relationship with affiliated organizations did not violate FDCPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Teamsters Health and Welfare Fund of Philadelphia and Vicinity v. World Transp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Imposition of alter ego liability upon sole shareholder of insolvent corporation for contributions that corporation owed to multi-employer benefit funds, pursuant to collective bargaining agreement (CBA) between labor union and corporation, was not warranted; corporation was not grossly undercapitalized, as it operated with insolvency for several years, shareholder infused his own funds into corporation with loans that were unlikely to be repaid in attempt to keep corporation solvent, corporation did not disregard corporate formalities and records, and corporation did not employ non-functioning officers, or operate as mere facade for sole shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of alter ego liability upon shareholder of corporation was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Teamsters Health and Welfare Fund of Philadelphia and Vicinity v. World Transp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Charitable donations made by corporation with financial problems were not siphoned for personal benefit of shareholder, but rather, were legitimate business expenses, which served advertising and business generating purposes, and thus donations did not support piercing corporate veil to impose alter ego liability upon shareholder for contribution amounts that corporation owed to multi-employer benefit funds pursuant to collective bargaining agreement (CBA).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of alter ego liability upon shareholder of corporation was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Teamsters Health and Welfare Fund of Philadelphia and Vicinity v. World Transp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Closely-held corporation did not have non-functioning officers and directors, as would support imposition of alter ego liability upon sole shareholder for contributions owed by corporation to multi-employer benefit funds, pursuant to collective bargaining agreement (CBA) between labor union and corporation; corporation's vice presidents, and president were all involved with the corporation's business operations, along with sole shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of alter ego liability upon shareholder of corporation was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Hoffman v. Harmony Pictures, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Parent company was employer's alter ego, and thus employee whose termination breached implied contract was entitled to lost wages for entire year, even though employer ceased doing business before end of year, where term of employment agreement expired at end of year, and parent company remained in existence throughout year.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of employer's corporate veil was justified in employee's action for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: La Fata v. Raytheon Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, parent corporation could not be held directly liable for subsidiary's alleged severance benefits allegedly owed to subsidiary's employees following subsidiary's sale, absent evidence that would justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Severance policy was benefit plan under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: McCarron v. British Telecom
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be considered the employer of its subsidiary's employees if the two corporations share (1) interrelation of operations, (2) centralized control of labor relations, (3) common management, and (4) common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Summary judgment was precluded on issue of whether employee's bipolar disorder was disabling.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Kingston v. Helm
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Unless alter ego is established, corporate officers and agents are subject to personal liability for their actions within the employment context only when they breach an independent duty of care.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Purchaser of town home was not required to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold developer's corporate president individually liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Praseuth v. Newell-Rubbermaid, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: To satisfy centralized control of labor relations prong of integrated enterprise test for determining parent corporation's liability for acts of subsidiary, parent must control day-to-day employment decisions of subsidiary.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Parent corporation was not liable to employee of subsidiary for subsidiary's alleged discrimination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Massachusetts Carpenters Cent. Collection Agency v. A.A. Bldg. Erectors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Nonunion employer which formed union subsidiary did not create union subsidiary to avoid obligations under collective bargaining agreement, and, thus, employer and subsidiary were not alter egos for purposes of employer's liability for making contributions to ERISA pension plan, despite fact that employer and subsidiary had same ownership, supervision, business purposes, method of operation and customer base, where subsidiary was created to satisfy customers who preferred union workers. Employee Retirement Income Security Act, §§ 502(g), 515, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1132(g), 1145; Labor Management Relations Act, § 301, 29 U.S.C.A. § 185.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Employer and subsidiary were not alter egos for ERISA purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: BMC Software Belgium, N.V. v. Marchand
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: A parent company's offering a stock option plan to a subsidiary's employees is acceptable under Internal Revenue Service regulations and is not evidence of abnormal control over the subsidiary such that the subsidiary is the alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have jurisdiction over foreign subsidiary of Houston based corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Arroyo Rodriguez v. Econo Supermarket Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, member of employer corporation's board of directors holding title of "Secretary," whose duties included signing stock certificates, arranging board meetings and keeping minutes of meetings, was not an "agent" for purposes of potential liability as employer's alter ego under workplace sexual harassment statute; Secretary did not exercise dominion and control such that employer had no separate will of its own. 29 L.P.R.A. § 155a(2).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Secretary of employer corporation was not agent for purposes of sexual harassment liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Arroyo Rodriguez v. Econo Supermarket Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, factors in deciding whether director of employer corporation was alter ego of employer for purposes of potential liability under workplace sexual harassment statute included: (1) whether individual's role was identical to that of employer; (2) individual's position in corporation; (3) whether individual was always physically there; (4) individual's control over employing entity; (5) individual's decision-making power; and (6) whether individual left any avenue for employees to object to his conduct. 29 L.P.R.A. § 155 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Secretary of employer corporation was not agent for purposes of sexual harassment liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Coleman v. ANR-Advance
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Terminated African-American employee, who suffered work-related injury, did not establish that employer acted as alter ego of parent company, such that parent company was liable for employer's alleged race and disability based discriminatory acts; traditional conditions for piercing corporate veil did not exist, and there was no evidence that parent company and its affiliates were created for express purpose of avoiding liability under Title VII and ADA, or that parent company directed employee's alleged discriminatory termination. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.; Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, § 2 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 12101 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employer was not parent company's alter ego, such that parent was liable for its discriminatory acts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Northwestern Ohio Adm'rs, Inc. v. S.E.A. Builders Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: To determine whether one company is alter ego of another company formed for purpose of evading collective bargaining agreement (CBA), district court must consider extent to which management, business purposes, operations, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership are common to two entities, as well as presence of any anti-union animus.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Affiliated company was not alter ego of employer, and thus was not liable for money owed ERISA plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Northwestern Ohio Adm'rs, Inc. v. S.E.A. Builders Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Affiliated company was not alter ego of employer, such that it was liable for money employer owed to ERISA union-management welfare plan; although same parties owned both companies and affiliated company paid sole employee of other company, they were separate and distinct corporations, in that they were managed and operated separately in their daily affairs, they served different business purposes and had different customers, and to extent that they shared some equipment, sharing was slight and matter of convenience, rather than indicative of common enterprise. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Affiliated company was not alter ego of employer, and thus was not liable for money owed ERISA plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Worth v. Tyer
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation affiliated with employer may be found to be proper Title VII defendant if affiliate possibly maintained employment relationship with plaintiff, if affiliate forfeited its limited liability, or if affiliate was responsible for misdeeds of employer through successor liability. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Damages. Punitive damages awarded to Title VII plaintiff were not excessive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Worth v. Tyer
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation may forfeit its limited liability, and thus become subject to Title VII liability to affiliated company's employee, through piercing of the corporate veil, whereby corporate formalities are ignored and the actions of one company can accrue to another. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Damages. Punitive damages awarded to Title VII plaintiff were not excessive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Worth v. Tyer
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil of affiliated corporation, Title VII plaintiff must show that there is such unity of interest and ownership between affiliate and employer that their separate personalities no longer exist, and circumstances must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Damages. Punitive damages awarded to Title VII plaintiff were not excessive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Worth v. Tyer
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: An affiliated corporation forfeits its limited liability, in the context of Title VII liability, when it takes actions for the express purpose of avoiding liability under the discrimination laws or when the affiliate corporation might have directed the discriminatory act, practice, or policy of which the employee is complaining. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Damages. Punitive damages awarded to Title VII plaintiff were not excessive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Worth v. Tyer
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Affiliates of corporation which had possible employment relationship with terminated worker were not proper defendants in worker's Title VII action when affiliates had ceased operations by month in which worker began work and thus never directly employed worker, affiliates did not succeed corporation in interest, so as to trigger successor liability, and there was no evidence that affiliates directed misdeeds underlying Title VII claims, that piercing the corporate veil was necessary to avoid fraud or promotion of injustice, or that affiliates were incorporated to avoid antidiscrimination liability. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701 et seq., as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Damages. Punitive damages awarded to Title VII plaintiff were not excessive.

Title: Worth v. Tyer
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.

Title: Starner v. Guardian Industries

Title: Holbrook v. Lobdell-Emery Mfg. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, to impute tortious intent to an employer that is a legal entity or artificial person, employee seeking to assert intentional tort claim against employer must show either that (1) corporation is tortfeasor's alter ego, or (2) corporation has substituted its will for that of the individual who committed the tortious acts; to prevail under alter ego theory, employee must show that both ownership and control of corporation are in tortfeasor's hands, while to succeed under the other theory, employee must show that individual who committed the tort was acting pursuant to policy or decision made through corporation's regular decision-making channels by those with authority to do so.

Headnote: In determining whether a carrier has used a related corporation for the purpose of evading a collective bargaining agreement (CBA) and the status quo requirements of the RLA, such that the corporate veil should be pierced, the district court may consider the chronology of events; if the carrier only transferred work to the related corporation after unsuccessful union negotiations, that fact may suggest that the carrier shifted the work in an effort to avoid the status quo provisions, and that inference of evasion may be stronger when the work shifted is distinct from the related corporation's primary line of business. Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. P.M.Q.T., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois.
Headnote: In determining whether one corporation is an alter ego of another in the ERISA context, courts will examine several factors and none are entirely dispositive: extent to which corporations are treated as separate entities by the shareholders; fraudulent intent involved; and amount of injustice which parties would suffer by respecting the corporate entity. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Trust funds brought action for delinquent contributions against employer, who was signatory to multiemployer collective bargaining agreement with union, and against company, who trust funds alleged was employer's alter ego.  The District Court, Keys, United States Magistrate Judge, held that company was the alter ego of employer and as such, company was bound by the terms of the collective bargaining agreement entered into by employer and company's funds could be reached in order to pay what was owed to trust funds. So ordered.

Title: Richard v. Bell Atlantic Corp.

Title: Wilson v. International Broth. of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America, AFL-CIO
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: "Alter ego" doctrine, used to bind new employer that continues operations of old employer on grounds that new employer is merely disguised continuance of the old employer, does not apply only to situations in which change in corporate form allows employer to evade collective bargaining obligations, and common ownership and evidence of intent to avoid labor agreements are not essential to alter ego claim.
Document Preview: Former employees brought hybrid claim alleging employer's breach of collective bargaining agreement and union's breach of duty of fair representation.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, David D. Dowd, Jr., District Judge, dismissed all but one plaintiff and entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of remaining plaintiff.  Plaintiffs appealed and defendants cross-appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Boyce F. Martin, Jr., Circuit Judge, held that: (1) grievance filed by one plaintiff was not group grievance; (2) administrative grievance remedy was not futile; (3) plaintiff was entitled to recover from union reasonable attorney fees that employee was forced to spend in pursuing claim against employer; (4) plaintiff was not entitled to recover attorney fees from employers; and (5) any errors in district court's jury instructions did not unduly prejudice jury's result. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Title: Murray v. Miner
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Single employer doctrine is exception to doctrine of limited liability, which allows corporations to organize so as to isolate liabilities among separate entities; rationale for exception is fairness of imposing responsibility on entity that shares decisionmaking authority with employing entity; thus, for policy to apply, the two entities must constitute single employer at time unlawful act was committed.
Document Preview: Former employees of defunct corporation brought suit against successor corporation's principal shareholders, seeking to hold them liable, under single employer doctrine, for breach of employment contracts.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Robert P. Patterson, Jr., J., 876 F.Supp.  512, dismissed complaint for failure to state a claim, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Meskill, Circuit Judge, held that under New York law as predicted by the Court of Appeals, single employer doctrine did not apply to hold controlling shareholders of successor corporation liable for breach of employment contracts, where there was no employer-employee relationship between employees and successor at time of alleged wrong. Affirmed.

Title: Doughty v. CSX Transp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not alter ego of subsidiary corporation, and parent thus was not liable under FELA for injuries sustained by employee while employed by subsidiary; facts that the two corporations had stockholders or officers in common, that one was parent of the other, that parent selected from its own directors and officers the majority of directors of the other, and that parent financed subsidiary were, without more, insufficient to warrant treating them as one. Federal Employers' Liability Act, § 1 et seq., 45 U.S.C.A. § 51 et seq.
Document Preview: Employee of subsidiary corporation brought Federal Employers' Liability Act (FELA) action against parent corporation for injuries he sustained while employed by subsidiary, alleging that parent was alter ego of subsidiary.  The Wyandotte District Court, Bill D. Robinson, Jr., J., entered summary judgment for parent.  Employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lockett, J., held that facts that the two corporations had stockholders or officers in common, that one was parent of the other, that parent selected from its own directors and officers the majority of directors of the other, and that parent financed subsidiary were, without more, insufficient to warrant treating them as one. Affirmed.

Title: Doney v. TRW, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Sixth District, California.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held vicariously liable under equitable doctrine of alter ego for deaths of murdered employees of subsidiary corporation, where subsidiary had satisfied its obligation to employees by securing payment of workers' compensation benefits; permitting application of theory of vicarious liability under such circumstances would produce anomalous result of imposing greater liability on nonnegligent parent than on negligent subsidiary, would give employees who work for corporations unwarranted windfall by exempting them from statutorily mandated limits of workers' compensation, and would, due to unavailability of equitable indemnity, place onerous burden on parent which was fault free. Headnote: In determining whether one corporation is alter ego of another, court examines substantial identify of management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership; antiunion animus is also a critical factor, and distinguishes "single-employer" from "alter ego" status; no single factor controls and all need not be found to support finding of alter ego status.
Document Preview: Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) funds brought action against two moving companies for unpaid contributions.  On motions by funds and companies for summary judgment, the District Court, Zobel, J., held that: (1) collective bargaining agreement requiring one company to contribute to ERISA funds did not exonerate it of responsibility, under alter ego and single-employer theories, for contributions owed by second company; (2) one moving company was alter ego of the other; and (3) companies were single employers liable for each other's debts. Motions granted in part and denied in part.
