Title: Perry v. Stitzer Buick GMC, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Managers who allegedly committed intentional tort against plaintiff employee did not act as alter ego of corporate employer, nor were they acting pursuant to corporate directions or policy, as would support jurisdiction in trial court on ground that plaintiff's injuries were intentionally inflicted by employer and not "by accident" as defined in Worker's Compensation Act. West's A.I.C. 22-3-1-1 et seq.
Document Preview: Discharged African-American salesperson brought action against employer and co-workers alleging civil rights violations and torts.  The Johnson Circuit Court, Jeffrey C. Eggers, J., granted employer summary judgment on all claims, and salesperson appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Baker, J., affirmed summary judgment of civil rights claims but reversed on tort claims. Both parties sought transfer.  The Supreme Court, Shepard, C.J., held that: (1) trial court properly disposed of civil rights claims; (2) salesperson failed to establish jurisdiction on ground that his injuries were intentionally inflicted by employer; but (3) Worker's Compensation Act was not exclusive remedy for employee's nonphysical injuries. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Dickson, J., concurred with separate opinion in which DeBruler, J., joined. Opinion, 604 N.E.2d 613, vacated in part.

Title: Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund v. Mississippi Warehouse Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Criteria for determining whether two entities are alter egos and basic indicia for determining whether two companies are members of same controlled group for purposes of ERISA withdrawal liability are not identical; finding that shareholder is alter ego is determination that corporation is not independent entity but instead has attempted to defraud creditors through technical change in structure or identity of company without any substantial change in ownership or management, whereas, in contrast, finding that entity is member of ERISA controlled group does not depend on any attempted fraud by controlled party, but rather, companies that operate entirely independently of each other can be treated as single employer based upon Internal Revenue Service stock attribution rules. 26 U.S.C.A. § 414(c); Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 4001(b)(1), as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1301(b)(1).

Title: Lopez v. TDI Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate employer was alter ego of majority shareholder, and, thus, piercing of corporate veil was warranted to make majority shareholder liable for judgment in favor of former employee for wages, penalties, interest, and attorney fees; shareholder incorporated at least six different companies in less than ten years, each new company was formed in order to escape liabilities of creditors of predecessor, corporate employer was grossly undercapitalized since only capital contributed by shareholders was $1 per share for 1,000 shares, only valuable asset, patent rights, always remained in ownership and control of shareholders and later majority shareholder, and employee was unsophisticated creditor.
Document Preview: Fiduciary Duty. Former employer's majority shareholder breached fiduciary duty to former employee to make good faith attempt to pay judgment for wages.

Title: St. Katherine Ins. Co. Ltd. v. Insurance Co. of North America, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, fact that parent corporation's employee was not prohibited from bringing suit against subsidiary under workmen's compensation law evidenced separate corporate existence of parent and subsidiary, for purpose of determining whether completed operations hazard clause of general liability policy insuring both parent and subsidiary covered loss sustained by employee when he fell into sulphur pit built by subsidiary on parent's property.
Document Preview: Umbrella insurers brought diversity action against general liability insurer and insureds, seeking declaration that loss was not a completed operations hazard loss under general liability policy.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Harry D. Leinenweber, J., entered judgment for defendants, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that loss resulting from fall by employee of parent corporation into sulphur pit built by subsidiary on parent's property was completed operations hazard loss covered by general liability policy insuring both parent and subsidiary. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Ripple, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion and would grant petition for rehearing.

Title: Daniels v. Kerr McGee Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under Wyoming law, parent corporation was not liable for alleged wrongful discharge of employee by subsidiary under alter ego test for imposing liability on parent corporation, even though there was some degree of interdependence between two corporations, where employee conceded that he was employee of subsidiary and not parent, where subsidiary was adequately capitalized and was capable of satisfying any potential judgment, and where decision to terminate employee was made solely by management of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against parent corporation based on subsidiary corporation's alleged wrongful conduct in discharging employee.  The District Court, Brimmer, J., held that parent corporation was not liable for alleged wrongful discharge of employee by subsidiary under either alter ego test or integrated enterprise test for imposing liability on parent corporation for acts of subsidiary. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Toledo v. Ayerst-Wyeth Pharmaceutical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Veil of corporation of which employer was separate division would not be pierced in action by employee claiming retaliatory discharge under ERISA; there was no evidence that corporation attempted to subvert ERISA's policies by reliance on technicalities of corporate form, and fact that benefit plan brochures bore name of corporation did not defeat separateness of corporation and employer. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 510, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1140.
Document Preview: Employee brought action alleging claims of retaliatory discharge under ERISA as well as various state claims.  On defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Gierbolini, Chief Judge, held that: (1) employer's medical benefits and disability plans constituted welfare benefit plan under ERISA and court had subject matter jurisdiction; (2) question of fact existed as to employer's motivation in discharging employee; (3) court would not pierce corporate veil of corporation of which employer was subdivision; and (4) court would assert pendent jurisdiction over state law claims. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Reboy v. Cozzi Iron & Metal, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Subsidiary was not so highly integrated with parent corporation that they could be treated as one corporate entity for purpose of applying exclusivity provision of Indiana Worker's Compensation Act; record was replete with evidence that subsidiary and parent were distinct and separately operated corporations and that parent made significant and continuing efforts to maintain separate corporate entities. IC 1976, 22-3-2-6.
Document Preview: Worker injured during rail switch maneuver at scrap metal processing yard sued metal company whose wholly owned subsidiary owned scrapyard.  Worker asserted claim for negligent training and supervision.  The United States District Court for Northern District of Indiana, Hammond Division, Rudy Lozano, J., entered judgment on jury verdict for worker.  Metal company appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Eschbach, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) metal company did not waive jury trial on issue of whether it employed worker; (2) evidence supported finding that metal company assumed duty to train and supervise worker; and (3) metal company and subsidiary would not be treated as one corporate entity. Affirmed, reversed and remanded in part.

Headnote: For purposes of determining whether alter ego doctrine applies, each case turns on its own facts, with National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) usually finding that alter ego status exists where two entities have substantially identical management, business purposes, operation, equipment, customers, and supervision, as well as ownership.

Petition denied.

Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether an employer is attempting to defeat its ERISA obligations, through placement of assets in "alter ego" enterprises, key factors to be weighed are whether two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership. Title: Frank v. U.S. West, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under the integrated enterprise test for determining in federal employment discrimination cases if parent corporation is liable for acts of its subsidiary, facts that are considered include interrelation of operations, centralized control of labor relations, common management, and common ownership or financial control.

Affirmed.

Title: Frank v. U.S. West, Inc.

Headnote: Possible tests to determine in federal employment discrimination cases if parent corporation is liable for acts of its subsidiary include: (1) agency theory under which plaintiff must establish that parent corporation exercised significant degree of control over subsidiary's decision making; (2) alter ego test which is founded in equity and permits court to pierce corporate veil; (3) instrumentality test under which plaintiff must establish that parent exercises extensive control over subsidiary's acts giving rise to claim of wrongdoing; and (4) integrated enterprise test which examines interrelation of operations, centralized control of labor relations, and common management and ownership or financial control.

Title: N.L.R.B. v. Greater Kansas City Roofing
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Showing of inequity necessary to satisfy the second prong of the test for piercing the corporate veil must flow from the misuse of the corporate form, and mere fact that corporation commits unfair labor practice, breaches a contract or commits a tort does mean individual shareholders of corporation should personally be liable.
Document Preview: The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) brought action seeking enforcement of supplemental order holding individual shareholder as well as successor corporation liable for unfair labor practice judgment. Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In the context of ERISA, great weight should not be attached to corporate form when interposed to defeat legislative policies. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.

Title: Johnston v. Green Mountain, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: To "pierce the corporate veil" of employer's stockholders in suit for breach of contract and fraud, employee had to show that stockholders had complete control and domination of corporation's finances, policy, and business practices and that stockholders misused that control to employee's detriment.
Document Preview: Employee sued employer for breach of contract and fraud and sought to impose personal liability on employer's stockholders.  The Madison Circuit Court, No. CV91775, Lynwood Smith, J., granted partial summary judgment for employer, and employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Steagall, J., held that: (1) liability could not be imposed on stockholders individually; (2) employer did not engage in anticipatory breach; (3) employer's conduct did not constitute promissory fraud; and (4) employer did not suppress material fact regarding employee's compensation. Affirmed.

Title: Hollingshead v. Burford Equipment Co.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation exercised sufficient control over subsidiary and sufficiently misused that control to be held liable for subsidiary's ERISA obligations; parent paid salaries and expenses of subsidiary, funds were shifted between the two companies at discretion of parent's management, corporate formalities were not observed, and subsidiary's management was aware of its ERISA obligations at time parent was incorporated. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Former employees brought action against employer and its parent corporation under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).  After determining that employer was liable under ERISA, the District Court, Ira DeMent, J., held that: (1) parent corporation exercised sufficient control over subsidiary and sufficiently misused that control to be held liable for subsidiary's ERISA obligation, and (2) individual shareholder who owned all voting shares of parent corporation sufficiently dominated parent's finances, policies and business practices to be held liable for subsidiary's ERISA obligations. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Trustees of Pension, Welfare and Vacation Fringe Ben. Funds of IBEW Local 701 v. Favia Elec. Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Unlawful motive or intent necessary for application of alter ego doctrine in action seeking to recover pension contributions pursuant to collective bargaining agreement entered into by corporation was not present during period of license agreement between corporation and nonunion sole proprietorship; sole proprietor and his wife were seeking to improve their business prospects through use of goodwill they believed was associated with corporation's name, corporation had no customers when agreement was executed, and subsequent customers were obtained through proprietor's efforts.
Document Preview: Trustees of benefit fund brought pension contribution suit against corporation, proprietor of sole proprietorship, and proprietor's wife.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, John F. Grady, J., entered judgment in favor of defendants, and trustees appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Eschbach, Senior Circuit Judge, held that neither single employer doctrine nor alter ego doctrine served to impose liability on any of defendants. Affirmed.

Headnote: Newly formed corporation was alter ego of corporate employer named in suit for contributions required under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) where both companies operated out of same location, had same phone numbers, business purpose, equipment and customers, same owner, and second corporation was set up only after grievance processing began for sole purpose of allowing employer to continue its business while evading further liability under union contract. Title: Talkington v. Anchor Gasoline Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Northeastern Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, subsidiary corporation which employed plaintiff was mere instrumentality of parent corporation, justifying piercing of corporate veil, in suit by former employee to enforce oral promise to provide deferred compensation where parent provided all financing to keep subsidiary in existence, both corporations had interlocking directories and officers, parent provided all legal and accounting services, parent filed consolidated tax returns, parent decided to close subsidiary, parent failed to follow corporate formalities, and parent availed itself of benefit of employee's services.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit based on alleged oral promise of employer's president to provide deferred compensation in lieu of company's standard retirement plan. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Morton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) under Tennessee law, equitable estoppel exception to statute of frauds applied where employer misrepresented intention to prepare and sign written memorandum and corporation's intention not to rely on statute of frauds; (2) partial performance exception to Tennessee statute of frauds applied; (3) corporate veil of subsidiary which employed plaintiff could be pierced as mere instrumentality of parent corporation; and (4) employee could bring suit for total amount due under promise, even though installments were contemplated. Judgment for employee.

Title: Hess v. L.G. Balfour Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, fact that employer owned its own land, paid its own taxes, had its own employees and manufacturing facility, used its own designers and artists, issued its own invoices, and kept its own bank accounts, precluded piercing of corporate veil under instrumentality test by Connecticut lawsuit for alleged breach of contract, failure to pay wages, and constructive discharge, even if parent corporation exercised high degree of control over employer.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit against employer and its parent corporation alleging breach of contract, failure to pay wages, unlawful deductions from wages, conversion, and constructive discharge.  Parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to demonstrate control or malice by parent required under Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality test; (2) employee failed to show that parent and subsidiary had same identity as required by Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under identity test; and (3) parent did not dominate or interfere with subsidiary as needed under Connecticut law to impose liability on parent based on agency's principles. Granted.

Title: Allen v. Oberdorfer Foundries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Although parent corporation may be deemed to be employer of employee of subsidiary corporation for workers' compensation purposes if subsidiary functions merely as alter ego of parent, in order for corporations to be considered alter egos, there must be direct intervention by parent in management of subsidiary to such extent that subsidiary's paraphernalia of incorporation, directors, and officers are completely ignored, and parent corporation must exercise complete domination and control of subsidiary's everyday operations.
Document Preview: Parent Liability. Parent corporation would not be deemed to be employer of subsidiary's worker.

Title: Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity v. United Magazine Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Assertion that party is "alter ego" of signatory of collective bargaining agreement is insufficient to incur liability under Labor Management Relations Act. Labor Management Relations Act, 1947, § 301(a), 29 U.S.C.A. § 185(a).
Document Preview: Employees filed suit alleging violations of Workers Adjustment and Retraining Act, Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) and Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA).  The District Court, 809 F.Supp.  185, denied motion to dismiss complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, granted motion to dismiss first cause of action for failure to state a claim, denied motion to dismiss second and third causes of action for failure to state claims, denied motion to dismiss complaint for failure to join a party, and denied motion to dismiss complaint based upon pleadings.  On defendants' motion for reconsideration, the District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) complaint failed to state claim against corporate movant; (2) complaint failed to allege that defendants were signatories to agreement, as required to state claim pursuant to LMRA for violation of labor contract; and (3) complaint sufficiently alleged alter ego liability under ERISA....

Title: Sasso v. Cervoni
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Sole officer, director and shareholder of corporation was not personally liable for ERISA trust fund contributions that corporation should have made; officer did not act in concert with fiduciary to breach fiduciary obligation, he did not commit fraud, and there was no basis for piercing corporate veil on theory that officer was corporation or its alter ego. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 3(5), 515, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1002(5), 1145.
Document Preview: Trustees of employee trust funds brought action against corporation and its sole officer, seeking to impose liability for unpaid trust fund contributions under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, Jacob Mishler, J., imposed personal liability on officer, and officer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Jon O. Newman, Circuit Judge, held that officer was not personally liable for trust fund contributions. Reversed.

Title: Tatum v. Philip Morris Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Cause of action did not lie against employer's sister corporation based on employer's discharge of employee, allegedly due to his gender, and former supervisor's actions in telling prospective employers that employee had been discharged for stealing property and for insubordination, where there was no indication that any employee of sister corporation was involved in decision to terminate employee or in supervisor's posttermination conduct, and employer and sister corporation, although subsidiaries of same parent, were entirely separate corporations.
Document Preview: Former employee filed action against former employer, former supervisor, former employer's managers and executives, and former employer's sister corporation alleging employment discrimination based upon gender and state law claims of tortious interference with contractual relations, defamation, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and negligent retention.  The District Court, Bohanon, J., held that: (1) employee had been discharged for stealing property and for insubordination, and not on basis of his male gender; (2) employee's discharge did not violate public policy of Oklahoma; (3) former employer had not tortiously interfered with employee's contractual relations with prospective employers; (4) former employer and supervisor had not defamed employee; and (5) former employer and supervisor had not intentionally inflicted emotional distress on employee. So ordered.

Title: N.L.R.B. v. International Measurement and Control Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Affiliated firms cannot be held liable for each other's obligations to workers merely on basis that they are affiliated.
Document Preview: National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) petitioned for enforcement of order imposing its unfair labor practices award previously ordered against allegedly liquidated employer on affiliated business entities and individuals.  The Court of Appeals, Easterbrook, J., held that: (1) NLRB could properly award interest on its previous back pay award; (2) pursuant to Illinois Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act, claims could be satisfied from assets of family members; and (3) evidence supported finding that owners used their three corporations and two partnerships to operate different aspects of one electronic-controls enterprise, having single pool of employees to whom they applied single labor-relations policy, and, thus, supported Board's finding that there was single employer. Enforced.

Title: In re Sullivan Sales Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Employees of parent corporation's wholly owned subsidiary could not rely on alter-ego theory in order to establish wage claim against parent, where parent was not shell but preexisting corporation to which subsidiary's former shareholders had sold their stock; following sale, parent proceeded to install its own board of directors and officers but maintained separate corporate formalities required of subsidiary.

Title: Pipe Fitters Health and Welfare Trust v. Waldo, R., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate officers cannot be held personally liable for corporation's failure to make ERISA contributions when there is no basis for piercing corporate veil. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Union, employee benefit plans, and fund administrators and trustees brought action against corporations and their sole shareholder under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) and Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA) to recover for lost wages, pension payments, health and welfare payments, initiation fees, and union dues.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, Edward L. Filippine, Chief Judge, found that collective bargaining agreements were illegal and unenforceable, and union appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 872 F.2d 815, reversed and remanded.  On remand, the District Court ruled that shareholder was not personally liable for corporate debts, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Beam, Circuit Judge, held that district court was not clearly erroneous in deciding not to pierce corporate veils and hold shareholder personally liable for corporations' failure to make ERISA contributions. Affirmed.

Title: Miller v. Bristol-Myers Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Parent corporation assumes duty of care to employees of its subsidiary where it is found that parent undertook to render services to subsidiary which parent should have recognized were necessary for protection of subsidiary's employees.
Document Preview: Corporate subsidiary's employee brought action against parent corporation for personal injuries arising out of fire which occurred in materials preparation room of subsidiary's facility.  The Circuit Court, Racine County, Stephen A. Simanek, J., entered judgment for parent.  On appeal, the Court of Appeals, 161 Wis.2d 683, 468 N.W.2d 744, reversed and remanded.  On review, the Supreme Court, Day, J., held that: (1) parent was not immune under Worker's Compensation Act, and (2) parent assumed duty to ensure existence of safe material preparation room for subsidiary's employees. Modified, and as modified, affirmed and remanded.

Title: Miller v. Bristol-Myers Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Once parent corporation assumes duty of care to its subsidiary's employees, parent is liable to employee if parent failed to exercise reasonable care to perform its undertaking and: parent's failure to exercise reasonable care increased risk of harm to employee and such increase was cause of employee's injuries; parent failed to exercise reasonable care in performing assumed duty and such unreasonable performance was cause of employee's injuries; or subsidiary or employee relied upon parent's undertaking such that they lessened, omitted, neglected or otherwise altered their safety-related practices and such alteration was cause of employee's injuries.

Title: N.L.R.B. v. O'Neill
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil so as to hold employer's majority shareholder liable for unfair labor practices in connection with closing of meat plant, reopening of plant by employer's alter ego corporations and subsequent permanent closing of plant was justified, as shareholder was driving force behind creation of corporations, created corporations with fraudulent intent and in effort to avoid his labor obligations, and continued to participate actively in their operations.
Document Preview: National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) petitioned for enforcement of two of its orders entered in connection with meat plant's closing, reopening and subsequent permanent closing. The Court of Appeals, D.W. Nelson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) fraudulent concealment exception applied to toll running of limitations period applicable to unfair labor practice complaint until date unions received testimony of indicted company official that majority shareholder of original employer was heavily involved in new corporations operating plant and, thus, NLRB properly allowed reinstatement of previously dismissed charge; (2) NLRB's finding that corporations which took over operation of plant were alter egos of prior employer, so as to warrant treating them as single employer liable for unfair labor practices, was supported by evidence; and (3) piercing of corporate veil so as to hold majority shareholder liable for unfair labor practices was justified. Orders enforced.

Title: Anweiler v. American Elec. Power Service Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, Fort Wayne Division.
Headnote: Insurer under long-term disability (LTD) plan was not alter ego of deceased employee's employer, and, thus, insurer was not itself an "employer," within meaning of Ohio statute barring "employer" from being beneficiary of employee's group life insurance, even if life proceeds, to which insurer claimed entitlement pursuant to reimbursement agreement entered into with employee, were credited to trust account controlled by employer; insurer was not responsible for any employer obligations, such as salary, fringe benefits, or payment of premiums on group policy. Ohio R.C. § 3917.01.
Document Preview: Employee's widow brought action against administrator of long-term disability (LTD) plan and life insurance plan, and against insurer under LTD plan, for breach of fiduciary duty.  On cross motions for summary judgment, the District Court, William C. Lee, J., held that: (1) reimbursement agreement, which designated LTD insurer as primary beneficiary under employee's life insurance benefit to extent of any LTD plan overpayment, was in breach of insurer's and administrator's fiduciary duties under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA); (2) widow was not entitled under ERISA to recover directly for breaches of fiduciary duties; (3) insurer was not employee which would be barred under Ohio statute from being beneficiary of group life insurance; and (4) widow was not entitled to recover statutory penalties or attorney fees under ERISA. Widow's motion denied; defendants' motion granted. Affirmed, 3 F.3d 986.

Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Corporate veil would be pierced to impose liability on shareholders for contributions owed to pension, health and welfare, and other plans where owners regularly paid for personal expenses out of corporate funds, loans were made without promissory notes being executed or interest being paid, one of the corporations was formed for the purpose of avoiding obligations to union and trust fund, and it would be unjust to recognize corporate entities because of corporation's limited assets and the wealth of the shareholders.
Document Preview: Union brought action against employer to recover contributions to pension and health and welfare funds.  On motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Caulfield, J., held that: (1) nonunion signatory business was alter ego of union-signatory; (2) corporate veil would be pierced to impose liability on individual shareholder; and (3) punitive damages in the amount of compensatory damages were appropriate. Judgment for plaintiffs.

Title: United Elec., Radio and Mach. Workers of America v. 163 Pleasant Street Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Federal court determining whether it is appropriate to disregard corporate separateness in ERISA-related dispute should consider whether parent and subsidiary ignored independence of their separate operations, whether some fraudulent intent existed on principals' part, and whether substantial injustice would be visited on proponents of veil piercing should court validate corporate shield.
Document Preview: Union sued employer and employer's foreign parent alleging that employer's planned cessation of health care payments after its closing would violate Massachusetts common law, Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA), and Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).  The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, A. David Mazzone, J., ordered parent corporation to pay health care premiums, and parent corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Selya, Circuit Judge, held that there was insufficient evidence to find that Scottish parent corporation purposefully availed itself of privilege of conducting activities in Massachusetts, and, thus, court lacked jurisdiction over Scottish parent of Delaware employer. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Kroschinsky v. Trustees of S.S. Trade Ass'n/Intern. Longshoremen's Ass'n Pension Trust Fund-Benefits Trust Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Fact that ERISA fund that provided retirement income and an ERISA fund that provided medical and disability benefits shared the same letterhead did not provide a basis for piercing the corporate veil to hold the fund providing retirement income liable in action brought by employee seeking to recover only medical and disability benefits. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Employee brought action under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) against ERISA funds seeking recovery of $12,000 in benefits allegedly due him in connection with work-related injury.  Funds moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Motz, J., held that: (1) fact that funds shared same letterhead did not provide a basis for piercing the corporate veil to hold fund providing retirement income liable in action brought by employee seeking to recover only medical and disability benefits; (2) filing of appeal more than three years after denial of benefits was untimely; and (3) trustees of fund providing medical and disability benefits did not abuse their discretion in denying employee credit for vacation and holiday hours earned during period of his disability. Motion granted.

Title: Baker v. Dataphase, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Former employees who established that former employer breached contract were not entitled to pierce corporate veil to hold officers personally liable for amounts corporation owed them; there was not such a unity of interest in ownership that separate personalities of corporation and officers ceased to exist, there was no commingling of funds and what funds that did pass between officers and corporation were clearly memorialized by notes and were timely paid back in full, corporate assets were not mixed with personal assets, and corporate formalities were observed.
Document Preview: Former employees brought separate actions against former employer and its officers alleging breach of employment contract and sought Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) damages.  The District Court, Aldon J. Anderson, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) former employer and officers breached contract with one employee when it failed to compensate him pursuant to contract; (2) second former employee was not entitled to recover for breach of contract; (3) first former employee was an independent contractor under FLSA and thus could not seek FLSA damages; and (4) former employees could not pierce corporate veil to hold officers liable for amounts due. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Connors v. Princeton Coal Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: Failure by corporations and individuals to address pension plan trustees' alter ego claims, coupled with admissions of alter ego status ordered as discovery sanction, established that corporations and individuals were alter egos for purpose of claim for unpaid contributions.

Ordered accordingly.

Title: Lumpkin v. Envirodyne Industries, Inc.

Headnote: Corporate parent of subsidiaries that were to assume responsibility for substantial unfunded pension fund upon sale of division could not invoke alter ego doctrine to avoid liability for unpaid benefits on ground that subsidiaries were released from liability under terms of settlement agreement negotiated between division employees, predecessor employer, and subsidiaries.

The Court of Appeals, Cummings, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) ERISA's antialienation provision did not apply where central issue was whether agreement's release extended to parent corporation; (2) release was ambiguous on its face as a matter of law; (3) employees but not parent corporation could seek to invoke alter ego doctrine; and (4) employees' claim was governed by ten-year state statute of limitations governing actions on written contracts. Title: Perkins v. Scott
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Coemployee of injured worker, who also was the owner and manager of business which employed injured worker, was not entitled to pierce his corporation's veil and receive its workers' compensation immunity.
Document Preview: Employee injured when he fell down stairway at his place of employment filed action against premises owner who was also owner and manager of plaintiff's corporate employer. The District Court of Appeal, Altenbernd, J., held that: (1) owner was entitled to immunity under fellow employee doctrine absent allegation that his conduct involved gross negligence; (2) owner's fellow employee immunity provided no protection for negligent breaches of duties retained as owner of premises which were separate and distinct from his duties as employee; and (3) owner and manager of corporate employer was not statutory employer and thus was neither obligated to secure workers' compensation benefits or entitled to workers' compensation immunity. Document Preview: Union pension funds brought action against employer and employer's principal seeking to recover alleged delinquency in fringe benefit contributions and unpaid wages. The District Court, Brian Barnett Duff, J., held that: (1) grounds for piercing corporate veil so as to hold principal liable were not shown, and (2) even if pension funds extended credit to corporation by reason of that corporation's failure to pay its bills, nothing in Employee Retirement Income Security Act allowed plans to recover loan from corporation's principal. So ordered.

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Litgen Concrete Cutting & Coring Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: When corporation has obligated itself under collective bargaining agreement to contribute to multiemployer plan, controlling person of corporation is not liable for unpaid contributions unless court can pierce corporation's veil of limited liability or corporation is alter ego of controlling person. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 2 et seq., 515, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1001 et seq., 1145.
Document Preview: Union pension funds brought action against employer and employer's principal seeking to recover alleged delinquency in fringe benefit contributions and unpaid wages.  Principal moved for summary judgment dismissing complaint.  The District Court, Brian Barnett Duff, J., held that: (1) grounds for piercing corporate veil so as to hold principal liable were not shown, and (2) even if pension funds extended credit to corporation by reason of that corporation's failure to pay its bills, nothing in Employee Retirement Income Security Act allowed plans to recover loan from corporation's principal. So ordered.

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Litgen Concrete Cutting & Coring Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Union pension and welfare funds could not recover from corporate employer's controlling person, under theory of piercing corporate veil or alter ego, unpaid contributions owed by corporate employer, where corporate employer was corporation in good standing, maintained its corporate records, had adequate capital, and was going concern, and there was no evidence that any of its three officer-directors commingled his funds with that of corporation, or vice versa. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 515, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1145.
Document Preview: Union pension funds brought action against employer and employer's principal seeking to recover alleged delinquency in fringe benefit contributions and unpaid wages.  Principal moved for summary judgment dismissing complaint.  The District Court, Brian Barnett Duff, J., held that: (1) grounds for piercing corporate veil so as to hold principal liable were not shown, and (2) even if pension funds extended credit to corporation by reason of that corporation's failure to pay its bills, nothing in Employee Retirement Income Security Act allowed plans to recover loan from corporation's principal. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Debreceni v. Bru-Jell Leasing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Bankrupt employer's sister companies were jointly and severally liable for employer's withdrawal from pension fund in violation of Multi-employer Pension Plan Amendments Act as companies under common control. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 4001(b), 4201, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1301(b), 1381.
Document Preview: Manager of pension fund brought action to collect money allegedly owed by corporate employer as result of employer's withdrawing participation in fund.  The District Court, Tauro, J., held that: (1) leave to amend was properly denied; (2) the court had no personal jurisdiction under long-arm statute over employer's principal on claim of fraudulent conveyance; (3) claim for misappropriation of employer's assets belonged exclusively in bankruptcy proceeding; and (4) employer's principal could not be held liable for withdrawal liability. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Laborers' Pension Trust Fund v. Sidney Weinberger Homes, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil of dissolved corporate employer could be pierced to hold shareholder liable under Employee Retirement Income Security Act for corporate employer's failure to properly fund employee benefit packages; sole shareholder "loaned" money to corporation with no formal agreements, paid expenses of corporation out of his pocket, corporation paid personal expenses of sole shareholder, corporation was operated solely for sole shareholder's personal benefit, and record of various expenses was generally inadequate. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Pension trust fund brought action against dissolved corporate employer and sole shareholder alleging failure to fund employee benefit packages properly. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, Horace W. Gilmore, J., granted summary judgment to trust fund.  Corporate employer and sole shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals issued an opinion at 865 F.2d 258, and held that: (1) it was appropriate to pierce corporate veil to hold sole shareholder liable, and (2) trust fund was entitled to prejudgment interest from date of deficiency until deficiency was paid. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Woodson v. Rowland
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Sole shareholder who made all the decisions concerning the corporation, including which jobs to bid, who to hire, and salaries, was an alter ego of the corporate employer and thus enjoyed the same immunity under the workers' compensation exclusivity provisions as the corporation. G.S. § 97-10.1.
Document Preview: Administratrix of estate of deceased worker brought action against employer and general contractor which hired employer.  The Superior Court, Durham County, Henry V. Barnette, Jr., J., granted defendants' motions for summary judgment, and administratrix appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Eagles, J., held that: (1) administratrix had not elected a remedy by filing claim with the Industrial Commission; (2) exception to the Workers' Compensation Act exclusivity provision for intentional injuries by an employer did not extend to injuries resulting from gross and wanton negligence; (3) sole shareholder of subcontractor was the alter ego of the general contractor and entitled to its immunity under the workers' compensation laws; and (4) general contractor owed no duty to employees of independent subcontractor with respect to negligence of the independent subcontractor. Affirmed. Phillips, J., filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO-CLC v. Connors Steel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under federal common law applicable to union's action to enforce collective bargaining agreement, parent corporation, as alter ego of bankrupt subsidiary, was obligated to continue paying subsidiary's employees' retirement benefits, upon determination that parent caused termination of payments which subsidiary was required to make. Labor Management Relations Act, 1947, § 301, 29 U.S.C.A. § 185.
Document Preview: Union sought to enjoin parent corporation of bankrupt subsidiary employer from terminating payment of retirement benefits under expired collective bargaining agreement.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, No. CV87AR0374S, William M. Acker, Jr., J., held for union, and parent appealed.  On rehearing The Court of Appeals, Tuttle, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) employer was obligated to continue providing benefits even after expiration of agreement, and (2) parent was alter ego of subsidiary. Affirmed. Opinion superseded, 847 F.2d 707.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Sargent v. McGrath
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: In absence of special circumstances, parent corporation is not liable for Title VII and § 1981 violations of wholly owned subsidiary. 42 U.S.C.A. § 1981; Civil Rights Act of 1964, §§ 701 et seq., 706, as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 2000e et seq., 2000e-5.
Document Preview: Discharged employee brought action against former employer and its parent corporation to recover for discharge on basis of race and retaliatory discrimination.  Parent corporation filed motion which was treated as motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Myron L. Gordon, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) questions of fact precluded summary judgment as to whether parent corporation was liable for acts of employer that was wholly owned subsidiary, and (2) discharged employee's failure to name employer's parent corporation in equal rights division charges did not deprive court of jurisdiction over claim against parent corporation. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Sargent v. McGrath
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Determinative factual consideration for holding parent corporation liable for acts of wholly owned subsidiary in Title VII and § 1981 action is whether parent and subsidiary are unusually integrated with respect to operation and organization of labor relations. 42 U.S.C.A. § 1981; Civil Rights Act of 1964, §§ 701 et seq., 706, as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 2000e et seq., 2000e-5; Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 56, 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: Discharged employee brought action against former employer and its parent corporation to recover for discharge on basis of race and retaliatory discrimination.  Parent corporation filed motion which was treated as motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Myron L. Gordon, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) questions of fact precluded summary judgment as to whether parent corporation was liable for acts of employer that was wholly owned subsidiary, and (2) discharged employee's failure to name employer's parent corporation in equal rights division charges did not deprive court of jurisdiction over claim against parent corporation. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Serembus v. Comfort Lines, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Status of employer's subsidiary as alleged alter ego did not render its property subject to prejudgment attachment to satisfy employer's delinquent contributions to health and welfare fund and pension trust; simply being alter ego with employer was not evidence of fraud or wrongdoing and did not evince intent on part of subsidiary to transfer property beyond scope of court's jurisdiction. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.; Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 64, 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: Trustee of health and welfare fund and pension trust brought action against employer, its president, and moved for freeze on assets of subsidiary during pendency of action.  The District Court, Moran, J., held that subsidiary's status as alleged alter ego of employer did not alone render its property subject to prejudgment attachment. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Hoffman v. Optima Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, failure of fraud and breach of contract plaintiff to demonstrate that piercing corporate veil of his employer was necessary to defeat the fraud or other alleged wrongs allegedly committed on him by employer, precluded piercing of the veil.
Document Preview: Employee filed breach of contract, fraud, deceptive trade practices, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and corporate negligence action against corporate employer and major shareholders.  On defendants' motion to dismiss, the District Court, Young, J., held that: (1) complaints stated fraud with sufficient particularity; (2) plaintiff's detrimental reliance removed breach of contract action from statute of frauds; (3) complaint failed to state deceptive trade practices action; (4) evidence was insufficient to support piercing of corporate veil; (5) plaintiff lacked standing to bring derivative corporation suits; and (6) complaints failed to state cause of action for intentional infliction of emotional distress. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Vermeer v. Dismantling Contractors, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Corporation established by owner of demolition business to operate on a nonunion basis was alter ego of original corporation created by owner to handle union contracts and was bound by collective bargaining agreement entered into by first corporation; second corporation came into existence in order to take over project which the first corporation had begun, its only reason for existing was to avoid first corporation's union obligations, and second corporation had same management, shared workers with other corporation and used same phone number, post office boxes and insurance policies as other corporation. ORS 19.125(3).
Document Preview: Trustees of several employer/employee trusts established by collective bargaining agreements between union contractors and union sought accounting of contributions that corporation was allegedly required to pay on behalf of laborers which it employed.  The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Lee Johnson, J., entered judgment in favor of corporation, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Warden, P.J., held that corporation established by owner of demolition business to operate on a nonunion basis was alter ego of original corporation created by owner to handle union contract and was bound by collective bargaining agreement. Reversed and remanded.

Title: In re Consolidated Litigation Concerning Intern. Harvester's Disposition of Wisconsin Steel
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: If person or corporation is misusing its privilege to create corporations by attempting to use corporate structures as a shield to circumvent purposes of Employee Retirement Income Security Act, district court may pierce corporate veil to impose liability on shareholders or parent corporation. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation brought action alleging that predecessor employer was required to reimburse it for payments it had to make to employees of successor which became insolvent.  Predecessor moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Moran, J., held that PBGC stated cause of action against predecessor employer for liability for successor's withdrawal from single-employer pension plan. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Kiehl v. Action Mfg. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In the absence of any threat to public convenience or fraud, Supreme Court would not pierce corporate veil of wholly owned subsidiary at request of parent corporation so as to entitle parent corporation to claim immunity under Workmen's Compensation Act from third-party's trespass suit brought by employees of wholly owned subsidiary. 77 P.S. § 481(a).
Document Preview: Employees of wholly owned subsidiary corporation brought trespass action against parent corporation.  The Court of Common Pleas, Philadelphia County, Nos. 3778 and 3779 May Term 1980, entered judgment in favor of parent corporation.  Appeal was taken.  The Superior Court, Nos. 02648 and 02649 Philadelphia, 1985, in a memorandum opinion, 357 Pa.Super. 641, 513 A.2d 1080 unpublished opinion, affirmed.  Petition for allowance of appeal was granted.  The Supreme Court, No. 21 E.D. Appeal Docket 1987, Larsen, J., held that parent corporation was not entitled to immunity under Workmen's Compensation Act from third-party suit brought by injured employees of wholly owned subsidiary. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Voss v. Supermail/Western Union
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Outlet store for telegraph company and other communications operations, which rehired telegraph company's employees shortly after they had been discharged by company, was not "alter ego" bound by terms of telegraph company's collective bargaining agreement; employees presented no evidence that outlet store was established as sham corporation so that telegraph company could avoid contractual obligations.
Document Preview: Employees sued employer and former employer for companys' alleged breach of covenant of good faith and fair dealing, misrepresentation, intentional infliction of emotional distress, defamation and age discrimination. Defendants removed case to federal district court based on purported federal question jurisdiction, and employees moved to remand.  The District Court, Enright, J., held that: (1) federal question existed regarding construction of collective bargaining agreement sufficient to defeat employees' motion to remand claims against former employer, but (2) employees' claims against other employer did not arise under collective bargaining agreement, did not raise federal question, and had to be remanded to state court. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Galgay v. Gangloff
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Personal financial responsibility for delinquent contributions to employee benefit plans may not be imputed under Employee Retirement Income Security Act or Labor Management Relations Act to shareholders or officers merely because of size of their ownership or extent of control which they exercise over corporation. Labor Management Relations Act, 1947, § 301(a), 29 U.S.C.A. § 185(a); Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Multiemployer plan brought action against enterprises and chief executive officer to collect delinquent contributions allegedly owed.  Defendants moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Nealon, Chief Judge, held that: (1) plan stated cause of action against chief executive officer for personal liability for delinquent contributions; (2) plan stated cause of action against enterprises on basis of alter ego theory; and (3) plan stated cause of action against enterprises for breach of fiduciary duty. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Galgay v. Gangloff
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Personal liability under Employee Retirement Income Security Act and Labor Management Relations Act may be imposed for delinquent corporate contributions to employee benefit plans where alter ego doctrine applies. Labor Management Relations Act, 1947, § 301(a), 29 U.S.C.A. § 185(a); Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Multiemployer plan brought action against enterprises and chief executive officer to collect delinquent contributions allegedly owed.  Defendants moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Nealon, Chief Judge, held that: (1) plan stated cause of action against chief executive officer for personal liability for delinquent contributions; (2) plan stated cause of action against enterprises on basis of alter ego theory; and (3) plan stated cause of action against enterprises for breach of fiduciary duty. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: DeBreceni v. Graf Bros. Leasing, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under general purposes of Multi-Employer Pension Plan Amendments Act of 1980, individual liability for corporate withdrawal liability should be governed by general principles of corporate law; corporate shareholder or officer may be held personally liable for withdrawal liability under ERISA by applying test generally required to "pierce the corporate veil," rather than by applying "economic reality" test similar to that used in cases decided under Fair Labor Standards Act. Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, § 6, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 206; Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 4201 et seq., as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1381 et seq.
Document Preview: Pension fund brought action seeking to recover balance of corporation's ERISA withdrawal liability from corporation's sole shareholder after corporation declared bankruptcy.  The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, A. David Mazzone, J., granted summary judgment for shareholder, and fund appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Torruella, Circuit Judge, held that corporation's sole shareholder was not personally liable for corporation's ERISA withdrawal liability following corporation's bankruptcy; corporation was not shareholder's alter ego under common-law piercing-the-corporate-veil theory. Affirmed.

Title: DeBreceni v. Graf Bros. Leasing, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation's sole shareholder was not personally liable for corporation's ERISA withdrawal liability following corporation's bankruptcy; corporation was not shareholder's alter ego under common-law "piercing-the-corporate-veil" theory. Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, § 6, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 206; Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 4201 et seq., as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1381 et seq.
Document Preview: Pension fund brought action seeking to recover balance of corporation's ERISA withdrawal liability from corporation's sole shareholder after corporation declared bankruptcy.  The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, A. David Mazzone, J., granted summary judgment for shareholder, and fund appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Torruella, Circuit Judge, held that corporation's sole shareholder was not personally liable for corporation's ERISA withdrawal liability following corporation's bankruptcy; corporation was not shareholder's alter ego under common-law piercing-the-corporate-veil theory. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: International Broth. of Elec. Workers, Local Union No. 332, AFL-CIO v. Hyland Wilson Elec. Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division. .
Headnote: Corporate employer that had not signed multiemployer collective bargaining agreement was alter ego under California law of corporate employer that had done so and, therefore, was bound by arbitration award against signing employer; officers and directors for both employers were identical before arbitration; one week after arbitration hearing employer that had not signed agreement changed officers; and employer that had not signed agreement used signing employer's trucks and ladders and employed persons who also worked for signing employer.
Document Preview: Union brought action to enforce arbitration award against corporate employer that had signed multiemployer collective bargaining agreement, officers of employer, and corporate employer that had not signed agreement. Motion to confirm arbitration award was filed. The District Court, Aguilar, J., held that: (1) signing employer received adequate notice of arbitration and waived right to contest award; (2) employer that had not signed agreement was alter ego of signing employer and was bound by arbitration award; and (3) notice to signing employer was constitutionally adequate notice to employer that had not signed agreement. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Fen Hin Chon Enterprises, Ltd. v. Porelon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Northeastern Division.
Headnote: Purchaser of plant to manufacture preinked hand stamps was not alter ego of vendor, even though purchaser employed same workers and same factory manager at same facility; owners of purchaser had owned only combined 32% interest in vendor; bona fide sale of business had occurred based on unimpeached appraisal value; and purchaser assumed entire liability for severance pay of labor force.
Document Preview: Licensee brought action against licensor for breach of exclusive patent and trademark licensing agreement to make and sell preinked hand stamps in Hong Kong.  The District Court, Morton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) licensee did not breach agreement by alleged sales to China, alleged quality problems, or alleged improper use of trademark; (2) licensor breached agreement by assisting competitor and by wrongfully terminating agreement; and (3) licensee was entitled to damages for past, present, and future lost profits. Judgment for licensee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Porter v. Beloit Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, wholly-owned subsidiary of decedent's employer was not the same as decedent's employer so as to be entitled to protection of workers' compensation exclusive remedy provision in wrongful death action alleging that subsidiary was negligent in installing platform above paper machine, which caused platform to give way, causing death of decedent when he fell into paper machine, absent showing that subsidiary's corporate identity should be disregarded because of fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Wholly-owned subsidiary of decedent's employer moved for summary judgment that subsidiary was entitled to exclusivity protection of Mississippi's workers' compensation law in wrongful death action arising out of accident wherein platform installed by subsidiary above paper machine gave way, causing death of decedent when he fell into paper machine. The District Court, Barbour, J., held that wholly owned subsidiary was not the same as decedent's employer under Mississippi law so as to be entitled to invoke protection of exclusivity provision of workers' compensation law. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Solomon v. R.E.K. Dress
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Even though officer and sole shareholder of corporation would not be deemed to be an "employer" as term was used in Employee Retirement Income Security Act, officer and sole shareholder could be held liable for corporation's failure to make contributions to benefit plans in accordance with terms of collective bargaining agreements if circumstances of case warrant piercing corporate veil. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 3(5), 29 U.S.C.A. § 1002(5).
Document Preview: Trustees of employee benefit plans brought action to require employer to make contributions to plans.  The District Court, Kram, J., held that: (1) president and sole shareholder of corporation was not an employer for purposes of applying Employee Retirement Income Security Act, and (2) president and sole shareholder of a corporation could be held liable for corporation's failure to make contributions to benefit plans, if circumstances of case warranted piercing corporate veil. Complaint dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Cement Masons' Pension Trust Fund-Detroit and Vicinity v. O'Reilly
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporation organized after cement contracting business was initially operated as sole proprietorship was not alter ego of sole proprietor such that he could be held individually liable for corporation's delinquent health and welfare contributions to fringe benefit funds; organization of corporation for avowed purpose of avoiding personal responsibility does not itself justify disregard of corporate entity, and there was no allegation that sole proprietor organized corporation in attempt to evade his obligations under collective bargaining agreements or that sole proprietor would be responsible for debts of corporation on theory of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Two fringe benefit funds initiated action against sole proprietor and successor corporation for delinquent health and welfare contributions owed to each of them under separate collective bargaining agreements.  After entry of partial summary judgment in favor of one fund against sole proprietor, the District Court, Cohn, J., held that: (1) workers described as independent contractors were nonetheless entitled to contributions on their behalf; (2) corporation was not alter ego of sole proprietor such that he was individually liable for corporation's delinquent health and welfare contributions; and (3) corporation was valid successor and was liable for delinquent health and welfare contributions. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Mo-Kan Teamsters Pension Fund v. Creason
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Corporation formed out of sole proprietorship could be bound to judgment requiring proprietor to make payments to union pension funds, even though corporation was not party to lawsuit against proprietor, in that corporation was alter ego of proprietor. Labor Management Relations Act, 1947, § 302, 29 U.S.C.A. § 186; Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 3, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1002.
Document Preview: Union pension funds brought action against employer and owner of employer to recover for unpaid contributions.  Employer and owner brought action against former attorney for failure to terminate liability to funds.  Motions for summary judgment were filed against funds, employer, owner, and attorney.  The District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) Kansas five-year statute of limitations for written contract did not bar recovery of delinquent contributions for more than five years before filing of lawsuit; (2) employer was liable for unpaid contributions incurred by its owner and prior proprietorship; and (3) Kansas two-year statute of limitations for tort did not bar action of owner and employer against attorney for failure to terminate liability to funds. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Owens v. American Nat. Red Cross
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: In deciding whether two entities are single employer for purposes of determining liability for wrongful discharge and breach of contract, Connecticut courts would consider functional interrelation of operations, centralized control of labor relations, common management, and common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against local chapter and national organization alleging wrongful discharge from employment and breach of contract.  The District Court, José A. Cabranes, J., held that: (1) national organization and local chapter were not sufficiently integrated to justify treating them as single employer; (2) local chapter's termination of employee for attending third party's unemployment hearing did not constitute wrongful discharge in violation of public policy; and (3) material issues of fact as to whether employee handbook constituted enforceable contract, and whether local chapter breached contract when it dismissed employee, precluded summary judgment in favor of local chapter. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: McKinney v. Gannett Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Publisher could sue newspaper organization for breaching publisher's employment contract with newspaper, even though organization had not signed contract, on theory that organization was essentially alter ego of newspaper, where organization had complete stock ownership of newspaper and controlled its board of directors, organization disregarded separate corporate status and treated newspaper as division of whole, all of newspaper's revenue went to organization, all of newspaper's capital expenditures were proved by organization, and organization drafted employment contract and negotiated with publisher as to rights and duties of parties.
Document Preview: Former owner of newspaper brought action against corporation which purchased newspaper after sale alleging breach of contract of employment, and seeking rescission of contract of sale. The Court of Appeals, 694 F.2d 1240, dismissed appeals.  The United States District Court for the District of New Mexico, Santiago E. Campos, J., entered final judgment in favor of former owner, and all parties appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Holloway, Chief Judge, held that: (1) dismissal of newspaper's counterclaim against former owner for breach of employment contract was proper; (2) newspaper organization breached employment contract by frustrating former owner's contractual powers of editorial control and right to hire and fire; and (3) district court did not abuse its...

Title: Joyce v. Super Fresh Food Markets, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Two subsidiary corporations could not be viewed as single entity so as to allow piercing of corporate veil of parent corporation, which had incurred costs of injured employee's workmen's compensation benefits, and to immunize nonhiring subsidiary from suit by injured employee of hiring subsidiary.
Document Preview: Injured employee of hiring subsidiary corporation brought suit for personal injuries sustained while working at one of nonhiring subsidiary corporation's stores.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, Charles R. Weiner, District Judge, 640 F.Supp. 721, granted summary judgment to nonhiring subsidiary, and injured employee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, James Hunter, III, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) the two subsidiary corporations could not be viewed as single entity so as to allow piercing of corporate veil of parent corporation, which had incurred all costs of injured employee's workmen's compensation benefits, and to immunize nonhiring subsidiary, and (2) whether hiring or nonhiring subsidiary corporation was injured employee's actual employer involved disputed factual questions, precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Johnson v. Flowers Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Parent company is employer of subsidiary's personnel, as required to establish prima facie case of age discrimination, only if it controls subsidiary's employment decisions or so completely dominates subsidiary that the two corporations are the same entity. Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 621 et seq.
Document Preview: Employees brought suit against their employer, its parent and another subsidiary, alleging that parent replaced them with younger employees of other subsidiary, in violation of Age Discrimination in Employment Act.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia, at Roanoke, James C. Turk, Chief Judge, granted summary judgment for defendants, and employees appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Wilkinson, Circuit Judge, held that absent showing that parent company, which allegedly replaced employees of one subsidiary with younger employees of second subsidiary, maintained anything other than normal parent-subsidiary relationship with second subsidiary, replaced employees failed to establish prima facie case of age discrimination. Affirmed.

Title: Scarbrough v. Perez, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Tennessee, Western Division.
Headnote: Employer's failure to pay into insurance and pension funds established by collective bargaining agreement and its withdrawal from pension fund was not type of fraud or injustice that would require piercing of corporate veil under Indiana law in order to make sole shareholder, chief executive officer, of corporate parent liable for delinquent contributions and withdrawal liability. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 2-4402, 3(9), 4001 et seq., as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1001-1461, 1002(9), 1301 et seq.

Motion granted.
