Title: Leichihman v. Pickwick Intern.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Parent company could not be held liable for alleged age discrimination by its subsidiary simply on the basis that, after acquiring the subsidiary, it change some of the management and retirement benefit policies that affected the subsidiary's employees where there was no evidence linking the parent to any of the individual employment decisions of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Former employee brought age discrimination action against former employer and its parent company.  The United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, James M. Rosenbaum, J., 589 F.Supp. 831, granted plaintiff's motion for summary judgment and, following first trial which resulted verdict in favor of former employee, granted former employer's motion for new trial and then entered judgment on jury verdict following second trial in favor of employer.  Former employee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, John R. Gibson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) trial court applied proper standard in granting new trial; (2) trial court's determination that first verdict in favor of former employee was against great weight of evidence was supported; and (3) disparate impact analysis was inapplicable where employer made a number of layoffs by applying subjective decisions to eliminate certain positions in order to cut costs. Affirmed.

Title: Laborers' Pension Trust Fund-Detroit and Vicinity v. Family Cement Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporation was alter ego of its officers' prior unincorporated business, and hence, officers were jointly and severally liable with corporation for unpaid fringe benefits owed under collective bargaining agreement; although there was no showing of unlawful intent, work of both corporation and unincorporated business was identical, successor assumed obligations of predecessor, and equipment, officers and control were the same.
Document Preview: Pension trust fund brought action against corporation and its officers seeking to collect unpaid fringe benefits owed under collective bargaining agreement. The District Court, Philip Pratt, Chief Judge, held that: (1) corporation was alter ego of officers' prior unincorporated business, and hence, officers were jointly and severally liable with corporations for unpaid contributions, and (2) fund was entitled to unpaid contributions, prejudgment interest, and liquidated damages or second interest award. So ordered.

Title: Lowen v. Tower Asset Management, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Although no explicit Employee Retirement Income Security Act provisions pertain to piercing corporate veil, remedial thrust of ERISA is not to be frustrated by meticulous emphasis on corporate form. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Trustees of two pension plans move for partial summary judgment on two counts of amended complaint alleging violation of prohibited transaction provisions of Employee Retirement Income Security Act.  The District Court, Vincent L. Broderick, J., held that: (1) investment banking corporation and registered broker dealer, as well as investment manager, were fiduciaries within meaning of Act; (2) basis for piercing corporate veil and holding individual defendants personally liable existed; (3) defendants violated ERISA provisions prohibiting fiduciary from dealing with assets of plan in his own interest and from receiving any consideration for his own personal account from any party dealing with plan in connection with transaction involving assets of plan; and (4) plaintiffs were entitled to restitution to plans of all profits and all forms of consideration received by defendant in violation of ERISA. Order accordingly.

Title: Alvarado Morales v. Digital Equipment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Parent corporation and wholly owned subsidiary did not constitute single enterprise or employer, and parent was thus not liable for subsidiary's alleged misconduct under "common control" doctrine, where corporations had separate and distinct boards of directors, no member of parent's board of directors had any involvement in factual issues raised in complaint, subsidiary acted in its own name, corporations each established their own separate employees relations and personnel policies, and subsidiary, not parent, employed employees who brought action against parent.
Document Preview: Employees brought putative class action against nonresident parent corporation for physical and emotional damages arising from work place conditions at wholly owned subsidiary.  The District Court, Perez-Gimenez, Chief Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation and its directors were not subject to personal jurisdiction under Puerto Rico long-arm statute for acts of wholly owned subsidiary, where subsidiary was separate legal entity; (2) employees' complaint was barred by Puerto Rico Workmens' Accident Compensation Act; and (3) employees and their attorney who alleged that parent corporation tortured and brainwashed employees with concentration camp tactics were liable for sanctions under Rule 11. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Curtis v. Lehigh Footwear, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not liable for severance pay of employees of wholly owned subsidiary, as statute mandating severance pay contained no clear expression of legislative intent to extend liability to shareholders of parent corporation. 26 M.R.S.A. § 625-B, subd. 1, par. C.

Title: Selser v. Pacific Motor Trucking Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Railroad's ownership of subsidiary's stock was insufficient to establish that railroad dominated subsidiary and that subsidiary should be treated as merely division of railroad for purposes of liability under Federal Employers' Liability Act. Grady Jolly, Circuit Judge, held that employee failed to establish that railroad dominated subsidiary to such extent that subsidiary should be considered no more than division of railroad for purposes of Federal Employers' Liability Act liability. Title: Solomon v. Klein
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Holder of 50% of stock of corporation, who was also president and chief executive officer, could not be held personally liable for unpaid amounts due retirement fund pursuant to collective bargaining agreement between corporation and union, where there was no basis for piercing the corporate veil. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 2 et seq., 3(5, 9), 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1001 et seq., 1002(5, 9).

Title: Gorrill v. Icelandair/Flugleidir
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Parent corporation dominated subsidiary and effected subsidiary's employees' discharges for purposes of piercing corporate veil, where it was resolution of parent's board that directed subsidiary to give employment preferences to Icelanders and Bahamians, parent's chief executive officer directed firing of subsidiary's employees, and parent's employees effectuated subsidiary's employees' discharges.
Document Preview: Airline pilots and flight engineers terminated from their employment brought action against employer and employer's parent corporation alleging improper termination. The Court of Appeals, Oakes, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) operations manual imposed express limitation upon employers' right to discharge at will; (2) parent corporation dominated employer and effectuated employees' discharges; (3) Railway Labor Act did not deprive court of jurisdiction; (4) employees were entitled to damages even after date employer ceased its passenger operations; and (5) employees who had reached age of 65 were entitled to damages. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded. See also 522 F.Supp. 670.

Title: Beckwith v. International Mill Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under integrated enterprise test, which has been specifically applied in Age Discrimination in Employment Act cases and which is directed towards determining whether a nominally separate corporation should be considered a single employer, court assesses interrelations of operations, common management, centralized control of labor relations and common ownership or financial control existing between parent and subsidiary. Motions granted.

Title: Reader v. Dertina and Associates Marketing, Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: Corporation was operated as alter ego of sole stockholder, and thus, corporate veil was properly pierced in favor of former employees for commissions and bonuses due where, inter alia, the business was incorporated as mere formality for tax purposes, no directors' meetings were held, sole stockholder retained total control of company operations, took money from corporate account for personal purchases, and made promises of possible ownership sharing and future benefits to employees, and where employees performed valuable services for the corporation.

Title: Bumpers v. International Mill Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To hold parent corporation of employer responsible under Age Discrimination in Employment Act, employee must show that nexus between parent corporation and employer was greater than mere parent-sub relationship. Title: Greater Kansas City Laborers Pension Fund v. Thummel
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.

Headnote: Parent corporation was proper defendant in age discrimination action brought by former manager of subsidiary where parent and subsidiary formed integrated enterprise regarding management decisions of subsidiary's executives and, in such area, parent was alter ego of subsidiary, which was but mere instrumentality of parent. Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, §§ 2 et seq., 11(b), 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 621 et seq., 630(b).
Document Preview: Former employee brought age discrimination action against subsidiary for which he worked and its parent, alleging discharge in violation of Age Discrimination in Employment Act. After trial on the merits, and on parent corporation's motion to be dismissed as defendant, the District Court, Raymond J. Broderick, J., held that: (1) parent corporation was employer of subsidiary's employee amenable to suit under Act; (2) parent corporation was properly subject to court's jurisdiction; and (3) although former employee had established prima facie case of discrimination, he had failed to prove by preponderance of evidence that former employers' articulated nondiscriminatory reasons for his discharge were mere pretext for discrimination. Judgment accordingly.

Title: Monroe v. Monsanto Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Greenwood Division.
Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether two related businesses should be considered as separate and distinct corporations for workmen's compensation purposes under law of South Carolina include whether businesses maintain separate corporate identities, whether businesses maintain separate boards of directors, whether businesses transact business from different locations under different managers, whether businesses hire and pay their own employees, whether corporations hold themselves out to their employees as two separate entities, whether corporations engage in different business activities, whether corporations maintain separate books, bank accounts and payroll records, and whether corporations file separate tax returns. S.C.Code 1976, § 42-1-540.

Title: Butler v. Collins
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Party hired by corporate general partner to act as producer of music festival was not entitled to pierce corporate veil in order to recover amounts allegedly due him for his employment from president of corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from order of the United States Bankruptcy Court, Thomas M. Brahney, III, J., which sustained objection of trustee in bankruptcy to claim against estate of debtors. The District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Charles Schwartz, Jr., J., held that: (1) record in suit by party hired by corporate general partner to act as producer of music festival to recover amounts president of corporation allegedly agreed to pay him did not demonstrate that president agreed to accept party's compensation as a personal obligation, and (2) party was not entitled to pierce corporate veil in order to recover amounts allegedly due him for his employment. Affirmed.

Title: Audit Services, Inc. v. Rolfson
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Employer's sole shareholder was not to be held personally liable for judgment assessed against employer for failing to pay contributions to union trust funds pursuant to collective bargaining agreement where there was no evidence of fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Assignee of certain union trust funds brought action against employer, employer's succeeding corporation, and corporations' owners to recover contributions allegedly required pursuant to collective bargaining agreements. The United States District Court for the District of Montana, Russell E. Smith, J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, J. Blaine Anderson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) the agreements required payment of trust fund contributions on behalf of nonunion employees; (2) defendant could not assert defenses of laches or estoppel; (3) subsequently-formed corporation was liable under the agreements as a successor to employer; and (4) successor's sole shareholder was not to be held personally liable for judgment assessed against the corporation. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Title: McKinney v. Gannett Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Newspaper was alter ego of parent corporation such that the corporate existence of the newspaper should be disregarded, and any remedy for breach of employment contract with editor-in-chief would run against the parent corporation, which was really the party that broke its promises to the editor-in-chief, made in connection with acquisition of his former ownership interest, where the parent corporation and sole shareholder of the newspaper had so manipulated the newspaper that its identity had merged into that of the parent, which in many important respects had bypassed the board of directors of the newspaper, and had funneled off all cash generated by the newspaper into the parent's headquarters.
Document Preview: Former owner of newspaper brought action against newspaper and corporation which purchased newspaper alleging breach of contract of employment and fraud, and seeking rescission of sale.  The District Court, Campos, J., held that: (1) agreement whereby former owner was to be employed as editor-in-chief and retain control of newspaper for several years was breached in various respects; (2) despite difference in parties, the employment contract and the contract involving the sale of the newspaper were an entire contract so that, where breach of employment contract went to the essence thereof, former owner was entitled to rescission; (3) newspaper was the alter ego of the purchasing corporation such that any remedy would run against the purchasing corporation; (4) appropriate remedy was to give former owner option of rescission after accounting rather than ordering rescission outright; (5) there was no basis for recovery of claimed ancillary...

Title: Humphries v. Bray
Court: Court of Appeals of Arkansas.
Headnote: Corporation with single shareholder who was also sole proprietor of two separate businesses was merely alter ego of shareholder, and, therefore, corporate employees could be combined with employees of shareholder's other enterprises for workers' compensation purposes. Ark.Stats. § 81-1302(c).
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from the Circuit Court, Crittenden County, Gerald Brown, J., awarding workers' compensation benefits to the claimant. The Court of Appeals, Glaze, J., held that the corporation which was technically the employer of the claimant was merely the alter ego of the sole shareholder, and, therefore, the employees of the corporation could be combined with the shareholder's other employees for workers' compensation purposes. Affirmed.

Title: Spray v. Kellos-Sims Crane Rental, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. Georgia, Augusta Division.
Headnote: Corporation which survived merger of crane rental business and family owned equipment rental business was alter ego of other interests of crane rental business and was "employer" within meaning of Title VII where there was confusion of crane rental business' business interest and failure to demonstrate by preponderance of evidence that corporation which survived merger had less than 15 employees. Civil Rights Act of 1964, §§ 701 et seq., 701(b), 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 2000e et seq., 2000e(b).
Document Preview: Former dispatcher for crane rental business filed an action alleging employment discrimination in her termination. A bench trial was held in a bifurcated fashion. The District Court, Bowen, J., held that: (1) the former dispatcher was discharged because she was not as efficient as another available dispatcher and because company personnel legitimately felt that she could not expand her duties to become an assistant or branch manager, and, therefore, her discharge was due to legitimate, nondiscriminatory reasons which were not pretextual, and (2) however, the former dispatcher was entitled to recover the difference in pay between that received by her predecessor, who performed essentially equivalent, if not identical, functions and was paid $50 per week more, and the amount paid to her. Complaint dismissed in part, judgment for plaintiff in part.

Title: Adams v. Associates Corp. of North America
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Employee of wholly owned subsidiary of wholly owned subsidiary of parent corporation, which administered all personnel policies and programs for the several corporations and which sold employee's employer, would be treated as an employee of parent corporation and was therefore entitled to termination pay under provision of parent's human resources policy authorizing termination pay for reduction in staff.
Document Preview: Parent corporation appealed from a judgment of the 15th Judicial District Court, Lafayette Parish, Lucien C. Bertrand, Jr., J., which required it to pay termination benefits to a former employee of a wholly owned subsidiary's wholly owned subsidiary. The Court of Appeal, Guidry, J., held that employee of wholly owned subsidiary of wholly owned subsidiary of parent corporation, which administered all personnel policies and programs for the several corporations and which sold employee's employer, would be treated as an employee of parent corporation and was therefore entitled to termination pay under provision of parent's human resources policy authorizing termination pay for reduction in staff. Affirmed. Swift, J., filed dissenting opinion and voted to grant a rehearing.

Title: Brink v. DaLesio
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: In view of fact that corporate formalities were not observed by insurance broker for union funds and that many of the services for the funds were performed by employees of the broker's sole proprietorship rather than his corporation, corporate veil would be pierced and the broker would be held individually liable for breach of fiduciary duties under ERISA. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, §§ 404, 406, 29 U.S.C.A. §§ 1104, 1106.
Document Preview: Union members who were participants in certain funds brought action against union official, who also served as trustee, and funds' insurance broker to recover for breach of fiduciary duties. The District Court, Joseph H. Young, J., held that: (1) plaintiffs had standing only with respect to funds in which they were participants; (2) union official had breached fiduciary duties owed to the fund and to the union under the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act and ERISA; (3) insurance broker was a fiduciary under ERISA; (4) broker had breached his fiduciary duties; and (5) union official was liable for breach of fiduciary duties by the broker. Order accordingly.

Title: Lane v. Dickinson State Bank
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Where bank and its president, who loaned employer money for its initial capitalization, were not alleged to be shareholders, incorporators, directors, or officers of employer, doctrine of corporate alter ego was inapplicable as basis for holding bank and its president responsible for harm suffered as result of allegedly wrongful discharge of employee, who alleged that bank and its president so controlled and dominated corporate employer that they and employer should be considered one and the same and that corporate fiction should be disregarded.
Document Preview: Suit was brought by former employee against employer, bank and its president for wrongful breach of his employment contract. The District Court, Galveston County, Ed J. Harris, J., granted bank and its president's motion for summary judgment and, after obtaining default judgment against employer, employee appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Peden, J., held that: (1) doctrine of corporate alter ego was inapplicable to hold bank and its president responsible for corporate employer's conduct; (2) former employee, who had not alleged that bank and its president committed any fraudulent act against him or caused employer to discharge him, or that their allegedly fraudulent activity caused financial condition of employer to deteriorate to point that his discharge became necessary, had no remedy against bank and its president as third parties, and (3) employee had no standing to sue on behalf of employer for alleged fraud. Affirmed.

Title: Harry Zeruld Co., Inc. v. Workmen's Compensation Appeal Bd.
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where there was no evidence indicating any misuse of corporate entity but, rather, claimant showed that company was duly incorporated for lawful purposes, that her husband's underlying motives for incorporation were legitimate, and that her husband and company did not commingle bank accounts or other assets, corporate entity of company could not be disregarded so as to deny workers' compensation benefits to claimant for death of her husband, who as a duly elected officer was an employee of company according to statute, despite his complete control over company. 77 P.S. § 22.
Document Preview: The Workmen's Compensation Appeal Board affirmed award of death benefits to claimant for death of her husband, who was fatally injured while working in company's regular course of business, and company appealed. The Commonwealth Court, No. 523 C.D.1979, Blatt, J., held that claimant's husband, who exercised complete control over company, but who as officer and manager of company was legally subject to ultimate right of control by entire board of directors, was an employee for purposes of the Workmen's Compensation Act. Affirmed.

Title: United Paperworkers Intern. Union v. T. P. Property Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Surrounding circumstances did not justify piercing corporate veil of parent corporation of paper company for purpose of requiring parent, which was not signatory to collective bargaining agreement between paper company and unions, to arbitrate provisions of such agreement. Title: Darnel v. East

Title: Baker v. Stuart Broadcasting Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors to be employed to determine whether two corporations may be treated as one, for purposes of definition of "employer" in Title VII of Civil Rights Act of 1964, include interrelation of operations, common management, centralized control of labor relations, and common ownership or financial control. 42 U.S.C.A. § 1982; Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701(b), 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e(b).

Title: Craft v. Califano

Headnote: To determine whether a qualifying employer-employee relationship exists, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare and the courts may pierce the corporate veil where the facts reveal that the employee and the real owner of the business were related. Title: Cooperman v. Unemployment Ins. Appeals Bd.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Fact that corporate entity has been disregarded for some purposes in an action does not mean that it will be disregarded for all purposes, and determination that corporation and its president and sole shareholder were one and same for purposes of unemployment insurance eligibility did not mean that he would necessarily be held personally liable for tort or contract action brought against his corporation.
Document Preview: A referee determined that a corporate president and sole shareholder was eligible for unemployment insurance benefits when the corporation was inactive, though ineligible when the corporation was active. The Court of Appeal, Loring, J., held that a finding that the corporate president and sole shareholder was the alter ego of the corporation was supported by substantial evidence and was not erroneous as matter of law, and where the activities of the president and sole shareholder were directed towards self-employment and the alter ego doctrine was applicable, he was unemployed and eligible for benefits for the period while the corporation was inactive. Judgment of trial court affirmed.

Title: Latham v. Technar, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Northern Division.
Headnote: Although stock ownership of one corporation by another may serve in certain instances as an indicia of identity or commixture as between the two corporations for the purpose of creating identity for workmen's compensation purposes, it is not conclusive.
Document Preview: Administrator of estate of individual killed in test chamber explosion brought wrongful death action. On corporate defendant's motion to set aside verdict awarding administrator $300,000 or, alternatively, for a new trial, the District Court, Robert L. Order accordingly.

Headnote: Unemployment Compensation Board of Review erred in piercing the veil of corporation which was owned by claimant's husband and herself and which was not used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime and in denying unemployment compensation on finding that her employer was her husband and not the corporation. 43 P.S. § 753(l )(4)(5), 802(h).

The District Court, Bailey Brown, Chief Judge, held that where former employee claimed discrimination in employment practices by employer which did not have requisite number of employees to make it subject to Civil Rights Act of 1964 but which was subsidiary of another corporation which maintained normal parent-subsidiary relationship with affairs of two corporations handled separately, parent and subsidiary would not be considered as one entity. Motions granted. Affirmed 6 Cir., 454 F.2d 199.

Title: Wakeman v. Paulson
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, Department 2.
Headnote: Even if defendant, who at time he hired plaintiff as sales manager owned 264/267264267s of corporate stock and owned 58% at time of filing of plaintiff's action for sales commission, had manipulated corporation by misrepresentations as to sales so that he would profit by public stock sale and subsequent sale of assets to another corporation, that would not justify disregarding corporate entity and allowing plaintiff to recover from defendant individually.
Document Preview: Action against corporation and majority stockholder for sales commission allegedly owing plaintiff who had been employed as sales manager of corporation. The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Alan F. Davis, J., disregarded corporate entity and held majority stockholder liable individually and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Denecke, J., held that, even if defendant, who at time he hired plaintiff as sales manager owned 264/267s of corporate stock and at time of the action owned 58% Of outstanding shares, had manipulated corporation by misrepresentations as to sales so that he would profit by public stock sale and subsequent sale of assets to another corporation, that would not justify disregarding corporate entity and allowing plaintiff to recover from defendant individually. Reversed as to individual defendant and affirmed as to defendant corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Wakeman v. Paulson
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, Department 2.
Headnote: Inasmuch as claim against a dissolved corporation survives, creditor of corporation can satisfy his claim against corporation out of assets distributed to stockholders upon dissolution, and assets of corporation which had employed plaintiff and which were distributed upon dissolution had substantial value, plaintiff was not entitled, on theory that his claim against corporation was uncollectible, to have corporate entity disregarded and recover from person who had been majority stockholder the amount due under employment contract. ORS 57.630(1).
Document Preview: Action against corporation and majority stockholder for sales commission allegedly owing plaintiff who had been employed as sales manager of corporation. The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Alan F. Davis, J., disregarded corporate entity and held majority stockholder liable individually and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Denecke, J., held that, even if defendant, who at time he hired plaintiff as sales manager owned 264/267s of corporate stock and at time of the action owned 58% Of outstanding shares, had manipulated corporation by misrepresentations as to sales so that he would profit by public stock sale and subsequent sale of assets to another corporation, that would not justify disregarding corporate entity and allowing plaintiff to recover from defendant individually. Reversed as to individual defendant and affirmed as to defendant corporation.

Title: Wakeman v. Paulson
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, Department 2.
Headnote: Even if individual defendant had in effect been the entire management of corporation, that would not justify disregarding corporate entity, in suit by former employee for compensation allegedly due.
Document Preview: Action against corporation and majority stockholder for sales commission allegedly owing plaintiff who had been employed as sales manager of corporation. The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Alan F. Davis, J., disregarded corporate entity and held majority stockholder liable individually and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Denecke, J., held that, even if defendant, who at time he hired plaintiff as sales manager owned 264/267s of corporate stock and at time of the action owned 58% Of outstanding shares, had manipulated corporation by misrepresentations as to sales so that he would profit by public stock sale and subsequent sale of assets to another corporation, that would not justify disregarding corporate entity and allowing plaintiff to recover from defendant individually. Reversed as to individual defendant and affirmed as to defendant corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Chelsea Industries, Inc. v. Florence
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Fact that subsidiary discharged general manager without substantial and material cause did not establish that parent corporation was entitled to enjoin general manager from engaging in a competitive enterprise, even if it was a separate corporate entity, since parent's ownership of all stock of subsidiary and existence of overlapping directors and officers in substance made parent responsible for discharge.
Document Preview: Bill in equity to enjoin defendant from competing with a wholly owned subsididary of corporate plaintiff. The Superior Court, Mitchell, J., dismissed bill, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Judicial Court, Cutter, J., held that exculpatory clause of employment contract between seller and corporate buyer of stock in corporation providing that noncompetition provisions of contract were to be null and void if contract was terminated for any reason other than seller's illness or for a cause which is substantial and material applied as well to closely interrelated purchase contract between same parties containing similar noncompetition provisions but no exculpatory clause, and, thus, once seller-employee was discharged for reasons other than substantial and material, his formation of a competing company did not constitute a violation of purchase contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: West Bearing & Parts, Inc. v. Peet
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, Department 2.
Headnote: In determination whether an enterprise is a single employing unit within meaning of unemployment insurance statutes, corporate structure may not be disregarded. ORS 657.020, 657.480.
Document Preview: Appeal from an order of the Appeals Board of the Department of Employment which denied corporations experience rating, for determination of amount of employer contributions under Unemployment Insurance Act, enjoyed by individual owner prior to incorporation. The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Phillip J. Roth, J., reversed, and the Commissioner of the Department of Employment appealed. The Supreme Court, Sloan, J., held that where business of an individual were transferred to two separate corporations, the corporations were not entitled to the experience rating enjoyed by the individual prior to incorporation. Reversed; order of Appeals Board reinstated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Industrial Commission v. Lavach
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, In Department.
Headnote: Party seeking to deny an individual the benefits of incorporation on equitable grounds must clearly show that the corporate fiction has been used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim, and such principle is applicable to workmen's compensation cases where claimant controls his corporate employer but suffers injuries while performing an employee's duties.
Document Preview: Action seeking workmen's compensation benefits. The District Court, City and County of Denver, Saul Pinchick, J., reversed an order of the Workmen's Compensation Commission and directed the Commission to award full workmen's compensation benefits, and writ of error was taken. The Supreme Court, Moore, C.J., held that where employer, which was controlled by employee who was killed in highway accident, agreed to provide its employee with means of transportation and to pay employee's cost of commuting to and from work, scope of employment was inferentially enlarged to include employee's transportation, so that employee, who was killed while returning home from work, was in the course of his employment and his widow was entitled to workmen's compensation benefits. Judgment of district court affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: National Homes Corp. v. Lester Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court W.D. Virginia, Danville Division.
Headnote: Where smaller corporate manufacturer of prefabricated housing units became wholly-owned subsidiary of larger corporate manufacturer of such units, smaller manufacturer's president agreed to continue in employment of smaller manufacturer and covenanted not to compete with larger manufacturer after termination of employment, and employment was terminated, the corporate veil would not be pierced to permit damage done to smaller manufacturer by president's subsequent competition to run to larger manufacturer.
Document Preview: Suit for injunction. The District Court, Walter E. Hoffman, Chief Judge, held that where smaller corporate manufacturer of prefabricated housing units became wholly-owned subsidiary of larger corporate manufacturer of such units, and smaller manufacturer's president became member of larger manufacturer's board of directors and agreed to continue in employment of smaller manufacturer and covenanted not to compete with larger manufacturer anywhere in United States after termination of employment within ten-year period, larger manufacturer suffered such irreparable injury by president's engaging in prefabricated housing business after termination of employment as to be entitled to injunctive relief as to areas in which such competition occurred. Injunctive relief granted. Affirmed in part and reversed in part 4 Cir., 404 F.2d 225.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Calhoun v. Louisiana Materials Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Defendant subsidiary corporation, with whom plaintiff had employment contract in connection with plaintiff's sale of business to parent corporation, being an entity distinct from its parent, had no standing to urge as offsets alleged breaches of warranties running in favor of parent.
Document Preview: Action to recover on employment contract. The Civil District Court for the Parish of Orleans, Division B, No. 443567, Clarence Dowling, J., rendered judgment, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeal, Yarrut, J., held that defendant subsidiary corporation, with which plaintiff had employment contract in connection with sale of business to parent corporation, was estopped to raise breach of warranty issues decided adversely to parent corporation in plaintiff's earlier action to recover on sale contract, and that plaintiff was entitled to interest from date amounts were due. Amended and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: In re Hursh's Estate
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where decedent was not initially entitled to annuity her received under the Railroad Retirement Act because he was rendering compensated services to a corporation formed by him to handle his personal business, his executor could not reject the corporate entity, hold it to be a mere fiction and treat corporate activity as decedent's personal activity, so that the United States was entitled to recover from estate annuity payments received by decedent, notwithstanding that decedent had received payments under an honest mistake and had not realized that corporate form made his receipt of government annuity improper. Retirement Act of 1937, 45 U.S.C.A. §§ 228a-228y.
Document Preview: Appeal from definitive decree of the Orphans' Court of Montgomery County, at No. 65,004, Alfred L. Taxis, Jr., President Judge, holding that since decedent was not initially entitled to annunity he received under the Railroad Retirement Act because he was rendering compensated services to a corporation formed by him, the United States was entitled to recover those annuity payments from his estate. The Supreme Court, No. 150 January Term, 1967, Cohen, J., held that even though decedent had received payments under an honest mistake and had not realized that corporate form made his receipt of a government annunity improper, his executor could not reject the corporate entity, hold it to be a mere fiction and treat the corporate activity as decedent's personal activity. Affirmed. Roberts, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Turpin v. Chicago, B. & Q. R. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, En Banc.
Headnote: Separate entities of corporations, though one owned stock of another, recognized in absence of fraud, connivance or undue domination, are to be given effect in solving questions of employment.
Document Preview: Federal Employers' Liability Act action brought against railroad as alleged joint employer of plaintiff who was employed by truck line wholly owned by railroad for injuries sustained in course of unloading trailer from flatcar. The Circuit Court of Jackson County, Paul A. Buzard, J., rendered a judgment for the defendant on a post-trial motion, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Eager, J., held that where railroad contracted with truck line which it wholly owned to load and unload trailers used in piggy-back operations as independent contractor and nothing was done to impair that relationship, truck line employee injured in course of unloading trailer remained solely employee of truck line and railroad was not a joint employer of him and he had no claim for injuries against railroad under Federal Employers' Liability Act. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Finazzo v. Mid-States Finance Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Where it appeared that assets of employer being sued by employee for amount allegedly due under contract requiring employee to be paid percentage of net earnings of employer had been dispersed into corporate maze controlled by principal stockholder of corporate employer, corporate veil would be pierced to prevent fraud on employee.
Document Preview: Suit by former employee against employer to recover under contract providing that employee was to be paid percentage of net earnings of employer. The Circuit Court, Madison County, I. H. Streeper, III, J., entered judgment adverse to defendant and defendant appealed. The Appellate Court, Goldenhersh, J., held that evidence supported finding that change of employer's accounting system reducing its net income had been made without plaintiff's approval and had been inconsistent with employer's prior accounting practices, but that there was no showing that employer's practice of making loans to affiliates without interest had been a change of employer's practice. Judgment for plaintiff in reduced amount entered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Lopp v. Peerless Serum Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Plaintiff who had dealt with president of dominant corporation and contracted to sell certain property in return for employment contract could, in seeking restitution upon breach of contract, disregard corporate entity of wholly-owned subsidiary which was formed for sole purpose of acquiring property in question, where subsidiary had insufficient assets to discharge obligation.
Document Preview: Action for restitution upon breach of contract whereunder a defendant promised to employ plaintiff in return for plaintiff's transfer of certain property. The Circuit Court of the City of St. Louis, Ivan Lee Holt, Jr., J., granted defendants' motions for judgment n. o. v. and for new trial, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Pritchard, C., held, inter alia, that failure to submit question whether amounts plaintiff had received exceeded reasonable value of his services, so as to excuse plaintiff from tendering return of benefits, was prejudicial error requiring a new trial. Judgment for one defendant affirmed; judgment for other defendant reversed and case remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Haynes v. Champagne Tile Corp.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Louisiana, Baton Rouge Division.
Headnote: Where corporate employer of plaintiff was incapable of handling business, but new corporation organized to obtain new work did not take place or supplant employer and did not acquire employer's officers or employees, new corporation was not alter ego of employer and plaintiff who terminated employment four months before new corporation was organized was not entitled to recover back wages from new corporation but was entitled to recover from employer. Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, § 1 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 201 et seq.; Fair Labor Standards Amendments of 1949, § 16(e), 29 U.S.C.A. § 216b.
Document Preview: Suit brought pursuant to Fair Labor Standards Act for back wages. The District Court, West, J., held that where corporate employer of plaintiff was incapable of handling business, but new corporation organized to obtain new work did not take place or supplant employer and it did not acquire employer's officers or employees, new corporation was not alter ego of employer and plaintiff who terminated employment four months before new corporation was organized was not entitled to recover from new corporation but was entitled to recover from employer. Claim against new corporation dismissed and judgment entered against employing corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Remme v. Herzog
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Judgment in favor of former employee for percentage of profits allegedly due under contract of employment was properly rendered against individuals who constituted stockholders of corporation, as well as corporate employer itself, in view of undercapitalization of corporation and evidence that individuals in operating business themselves disregarded corporate entity.
Document Preview: Action by former employee against former employer for accounting and to recover percentage of profits allegedly due employee under contract of employment. The Superior Court, Sacramento County, James H. Oakley, J., entered judgment for the employee, and an appeal was taken. The District Court of Appeal, Van Dyke, J. pro tem., held that judgment in favor of former employee was properly rendered against individuals who constituted stockholders of corporation, as well as corporate employer itself, in view of undercapitalization of corporation and evidence that individuals in operating business themselves disregarded corporate entity. Judgment modified, and as modified, affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Reynolds Pallet & Box Co. v. N. L. R. B.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Where sole proprietor transferred business to corporation and proprietor and his wife owned 90% of company, which built new plant, and supervisory personnel was brought over to new plant, and equipment of old plant was purchased by company and transferred to new location, and company continued in same line of business, corporation was alter ego of sole proprietorship and was liable for unfair labor practices based on dismissal of employees of sole proprietorship because of union activity when business was transferred to new location. National Labor Relations Act, § 8(a), (1, 3) as amended 29 U.S.C.A. § 158(a) (1, 3).
Document Preview: Proceeding on petition for review of an order and proceedings of the National Labor Relations Board which filed an answer seeking enforcement of the order. The Court of Appeals, Cecil, Chief Judge, held that where sole proprietor transferred business to a corporation and proprietor and his wife owned 90% Of the company, which built new plant, and supervisory personnel was brought over to the new plant, and equipment of old plant was purchased by the new company and transferred to new location, and the company continued in the same line of business, the corporation was the alter ego of the sole proprietorship and was liable for unfair labor practices based on dismissal of employees of sole proprietorship because of union activity when business was transferred to new location. Decree accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Carbone v. Unemployment Compensation Bd. of Review
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Unemployment compensation board could properly pierce the corporate veil to determine that claimant employed by a corporation, which was owned by the claimant's two sons and nephew in three equal shares, was actually employed by his sons and was therefore disqualified for unemployment compensation benefits.
Document Preview: Proceeding on appeal from a decision of the Unemployment Compensation Board of Review, No. B-76723, dated March 14, 1963. The Superior Court, No. 182 October Term, 1963, Woodside, J., held that the claimant was not entitled to unemployment compensation benefits because corporation for which he worked was actually owned by his two sons and his nephew in three equal shares. Decision affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Moss v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Employee of first corporation could not recover dismemberment benefits under group policy issued to second corporation on theory that second was alter ego of first, where corporations were created under laws of different states and had different principal places of business, neither was subsidiary to nor owned stock in the other, and interlocking directorate or management did not exist.
Document Preview: Action for dismemberment benefits under group policy. The Fourth Judicial District Court, Parish of Ouachita, Hillyer S. Parker, J., entered judgment rejecting plaintiff's demands, and he appealed. The Court of Appeal, Ayres, J., held that employee of first corporation could not recover dismemberment benefits under group policy issued to second corporation on theory that second was alter ego of first, where corporations were created under laws of different states and had different principal places of business, neither was subsidiary to nor owned stock in the other, and interlocking directorate or management did not exist. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Roberts' Fish Farm v. Spencer
Court: Supreme Court of Florida.
Headnote: Industrial Commission, acting through either full commission or a deputy, had no jurisdiction to disregard legal entities and hold another corporation and partnership, for which claimant had never performed any services, jointly liable with corporate employer for payment of compensation benefits on theory that the partnership and corporations were in fact one and not three separate entities.
Document Preview: Proceeding on claims against two separate corporations and a partnership for workmen's compensation benefits. To review an order of the Florida Industrial Commission which affirmed an order of the deputy commissioner awarding compensation benefits and holding one of the corporations and the partnership jointly liable with corporate employer for payment of such benefits, such corporation and partnership brought certiorari. The Supreme Court, O'Connell, J., held that the Industrial Commission, acting either through the Full Commission or a deputy, had no jurisdiction to disregard legal entities and hold another corporation and partnership jointly liable with corporate employer for payment of compensation benefits on theory that the partnership and corporations were in fact one and not three separate entities. Order quashed and cause remanded for proceedings consistent with opinion.

Title: Basila v. Unemployment Compensation Bd. of Review
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: It was permissible for unemployment compensation authorities to pierce corporate veil in order to determine true ownership of corporation and determine that claimant whom it found, with her husband, owned 80 per cent of stock of her alleged employer was actually self-employed and disqualified from benefits. 43 P.S. § 802(h).
Document Preview: Unemployment compensation case wherein the claimant appealed from a decision of the Unemployment Compensation Board of Review at No. 71488, June 15, 1962, denying benefits. The Superior Court, No. 19 February Term, 1963, Montgomery, J., held that it was permissible for unemployment compensation authorities to pierce corporate veil in order to determine true ownership of corporation and determine that claimant whom it found, with her husband, owned 80 per cent of stock of her alleged employer was actually self-employed and disqualified from benefits. Decision affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Fawcett v. Missouri Pac. R. Co.
Court: United States District Court W.D. Louisiana, Lake Charles Division.
Headnote: Fact that trucking company which employed decedent was wholly owned subsidiary of defendant railroad did not establish that trucking company was alter ego, adjunct, subsidiary agent, and instrumentality of railroad so as to permit suit under Federal Employers' Liability Act against railroad for death of such employee. Federal Employers' Liability Act, §§ 1-10, 45 U.S.C.A. §§ 51-60.
Document Preview: Action against railroad under Federal Employers' Liability Act. The District Court, Hunter, J., held that freight company employee, who died as result of being crushed between truck tractors on flatcar being loaded on siding owned by defendant railroad, who was not on railroad payroll, who was not doing work that railroad was required to do, and who was not under supervision of railroad employees was not employee of railroad within coverage of Federal Employers' Liability Act at time that he met his death, and his administratrix had no cause of action against railroad where freight company was not alter ego of railroad even though railroad owned all outstanding stock of freight company and five officers of freight company were also officers of railroad. Summary judgment for defendant. Judgment affirmed, 347 F.2d 233.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Lazar v. Board of Review, Division of Employment Sec., Dept. of Labor and Industry
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey Appellate Division.
Headnote: The corporate veil could be pierced and the true factual situation determined in case involving unemployment compensation benefits of wife who worked in incorporated toy and gift shop which was run by husband. N.J.S.A. 43:21-19(i) (7) (C).
Document Preview: Unemployment compensation case. The claimant appealed from a decision of the Board of Review in the Division of Employment Security holding that her claims for unemployment compensation benefits were invalid and that she was not entitled to the benefits she received and was liable for their refund. The Superior Court, Appellate Division, Goldmann, S.J.A.D., held that evidence sustained finding that toy and gift shop, although it had been incorporated, was individual business of husband who was sole owner of corporation, so that wife who worked in shop did not work for family corporation but was in husband's employment, with result that she was not entitled to unemployment compensation when she did not work during the slack season. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Brown v. Benton Creosoting Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Sawmill company which was mere alter ego of creosoting company over which it had full management and entire control was not permitted to cloak itself behind corporate entity of creosoting company to shield itself from responsibility for workmen's compensation liability to creosoting company employee. LSA-R.S. 23:1061, 23:1062.
Document Preview: Suit for workmen's compensation for permanent and total disability from burns. The Twenty-Sixth Judicial District Court, Parish of Bossier, O. E. Price, J., rendered judgment for defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeal, Ayres, J., held that trial court erred in denying compensation for total and permanent disability on theory that plaintiff had not sustained demands where plaintiff adduced evidence establishing that, at time of trial, because of burns, he was unable to return to and discharge employment duties, though rpobable duration of disability was not established, but he was to be awarded compensation for permanent total disability, and that sawmilling company which was mere alter ego of creosoting company immediately employing plaintiff could not escape liability for compensation by cloaking itself behind corporate shield of creosoting company and held that under the circumstances penalties and attorney fees were not warranted. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Pettaway v. McConaghy
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Injured workman who suffers compensable injury may not recover from defendant who is sole stockholder, president and manager of employer corporation, if corporate veil is pierced by almost complete identity between corporation and defendant. Comp.Laws Supp.1956, § 413.15.
Document Preview: Action by corporation's injured employee against sole stockholder, president and manager. The Circuit Court, Wayne County, Joseph G. Rashid, J., dismissed the declaration, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Adams, J., held that statute permitting injured employee to recover from third person, excepting employer and natural person in same employ, was intended to exempt all natural persons carrying on any of employer's activities, and precluded employee's action against employer corporation's sole stockholder, president and manager. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: McLaughlin v. L. Bloom Sons Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Where new corporation was formed to operate a fourth shoe store and there was a unity of ownership of both new corporation and older corporation which operated three shoe stores and which had signed collective bargaining agreement with union, there was no abuse of discretion in applying alter ego doctrine to require that new corporation be bound by collective bargaining agreement of older corporation.
Document Preview: Union's action for declaratory judgment that the new defendant corporation was the alter ego of the old defendant corporation for the purposes of collective bargaining agreement. The Superior Court, County of Santa Clara Robert F. Peckham, J., entered a judgment for the union and the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Agee, J., held that it was not an abuse of discretion to apply the alter ego doctrine to the new corporation which was controlled by the same individuals as the old corporation that had signed a collective bargaining agreement. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Di Gregorio v. Unemployment Compensation Bd. of Review
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The corporate entity may be ignored in determining whether an unemployment compensation claimant in fact was unemployed under the Act, or was a self-employed person whose business merely proved unremunerative during period for which claim for benefits was made. 43 P.S. §§ 753(w) (1), 801(c), 802(h).
Document Preview: Unemployment compensation case. The Unemployment Compensation Board of Review, No. B-66891-B, December 5, 1961, entered a decision that claimant was ineligible and he appealed. The Superior Court, No. 68, October Term, 1962, Montgomery, J., held that mere fact corporate landscaping business was operated on a seasonal basis and consequently was unable to continue paying claimant's wages during claim weeks in question was not sufficient to remove claimant from classification of a self-employed person, where he was president and part owner of corporation from which he allegedly was laid off. Order affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Roccograndi v. Unemployment Compensation Bd. of Review
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate entity of family corporation could be ignored for purpose of determining whether employee-members were self-employed, and as such not entitled to unemployment compensation. 43 P.S. § 802(b) (1), (h).
Document Preview: Unemployment compensation case. The Unemployment Compensation Board of Review, Nos. B-63682, B-63683, and B-63684, May 11, 1961, denied compensation, and applicants appealed. The Superior Court, at Nos. 12, 13, 14 February Term, 1962, Montgomery, J., held that corporate entity of family corporation could be ignored for purpose of determining whether employee-members were self-employed, and as such not entitled to unemployment compensation. Decisions affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1064 Labor and employment liabilities and violations >
Title: Brannon v. Ribicoff
Court: United States District Court, D. Montana, Billings Division.
Headnote: Income received by president of family corporation may constitute wages and self-employment earnings under Social Security Act, where corporation was duly and properly organized under state law, president and his wife transferred their property to corporation, directors and officers were regularly elected, corporate reports and tax returns were regularly filed on behalf of corporation, and corporation maintained accounting books and records, though annual meetings of stockholders and directors were not held. Social Security Act, §§ 209, 210(a, j), 211(a) (1) as amended 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 409, 410(a, j), 411(a) (1).
Document Preview: The president of a family-owned corporation brought an action under the Social Security Act against the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare to review a decision adverse to the president with respect to old-age benefits. The District Court, Jameson, J., held that income received by the president may constitute wages and self-employment earnings under the act, where the corporation was duly and properly organized under state law, the president and his wife transferred their property to the corporation, the directors and officers were regularly elected, the corporate reports and tax returns were regularly on behalf of the corporation, and the corporation maintained accounting books and records, though annual meetings of the stockholders and directors were not held. Case remanded to Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

Title: Gottlieb v. Arrow Door Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: The veil of corporate existence would not be pierced in workmen's compensation case brought by principal stockholder and officer in complete control of corporation, in absence of allegations or proofs of fraud, sham or other improper use of corporate form.
Document Preview: Workmen's compensation case. The Workmen's Compensation Appeal Board awarded compensation, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Smith, J., held that claimant was entitled to compensation even though he was sole stockholder of corporation. Affirmed.

Title: N.L.R.B. v. Deena Artware, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of the United States
Headnote: Where petition of National Labor Relations Board to hold parent corporation, dominant stockholder, and other subsidiaries in civil contempt for failure of parent corporation to pay amounts due employees under a back pay order, charged that dealings between corporations and between corporations and stockholder showed both fraud and wrongdoing for purpose of frustrating back pay order and operation of various corporations as a single enterprise, with each of corporations performing particular function as a department or division of one enterprise in manufacture, sale and distribution of common product, board was entitled to show that separate corporations were not what they appeared to be but that in truth they were but divisions or departments of a single enterprise and to a hearing on that alternative theory and to discovery in aid of it. National Labor Relations Act, § 8(a) as amended 29 U.S.C.A. § 158(a).

Title: Klekamp v. Blaw-Knox Co.
Court: United States District Court S.D. California, Central Division.
Headnote: Evidence established that parent corporation was a party to contract whereby a piping engineer was employed to work on a construction job in Venezuela under a contract with parent corporation's subsidiary and hence parent corporation could be held liable as a principal if it breached the employment contract.
Document Preview: Action for breach of employment contract. The United States District Court for the District of California, Central Division, Byrne, J., held, inter alia, that where printed terms' of employment contract whereby piping engineer was employed to work on construction job in Venezuela under contract that employer had entered into with government of Venezuela, provided that under Venezuelan law contract could be terminated on notice provided certain payments were made, employer in effecting engineer's termination by giving notice and paying certain expenses including expenses of returning to point of origin committed no breach whether such terms' were considered as part of contract or were considered dehors the contract and, applying the governing principles of conflicts of law, the Venezuela contract law were applied. Judgment for defendant in accordance with opinion.

Title: U.S. v. Islip Mach. Works, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. New York.
Headnote: In action by the government under the Walsh-Healey Act for damages for underpayment of wages on a government contract against the corporate contracting party and the president of the corporation who was not a signatory thereon but whose liability was predicated upon the finding that he was in effect a "party responsible" for breach of the contract, where, in reality, corporation was the individual defendant's alter ego or agent, he could be held liable as the "party responsible" by disregarding the corporate fiction and considering him the actual party to the contract. Walsh-Healey Act, §§ 2, 5, 41 U.S.C.A. §§ 36, 39.
Document Preview: Action under the Walsh-Healey Act for damages for breach of contract arising out of underpayment of wages on a government contract brought against the corporate contracting party and the corporate president who was not a signatory on the contract but whose liability was predicated upon a finding that he was in effect a party responsible for the breach of the contract. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, Bartels, J., held that where the corporation and the president were one and the same as contracting parties they could be held jointly and severally responsible. Judgment for the government.

Title: Spector Freight System, Inc. v. Dispatch Exp. N.Y. Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term, Part I.
Headnote: Employees' mental approach, that is, their professed belief that one corporation was their employer, was not sufficient to effect a merger of identities where such corporation and another were separate and distinct and each apparently assumed its appropriate responsibility under federal and state requirements.
Document Preview: Action by motor carrier against its alleged local cartage agent and unions, with which carrier and cartage agent had executed separate collective bargaining agreements, to determine whether carrier had contract with union which had entered into agreement with cartage agent. Upon motion and cross motions for summary judgment, the Supreme Court, Special Term, Stevens, J., held that motor carrier would be bound by collective bargaining agreement it had executed with one union, but not by agreement executed by cartage agent and, other union, in absence of proof of agency on part of cartage agent in regard to execution of agent's collective bargaining agreement with other union. Motion and cross motions denied. See also 9 Misc.2d 691, 173 N.Y.S.2d 877.

Title: Babis v. Mount Jacob Cemetery Co.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Compensation board was not justified in absence of unfairness, injustice or compelling public policy, in disregarding corporate entity and determining that corporation director who was killed while about corporation's work had received money from corporation not as salary or wages but as proceeds of participation in a joint venture.
Document Preview: Workmen's compensation case. The compensation board set aside referee's award but the Court of Common Pleas, Delaware County, at No. 601, September Term, 1953, Arthur P. Bretherick, J., reversed the board, and employer and insurer appealed. The Superior Court, at No. 246, October Term, 1955, Ross, J., held that board's finding that decedent, who was a stockholder and director in corporation and who was killed while about corporations's work, had received pay otherwise than as a director or officer, as indicated by corporation's pay rool records, was inconsistent with finding that decedent had not been an employee of corporation, and required that case be remanded. Judgment reversed and record remanded.

Title: Warren v. Motion Picture Mach. Operators New Castle Local No. 451 of Intern. Alliance of Theatrical Stage Emp. and Moving Picture Mach. Operators of U. S. and Canada
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where family corporation which owned drive-in theater employed stockholder-member of family as nonunion projectionist, in violation of terms of contract between corporation and projectionists' union, corporate veil would not be pierced to regard person as self-employed. 43 P.S. §§ 206a et seq., 206c(c).
Document Preview: Proceeding by family-owned theatre corporation against projectionists' union for damages and injunctive relief against picketing. The Court of Common Pleas of Lawrence County at No. 3, September Term, 1955, in Equity, John G. Lamoree, J., denied the plaintiff relief on the ground that a bona fide labor dispute existed, which was not enjoinable. The theater appealed. The Supreme Court, No. 207, March Term, 1955, Musmanno, J., held that where family corporation, which owned drive-in theater, employed stockholder-member of family as non-union projectionist, in violation of terms of contract between corporation and projectionists' union, a labor dispute was involved, within statute prohibiting the issuance of injunctions in labor disputes, except upon certain conditions. Order affirmed.

Title: Goldmann v. Johanna Farms, Inc.
Court: County Court, New Jersey, Mercer County, Law Division.
Headnote: Where owner sold one-half of farming corporation's stock to workmen's compensation claimant and his three copartners under agreement, and claimant became corporation's farm manager and vice-president, and owner and partners each controlled one-half of the directors, corporate veil would not be pierced for purpose of preventing recovery for injuries received by claimant as employee of corporation.
Document Preview: Workmen's compensation proceeding by corporation's vice-president and farm manager against corporation and compensation carrier for injuries allegedly received when petitioner was blown off porch steps which he was ascending after having checked on existing milk supply at request of corporation's assistant farm manager. The Division of Workmen's Compensation, Department of Labor and Industry entered award of total permanent disability is favor of petitioner, and respondents appealed. The County Court, Law Division, Hutchinson, J.C.C., held that injuries, which were received in accident which occurred while petitioner was in performance of special service for his employer and which arose out of and in course of his employment, were compensable under Workmen's Compensation Act. Award affirmed as to corporation and reversed as to compensation carrier.

Title: Schusterman v. Appeal Bd. of Mich. Employment Sec. Commission
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Where two apartment building projects were designed as two separate entities on recommendation of Federal Housing Administration, and two separate corporations, having same stockholders, were formed to carry out the projects, the accounts and records of which were separately kept, and there was no plan of avoidance of contributions to state unemployment compensation fund, the two corporations did not constitute a single employing unit under the employment security act, but each was a separate and distinct unit. Comp.Laws 1948, §§ 421.1 et seq., 421.41(3).
Document Preview: Proceeding for unemployment compensation. The referee's decision that neither of two corporations by whom claimant was employed during period involved, considered separately, was an employer within meaning of employment security act, and that claim would therefor be denied, was affirmed by the Appeal Board of the Unemployment Compensation Commission, but decision of Appeal Board was reversed by Circuit Court, Wayne County, on certiorari, and employers appealed. The Supreme Court, Sharpe, J., held that where two apartment building projects were designed as two separate entities on recommendation of Federal Housing Administration, and two separate corporations, having same stockholders, were formed to carry out the projects, the accounts and records of which were separately kept, and where there was no plan of avoidance of contributions to unemployment compensation fund, the two corporations did not constitute a single employing unit under the act, but each was a separate and...

Title: Sasmor v. V. Vivaudou, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Trial Term, Part 16.
Headnote: Where wholly owned subsidiary corporation was a separate and distinct entity, was treated as such, and was not used as a decoy or fraudulent front for the benefit of parent corporation, fact that parent corporation owned all of the capital stock of subsidiary and through identity of officers and directors controlled subsidiary did not justify court, sitting without a jury in law action, in disregarding the corporate entity of subsidiary and holding parent corporation liable for contract of employment knowingly made with subsidiary alone by sales manager who was at the time a stockholder of parent corporation.
Document Preview: Action by Louis Sasmor against V. Vivaudou, Inc., and another to recover damages for breach of contract of employment of plaintiff as sales manager for named defendant. The Supreme Court, Trial Term, Matthew M. Levy, J., held that the evidence established that plaintiff had received timely written notice of termination of employment at expiration of initial term pursuant to provision in contract for its renewal for a like term unless written notice to the contrary was given by either party to the other on or before specified date. Plaintiff's motion for judgment in his favor denied and judgment on the merits in favor of defendants granted.

Court: United States District Court E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: An individual who has attempted to use the corporate entity to escape the prescriptions and proscriptions of the Walsh-Healey Act may be held personally responsible for violating them. Walsh-Healey Act, §§ 1-11, as amended, 41 U.S.C.A. §§ 35-45.
Document Preview: Action by the United States of America against Hudgins-Dize Company, Inc., and others to recover as liquidated damages the amount of the underpayment of overtime wages for alleged violations of the Walsh-Healey Act, Secs. 1-11, as amended, 41 U.S.C.A. §§ 35-45.  On motions for summary judgment. Decision in accordance with opinion.
