Title: Dallas Liquor Warehouse No. 4 v. State
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: The Unemployment Compensation Act regards corporate organization objectively and realistically, unencumbered by fictions of corporate identity, and deals with substance, not form. Vernon's Ann.Civ.St. art. 5221b-1 et seq.

Title: Martin v. John S. Doane Co.
Court: District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Where veteran's mother had owned stock of corporation employing veteran when he entered naval service, but had sold stock before he was discharged, he was entitled to look to corporation and not to his mother for re-employment as required under Selective Service Act. Selective Training and Service Act of 1940, 50 U.S.C.A.Appendix, § 301 et sq.
Document Preview: Action by John J. Martin, Jr., against the John S. Doane Company to compel the defendant to restore the plaintiff to his former position with the defendant corporation and to recover money damages to compensate him for loss of wages because of the defendant's action. Title: Boutell v. Walling
Court: Supreme Court of the United States
Headnote: Mechanics of copartnership engaged exclusively in servicing motor transportation equipment operated in interstate commerce by a corporation of which the partners were sole stockholders were not exempt from maximum hour provisions of Fair Labor Standards Act, under clause exempting any employee with respect to whom Interstate Commerce Commission has power to establish maximum hours of service. Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, § 13(b)(1), 29 U.S.C.A. § 213(b)(1); Interstate Commerce Act, § 204(a)(1-3), 49 U.S.C.A. § 304(a)(1-3).
Document Preview: Suit by L. Metcalfe Walling, Administrator of the Wage and Hour Division, United States Department of Labor, against Anna M. Boutell and another, doing business as F. J. Boutell Service Company, to enjoin defendants from violating the maximum hour provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, 29 U.S.C.A. s 201 et seq. A judgment granting an injunction was affirmed, 148 F.2d 329, and the defendants bring certiorari. Affirmed. Mr. Justice DOUGLAS, Mr. Justice FRANKFURTER and Mr. Justice RUTLEDGE, dissenting. On Writ of Certiorari to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

Title: Consolidated Realty Co. v. Dyers, Finishers and Bleachers Federation
Court: Court of Chancery of New Jersey.
Headnote: A corporate landlord, owned and controlled by and having same officers and office manager as its corporate tenant, employees of which were on strike, was involved in same labor dispute as tenant, and hence not entitled to injunction pendente lite against labor unions' interference with deliveries of fuel oil and coal to landlord for tenant's use, in absence of evidence of coercion, threats or intimidation by pickets to prevent such deliveries. N.J.S.A. 2:29-77.8.
Document Preview: Suit in equity by the Consolidated Realty Company against the Dyers, Finishers and Bleachers Federation and others for injunction against interference with delivery of fuel oil and coal to complainant. Title: Packard Clothes v. Director of Div. of Employment Sec.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Corporation which took over and operated the business formerly conducted by an individual under two fictitious firm names, which corporation was managed and controlled by such individual, who was principal stockholder in corporation, although a separate legal entity from individual, was successor in fact of such businesses and became successor employing unit of former employing units within meaning of Unemployment Compensation Act and as such was entitled to merit rating previously acquired by individual. Title: In re Patterson
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where individual owner of taxicab business in order to evade responsibility under Labor Relations Act because of certain violations of the Act, organized a corporation and transferred taxicab business to it, but retained control of business and continued violation of act, corporation was properly held responsible for previous violations of act by individual owner. 43 P.S. § 211.6(1) (a, d, e).

Title: Gerdert v. Certified Poultry & Egg Co.
